column1: Apple Inc. Has Big Plans for Its Fast-Growing Services Business;February 04
column3: 11:22:00 AM EDT;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is primarily a hardware company. Most of its   revenue comes from the sale of iPhone
column4: iPad
column5: and Mac products.   Beyond those key product categories
column6: the company generates   meaningful revenue from its Apple Watch family of smartwatch   products
column7: as well as from the various accessories
column8: such as its   well-received AirPod line of wireless earbuds.Apple music running on different Apple products. Image     source: Apple.makeArticleAd();However
column9: one of the most exciting parts of the company's   portfolio is the services business
column10: which the company says   ""includes revenue from Digital Content and Services
column11: AppleCare
column12: Apple Pay
column13: licensing and other services.""This segment has been on a robust growth path for quite some   time
column14: with revenue here growing 10% in the company's fiscal year   2015 and then a whopping 22% in fiscal year 2016. In the   company's most recent quarter
column15: it reported that services revenue   was up another 18% year-over-year.This isn't a small business
column16: either -- at least in absolute   terms. It generated more than $24 billion in the company's last   fiscal year
column17: making up more than 10% of the company's   consolidated revenue. To really put it into proper perspective
column18: services was Apple's second-largest business by revenue in 2016   -- bigger than the iPad and Mac.On the company's most recent earnings call
column19: CEO Tim Cook made   public the company's vision for services over the next four   years
column20: and it's quite ambitious.Doubling revenue in just four years""Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column21: and we   expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company this   year""
column22: Cook said.Cook then went on to say that Apple ""feel[s] great about this   momentum"" and that the company aims to ""double the size of [its]   Services business in the next four years"".Of course
column23: what Apple's goals are and what happens aren't   necessarily the same thing
column24: but the fact that management is   willing to put a growth figure out there -- a hard number that   investors will now hold Apple accountable for -- speaks to the   company's confidence.What would a doubling of this business mean?Put simply
column25: doubling the business from the revenue levels seen   in 2016 would mean that
column27: Apple's services business will   be bringing in about $48 billion. If Apple can get the business   to that scale and then grow it at a modest rate from that point   forward (perhaps 5% to 10% annually)
column28: then that would do wonders   for Apple's longer-term revenue growth prospects.What's not entirely clear
column29: however
column30: is how that growth will   translate into incremental profitability. CFO Luca Maestri said   on the call that
column31: on average
column32: the gross profit margin of Services   businesses ishigherthan the corporate average
column33: so an increase in Services mix should   help Apple on the gross profit margin front.That said
column34: as Apple scales up its services revenue
column35: it will   likely need to drive up operating expenses associated with the   business
column36: as well. While I do expect nice growth in profitability   from a boost in services
column37: the incremental gross profit isn't all   flowing to the bottom line.At the end of the day
column38: if Apple hits its growth target with   respect to this growing segment
column39: it should be less dependent on   the iPhone and could ultimately see earnings multiple expansion   as software/services companies tend to be valued more by   investors than pure hardware plays.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Will Donald Trump Target Share Buybacks Next?;February 04
column3: 08:02:00 AM EDT;"Donald Trump. Image source: Whitehouse.gov.President Donald Trump has taken several bold steps since   taking office
column4: but one area seems to be a bigger priority than   any other. Trump has been adamant about getting American   companies to invest in the U.S. by building factories and plants   and hiring American workers. In his inaugural address
column5: he   declared that as a central theme of his presidency
column6: imploring   American companies to ""buy American and hire American.""makeArticleAd();Before he even took the oath of office
column7: Trump said he had   struck a deal withUnited Technologies'Carrier Industries to keep about 800 jobs in Indiana that were   slated to go to Mexico. He pressured other manufacturers like   automakers to keep jobs in the country
column8: and may have influencedFord'sdecision to scrap plans for a new plant in Mexico.Once in office
column9: Trump backed out of the Trans Pacific   Partnership
column10: a 12-nation trade deal
column11: and met with leaders of the   Big 3 automakers to urge them to expand in the U.S.While those moves may help curry the favor of Trump's base
column12: their effect on investment in the U.S. is uncertain. The   automakers already believe that the auto market is at its   cyclical peak
column13: as last year marked a record for vehicle sales
column14: and they are therefore reluctant to invest in new factories.Manufacturing jobs have certainly declined over the past   generation
column15: but analysts tend to blame that on automation rather   than outsourcing.Trump has supported tax breaks that would encourage companies   to bring back money kept overseas. Some see this as step one to   getting the companies to invest in American jobs. Others see it   as priming the companies to use the money to buy back their own   shares. Larry Fink
column16: BlackRock founder and CEO and a member of   Trump's ""President's Strategic and Policy Forum
column17: recently warned   that companies should only engage in buybacks ""when they are   confident that the return on those buybacks will ultimately   exceed the cost of capital and the long-term returns of investing   in future growth.""Fink mentioned Trump by name twice in his Jan. 24annual letter to CEOs
column18: saying in part:If tax reform also includes some form of reduced taxation     for repatriation of cash trapped overseas
column19: BlackRock will be     looking to companies' strategic frameworks for an explanation     of whether they will bring cash back to the U.S.
column20: and if so
column21: how they plan to use it. Will it be used simply for more share     buybacks? Or is it a part of a capital plan that appropriately     balances returning capital to shareholders with prudently     investing for future growth?President Trump has indicated an interest in infrastructure     investment
column22: which has the dual benefits of improving overall     productivity and creating jobs
column23: especially for workers     displaced by technology.Fink went on to write that infrastructure investing is not a   solution to automation taking jobs
column24: saying ""businesses will need   to increase the earnings potential of the workers who drive   returns
column25: helping the employee who once operated a machine learn   to program it.""Trump has showed himself committed to American jobs. We don't   know if he will use his bully pulpit to try to force companies to   forgo buybacks
column26: but he might if he follows the logic that doing   so would result in the companies instead putting the money to use   in ways that would boost American workers. Let's take a look at   the issue.A Wall Street favoriteShare repurchases
column27: orbuybacks
column28: in which a company buys share of its own stock
column29: were once   illegal
column30: as they were seen as facilitating insider trading   because a company could act on information not available to the   public. The SEC changed the rule in 1982
column31: and since then
column32: stock   buybacks have become increasingly popular. According toHSBC
column33: American companies have spent $2.1 trillion on repurchases over   the last five years.Often called a form of financial engineering by detractors
column34: share buybacks boost a company's earnings per share
column35: not by   increasing earnings
column36: but by reducing the number of shares   outstanding. The pie is split among fewer shares. Investors to   tend to cheer share buybacks due to the lift they give to stock   prices
column37: but from a larger economic perspective
column38: and possibly from   Donald Trump's point of view
column39: they may be the least efficient   form of spending cash.Image source: Getty Images.By allocating money to buy back shares
column40: business are choosing   to spend profits on inflating earnings per share instead of   potentially investing in the long-term growth of the business by   opening new plants
column41: hiring or training new workers
column42: investing in   research and development
column43: or even acquiring other companies.   Unlike dividends
column44: the other from of returning capital to   shareholders
column45: buybacks don't give money to current shareholders   that can be reinvested
column46: and they do not add market value to the   company
column47: which is based in part on the number of shares   outstanding. In other words
column48: no value is being created by   repurchases in the aggregate.  Share repurchases are   controversial for a number of reasons
column49: but their ability to   dissuade companies from investing in long-term growth is   certainly one of the biggest.How the pros do itWith interest rates especially low in recent years
column50: many   companies have taken on debt
column51: not to expand their businesses
column52: but   to reward shareholders with buybacks.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) founder Steve Jobs refused to pay a dividend
column53: believing that it meant the company was out of ideas. He also   didn't authorize share repurchases.Apple under Tim Cook
column54: however
column55: has taken out $87 billion in   debt to fund repurchases
column56: reducing the share count by 1.3 billion   in the process
column57: and spending about $125 billion in the process.   Part of the reason Apple has done so is because much of its cash   is parked overseas and it wants to avoid repatriation taxes
column58: but   one could see the Trump administration cutting a deal with the   iPhone maker to reduce or eliminate repatriation taxes if it   agreed to invest in jobs in the U.S.Apple
column59: with nearly $200 billion overseas
column60: has been demanding   such an arrangement for years
column61: and could be willing to invest   some of that cash in the U.S. if the tax rate was significantly   reduced. Notably FoxConn
column62: its biggest supplier
column63: said it was   considering opening a plant in Pennsylvania that would employ   50
column64: 000 Americans. Apple is unlikely itself to invest in domestic   manufacturing
column65: but since FoxConn assembles iPhones and other   Apple products
column66: if it opened a plant in Pennsylvania
column67: it would   mean that some Apple products would be made in America
column68: though   outsourced to a Chinese company.Trump has said he would like to make deals with corporations   to bring some of their overseas cash back home
column69: though that would   likely come with stipulations.Goldman Sachspredicted Trump's tax and repatriation plans would encourage more   buybacks as it frees up cash for companies
column70: but BlackRock's Fink   scolded corporations in his recent letter for spending so much on   buybacks.He noted that the total thatS&P 500companies have spent on dividends and buybacks in the last   12 months is greater than the operating profits they've   earned. With $5 trillion in assets under management
column71: the   Blackrock CEO's missives attract attention on Wall Street
column72: and if   he gets the President's ear
column73: Trump could end up using the bully   pulpit to excoriate big business for its excessive buybacks.IBM's(NYSE: IBM) recent misadventures perhaps best illustrate the   folly of buybacks. After outlining a goal in 2010 of reaching $20   in earnings per share (EPS) by 2015
column74: Big Blue spent aggressively   on repurchases to pump up EPS to meet that target
column75: pouring $70   billion between 2010-2014 into lowering its share count. As a   result
column76: however
column77: the business suffered.Revenue at the tech giant has now fallen for 19 quarters in a   row
column78: and the company was forced to step back from its $20 EPS   goal in 2014. In 2016
column79: adjusted EPS was just $13.59
column80: down 9% from   the previous year. In the meantime
column81: IBM has also slashed   headcount as the number of employees has fallen by close to   100
column83: since its peak in 2014
column84: to 368
column85: 000. Considering Big   Blue's decision to use profits to reward investors while laying   off employees
column86: the company would seem to be a target ripe for   Trump's ire.It's not just tech companies that are using this tactic
column87: as   manufacturers likeGM
column88: Ford
column89: andCaterpillarhave all been spending on share repurchases recently.Any attempt by the Trump administration to tackle share   repurchases would likely rankle Wall Street
column90: which favors the   practice. But as the president looks for more levers to pull to   boost the ""forgotten men and women"" of America
column91: share buybacks   may start to look like a worthy target.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Why This 1 Number Is So Important to Apple Investors;February 03
column3: 07:08:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.The iPhone is by far the most important product inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) lineup. The device accounted for over 69% of the   company's first-quarter sales. After three consecutive quarters   of unit sales declines
column4: Apple righted the ship with the release   of the iPhone 7 last fall
column5: driving a near-5% increase in unit   sales.makeArticleAd();But more important than the growth in units is Apple's ability   to sell its higher-end device
column6: the iPhone 7 Plus. CEO Tim Cook   revealed the newest model was the best selling Plus model it's   released yet during the company's first-quarter earnings call.   The ability to sell higher-end devices is key for the company   going forward as it becomes increasingly difficult to grow unit   sales.A look at selling pricesData source: Apple quarterly reports.The first thing that stands out in the chart above is the huge   drop in average sales price (ASP) during the previous three   quarters. The drop coincides with the release of the lower-priced   iPhone SE
column7: which starts at just $399. After a late second-quarter   release
column8: sales of the model seemed to peak in the third quarter
column9: resulting in a low $595 ASP for all iPhone units.Apple also faced significant foreign exchange headwinds over   the past year. CFO Luca Maestri noted the dollar has strengthened   25% against the basket of currencies where Apple does business   since June 2014. That led Apple to raise some of its prices in   foreign countries last year.But more iPhone shoppers opted for the high-end iPhone 7 Plus   last quarter
column10: leading to a record ASP of $695. That's even more   astonishing considering the inclusion of the iPhone SE in those   sales.What's so telling about the popularity of the iPhone 7   Plus?Unlike in the two previous Plus models of the iPhone
column11: the 7   Plus included a higher-end camera compared to its   smaller-screened sister. That point of differentiation may be   what led more consumers to opt for the more expensive device last   quarter.The significant demand for the 7 Plus shows that Apple has the   potential to drive sales growth by further differentiating the   Plus lineup from the standard iPhone model. Instead of just   offering a larger screen
column12: Apple can keep its best innovations   exclusively for its highest-paying customers before letting them   trickle down to the lower-priced models.Such a move would strengthen the position of the Plus model in   the simple good
column13: better
column14: best price positioning Apple uses. Just   as importantly
column15: the upsell is easy thanks to installment plans --   just $4 more per month gets you the best ever phone
column16: camera
column17: mobile gaming machine
column18: Snapchat device
column19: and so on.But don't get excited just yetThere's no doubt that Apple benefited from one of its biggest   competitors running into some technical difficulties late last   year.Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) had to recall its Galaxy Note 7 after units   started randomly exploding due to battery malfunctions.Many Note 7 customers likely ended up buying an iPhone 7 Plus   for its similarly sized screen. Cook noted it saw the highest   Android switcher rate of any quarter.Obviously
column20: Apple can't rely on Samsung or one of its other   major competitors having problems with their large-screen phones   every quarter. That's why investors must pay attention to the   iPhone ASP going forward to see if last quarter was a fluke or if   Apple's differentiation strategy is paying off. If ASP continues   to rise

column1: Why 2 Well-Known Tech Companies Are Making Significant AI Acquisitions;February 03
column3: 05:22:00 PM EDT;"With the race for artificial intelligence (AI) shifting into   high gear
column4: companies are not only developing AI systems in-house
column5: but are increasingly bringing start-ups into the fold to augment   their efforts. Market intelligence firm CB Insights released its   list ofAI acquisitionsover the last five years. A review of the most active acquirers   can provide insight into future developments at those companies
column6: and show how the new technologies are being integrated.Artificial intelligence acquisitions are skyrocketing. Image     source: Pixabay.makeArticleAd();One intriguing revelation is that many of the acquired   companies work in the areas of deep learning and machine   learning
column7: two disciplines within AI. Algorithms and software are   used to develop models of the human brain called neural networks
column8: attempting to recreate our capacity to learn. Another revelation   is that much of the acquired technology can be directly   integrated intovirtual personal assistants. This is an area of great interest to big tech
column9: but is alsobeing pursuedby a surprising number ofother companies.Apple is on an AI buying spree. Image source: Author.Apple is giving Siri a makeoverApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has been at the leading edge of AI since its   introduction of Siri five years ago. While it is making a   significant number of acquisitions
column10: each appears to specialize in   a different area:VocalIQ concentrated its deep-learning capabilities to     better understand human speech. This could provide Siri with an     upgrade.Perceptio can run neural-network algorithms and perform     advanced calculations locally on a cellphone
column11: without uploading     user data to the cloud. This would help Apple protect consumer     data bykeeping it localto each phone.Emotient attempts to read facial expressions in order to     determine a person's emotional state. This recent acquisition     is likely related to apatent Apple applied forin 2014
column12: describing a system for determining mood based on     numerous factors
column13: including facial expressions.Tuplejump provided a better way to apply deep learning to     large data sets as they are uploaded. Apple has previously     stated that it could receive filtered data from iPhones
column14: and     this technology would enable it to process the data in real     time.One especially compelling acquisition was Turi
column15: described as a   ""machine learning platform for developers and data scientists.""   It had created tools that allowed developers to build apps   utilizing deep learning that could scale for many users; this   tool kit was described as being similar to Google's TensorFlow   open-source machine-learning library. Turi allows Apple to bring   AI capabilities to developers for its App Store offerings.Twitter wants a seat at the big tech tableTwitter acquired Whetlab to boost AI efforts. Image source:     Whetlab.Twitter(NYSE:TWTR) has made a number of AI-related acquisitions in the area of   machine learning. Each appears to provide the company with   specific opportunities to improve its current business:Madbits focused on technology related to searching and     understanding images
column16: and the ability to organize large data     sets. It previously released an iOS app that created photo     collages.Magic Pony developed neural networks that can sharpen     blurry cellphone images or video to near HD-quality. It also     can use information in the original to improvise new or     expanded images -- great for use in virtual reality. These will     both help Twitter increase its image features.TellApart allows marketers to better target potential     customers across device platforms. This could improve     monetization of Twitter's ads.Whetlab is probably the most interesting acquisition. While it   is less business-specific
column17: it will bring the most advanced AI   capability. It created technology that helps companies jump-start   their deep learning by providing an infrastructure; the time   required to train AI systems is reduced from months to days. This   technology can be used to improve a variety of areas in Twitter's   business
column18: including language understanding
column19: image recognition
column20: and user profiles.These acquisitions reveal how two very different technology   companies are integrating AI with a goal of improving their   respective businesses. Acquisitions for their own sake are folly
column21: but using them to gain a competitive advantage
column22: improve business   processes
column23: or to better serve customers can lead to success. Time   will tell how successful each of these companies has been in   leveraging these technologies.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 3 Interesting Things We Learned From Snapchat's IPO Prospectus;February 03
column4: the parent company of photo-sharing application Snapchat
column5: recently filed a prospectus with the SEC and is officially gearing up for an initial public offering. Snapchat has taken the social media landscape by storm since its debut in 2012
column6: and with private valuations hitting nearly $25 billion
column7: investors should be anticipating what could be the biggest tech IPO of the year.Snapchat co-founder and CEO Evan Spiegel
column8: alongside fellow founder and CTO Bobby Murphy
column9: will lead his company through this important period. At just 26 and 28 years of age
column10: Spiegel and Murphy are set to become some of the wealthiest under-30s in the world after Snap Inc. debuts; just how much their net worths will swell depends on how big the company's IPO can get
column11: and we got a better sense of this size from its recent prospectus filing.(Also Read:Inside Snapchat: The Best Tech IPO of 2017?)The prospectus contained tons of juicy information
column12: including key financial and membership data. For example
column13: we learned that Snapchat now has about 158 million average daily active users and its annual revenue swelled to $404.4 million in 2016. We also know that Snapchat plans to list its shares in March under the ticker ""SNAP."" The company filed for $3 billion debut
column14: but this is expected to be a placeholder until Snap Inc. prices the deal.All of this information is important to know and understand as investors think about investing in Snapchat at its IPO. However
column15: the juiciest details in the prospectus were ones that not every investor expected to see or knew to look for. Check out these three key facts that you may have missed:1.It's a ""camera company""  kind ofWhile most people would consider Snapchat a social media company
column16: its prospectus proudly proclaimed that ""Snap Inc. is a camera company."" In the sense that Snapchat is inherently interested in its users' phone cameras
column17: this is a logical statement; however
column18: Snapchat is certainly not-nor does it seem interested in becoming-a major manufacturer of camera-based hardware.Sure
column19: the company recently debuted its own line of camera-equipped sunglasses called ""Spectacles
column20: but as its prospectus points out
column21: 96% of revenue comes from advertising and that is unlikely to change soon. Do you know any other ""camera companies"" that rely on advertising revenue? Not really
column22: which means Snapchat's labeling of itself as a ""camera company"" is more about its focus on the importance of the camera as a communicative device
column23: not its business model.2.Mysterious third founder is goneThose who have followed Snapchat since its earliest days are probably already familiar with the impressive leadership of Spiegel and Murphy. However
column24: every Snapchat-related story seems to include a mention of Reggie Brown
column25: Snapchat's mysterious third founder who reportedly came up with the idea of disappearing photos.While we knew that Brown was no longer at the company
column26: the prospectus finally revealed the full details on the situation
column27: and it is a classic case of ""hush money"" that resembles the Winklevoss-Zuckerberg fiasco. According to the filing
column28: Brown sued the company over intellectual property violations in February 2013. The parties involved eventually settled in September 2014
column29: with Snap Inc. agreeing to pay Brown about $158 million in cash.3.They know their competitionOne of the key elements of a prospectus for a company like Snap Inc. is the information the company shares about its perceived challenges within its own industry. In that regard
column30: it is clear that Snapchat is acutely aware of its competitors right now.The company underscores the dangers of competitors that ""mimic"" Snapchat's features throughout the report
column31: and it uses a rhetoric of caution to describe the businesses that challenge it.""Many of our current and potential competitors have significantly greater resources and broader global recognition and occupy better competitive positions in certain markets than we do
column32: the prospectus said
column33: identifying FacebookFB
column34: AppleAAPL
column35: Alphabet Inc.GOOGL
column36: LINELN
column37: Twitter (TWTR)
column38: and many others as key foes.Final DetailsStartups like Snapchat benefit greatly from keeping their books closed and operating under the cover of being private
column39: but the era is nearly over for Snap Inc.
column40: and the company will soon have many new shareholders to please.Looking ahead
column41: we can expect a SNAP offering in March
column42: and pricing details should come closer to that time. Other than that
column43: we know that SNAP will be listed on the NYSE and some of the world's biggest banks
column44: including Morgan StanleyMS
column45: Goldman SachsGS
column46: JPMorganJPM
column47: Deutsche BankDB
column48: BarclaysBCS
column49: and Credit SuisseCS
column50: are working on the deal.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking   About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: AAPL is Facing a FaceTime Lawsuit;February 03
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a lawsuit over FaceTime. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.makeArticleAd();Source: Martin HajekFaceTime Lawsuit:Apple is facing a new lawsuit that claims it intentionally hurt FaceTime for iOS 6
column6: reportsMacRumors. According to the lawsuit
column7: AAPL allegedly placed a bug in FaceTime for iOS 6 in an effort to force users to upgrade to iOS 7. The lawsuit claims that this was done so that the company could avoid fees to Akami
column8: which handled the service in iOS 6. The release of iOS 7 saw the tech company introduce new peer-to-peer tech that didn't require Akami for use.LG UltraFine Fix:A new version of the LG UltraFine 5K display will fix issues with the device
column9: AppleInsidernotes. The new versions of the LG UltraFine 5K display will feature additional shielding to protect the devices from interference with routers. The company also says that it will put the additional shielding in current models of the display as well. It hasn't announced how it will do this yet. The problem with the current LG UltraFine 5K displays has them not working properly when near routers.BeatsX Launch: Apple is reportedly getting ready to launch its BeatsX headphones
column10: reports 9to5Mac. The BeatsX has faced a long delay after being announced at the same time as the iPhone 7. The delay had the company pushing back the launch to February. Now there are reports that the headphones will launch as soon as this week. The headphones will cost $149 when they launch.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: AAPL is Facing a FaceTime Lawsuitappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Tech Stocks That Will Win as Qualcomm Collapses;February 03
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's often stated by motivational speakers that the Chinese word for ""crisis"" is composed of two characters - one signifying danger
column5: the other opportunity. It's alsoembarrassingly inaccurate. This goes to show you that if the crux of an investment argument invokes ""the Chinese
column6: stop! You might be getting had. Still
column7: this ""Chinese philosophy"" is extremely relevant for tech stocks these days.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's because semiconductor and digital communications giantQualcomm
column8: Inc. (NASDAQ:QCOM) is having a year to forget. Despite the fact that it's only early February
column9: QCOM shares are down 18.5% year-to-date. Not surprisingly
column10: Qualcomm is trading firmly below its 50- and 200-day moving averages. If something substantive doesn't happen soon
column11: it risks repeating the disaster of 2015
column12: when QCOM lost nearly 31%.The disaster that Qualcomm is currently facing was seen well in advance by those watching the industry closely. The crux of the issue is the company's technology licensing business. This is themost lucrativedivision for QCOM
column13: accounting for the majority of its profits. By ""selling the rights to use patents that are essential to all modern mobile phone systems
column14: QCOM had a monopoly. That's an incredible opportunity
column15: so long as you don't get caught.Of course
column16: they got caught. First
column17: it was
column18: you guessed it - the Chinese. Regulators in the world's second-biggest economy found Qualcomm guilty of violating theiranti-monopoly law. Then
column19: individual companies began filing complaints. Finally
column20: the Federal Trade Commission got involved in mid-January
column21: claiming that QCOM illegally maintained a monopoly. Shares never looked the same after that
column22: and who knows when Qualcomm will recover.Those are questions that analysts will squabble over. But for rival tech stocks
column23: they only have one message - better you than me. It's not just the fact that a major competitor is falling. This is a classic case where an enemy of an enemy is a friend. Furthermore
column24: the benchmarkTechnology SPDR (ETF)(NYSEARCA:XLK) is up 4.6% YTD. Granted
column25: these aren't the best numbers
column26: but it's much more preferable than what Qualcomm is going through.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryWhile QCOM is swimming with the sharks
column27: here are three tech stocks that are now set up to win big!Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Apple Inc. (AAPL)Click to EnlargeUndoubtedly
column28: of all the tech stocks that were affected by Qualcomm
column29: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) stands to be the biggest winner.On Jan. 20
column30: AAPL filed suit against Qualcomm
column31: alleging that the company ""withheld $1 billion in rebates in retaliation for Apple cooperating with Korean efforts to open the radio chip market."" Although it's difficult to call a stalwart like AAPL a ""victim
column32: the pattern of allegations is pretty damning.First
column33: we already saw Qualcomm violate foreign anti-competition laws
column34: and pay dearly for it. Second
column35: Korean manufacturerSamsung Electronics Co. Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) alleged similar shenanigans
column36: although they later backed down. Finally
column37: and most importantly
column38: the FTC claimed that Qualcomm forced AAPL to use their chips to prevent competitor encroachment. For Qualcomm
column39: Applr is its biggest customer
column40: so the potential ramifications are deep and wide.Of course
column41: Cupertino isn't going to shed any tears.Last October
column42: AAPL ""reported its first decline in annual sales and profit in 15 years
column43: according toThe Guardian. There are serious concerns that the king of consumer tech stocks has reached peak popularity. Whatever it is
column44: Apple needs to boost its profitability. Getting out of unfavorable contracts is a good start.And with the world seemingly against Qualcomm
column45: AAPL has an excellent chance of reviving itself at their expense.Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Intel Corporation (INTC)Click to EnlargeAlthough I believe that Apple will get the most benefit out of the QCOM fiasco
column46: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) has a strong case as well. I wouldn't be surprised if most people viewed it as a toss-up between the two titans.Among tech stocks
column47: INTC is one of the most recognizable
column48: but for the wrong reasons. Everybody knows the ""Intel Inside"" slogan
column49: but the only problem is that it relates to the aging personal computer business.It's a common challenge for consumer tech stocks - INTC needs to find new blood. The company'srevenue growthisn't the most consistent in the world. That's why the partnership last year between Intel and AAPL was a much-needed step in the right direction. Up until that point
column50: Qualcomm was the sole provider of chips for the iPhone.In 2016
column51: INTC stepped in to provide half the demand. Apparently
column52: QCOM took exception to this arrangement; hence
column53: the FTC charges of competitive foul play.So far
column54: the market response towards Intel stock has been mixed. Therefore
column55: I still give the advantage to Apple. Nevertheless
column56: encouraging signs do exist. Yes
column57: shares are down 4% from its high of the year. However
column58: it's still very close to parity for the year. Furthermore
column59: INTC remains inside a bullish trend channel that began in late summer of 2015.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketThe collapse at Qualcomm just gives other tech stocks more options
column60: and Intel is happy to help.Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Broadcom Ltd (AVGO)Click to EnlargeWhile virtually all tech stocks are affected by the Qualcomm crisis
column61: few were as glued to their TV screens asBroadcom Ltd(NASDAQ:AVGO).As a semiconductor and communications company themselves
column62: AVGO is a direct competitor and rival to QCOM.Naturally
column63: if your primary nemesis goes down hard
column64: it raises the boat for everyone else. And Qualcomm is sinking quite nicely for the Singapore-based firm.It's not just the fact that QCOM has transitioned into the world's most hated stock. Nor is it the money that they'll have to dish out in penalties. Rather
column65: Qualcomm will be forced to fundamentally change its business plan. If it doesn't
column66: government watchdogs are on standby
column67: eager to pounce. That just gives AVGO and others a leg up. Maybe Broadcom is no saint. However
column68: at the moment
column69: the spotlight isn't on it
column70: providing a margin of comfort.Most importantly
column71: AVGO is making the most of its ""Chinese crisis."" On a YTD basis
column72: shares are up a smoking 16% - that's almost the exact inverse of Qualcomm's results. Furthermore
column73: Broadcom is trending inside a steadily rising channel. With so much ugliness associated with its primary rival
column74: it's hard not to see anything but optimism for AVGO.As of this writing
column75: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The post3 Tech Stocks That Will Win as Qualcomm Collapsesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: If You Like Apple Inc.
column5: 12:01:52 PM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column6: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSuccessful stock market investing over the long term takes skills in several disciplines. First
column7: you need to be able to think outside of the box by looking behind the headline stocks into lesser-known names operating behind the scenes.makeArticleAd();Now
column8: I am certainly not saying to avoid the headline names. Getting in early on a favorite stock is a sure way to stock market profits. But often
column9: once a stock starts making mainstream news headlines it's upward price momentum is about to slow or fail altogether.Identifying companies that support one or a combination of headline names yet do not get the same attention as the headliner is a consistent way to locate winning stocks for the long term.Once you locate your behind-the-news stock
column10: it's time to take a close look at its fundamentals to make certain there is support behind the price move. Are the fundamentals improving over time? Are revenue and sales upward-trending from quarter to quarter? Do the products and services support an overall societal or economic trend? These are the basic questions to answer before making an investing decision.Next
column11: make certain the share price is in an overall upward trend. This means judging whether the shares higher over the last year and by how much they are up relative to the headline name.Ideally
column12: the stock should be outpacing the headliner price-performance wise and consistently making new highs on the daily price chart.I like stocks that are trading at or near their highs for one of my favorite investing tactics
column13: trend following.I define trend following as buying stocks as they make new highs
column14: then riding the upward trend and protecting profits via trailing stops. Certainly
column15: there are many permutations of this basic method
column16: such as waiting for a short term pullback to enter long
column17: but for the purpose of this article
column18: buying breakouts to new highs will suffice.The ideal trend-following stock isSkyworks Solutions Inc(SWKS). This stock holds the key to the future of the Internet of Things. It has soared over 42% in the last 52 weeks
column19: and the company just keeps outperforming. With both strong fundamentals and robust technicals
column20: if there ever was a stock made to order for the trend-following investing method
column21: this is the one.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryI found this company by first noticing that thatApple Inc.(AAPL) shares had posted over 35% gains in the last 52 weeks
column22: despite the apparent slowdown in iPhone sales. This observation led me to look behind the headlines to see what companies Apple depends on as suppliers.Skyworks jumped out immediately
column23: as it obtains approximately 40% of its revenue from Apple
column24: and is also a supplier to Apple's Chinese smartphone competitors such as Huawei.The fact that shares of Skyworks had skyrocketed around 42% over the last year truly piqued my interest
column25: and here's whySkyworks specializes in connecting devices and technology
column26: and experts are predicting there will be 70 billion internet connected devices by 2020. Called the Internet of Things
column27: this burgeoning new web structure is expected to grow exponentially into the near future.Skyworks Solutions
column28: Inc. officially describes itself as an analog semiconductor company powering the wireless networking revolution. Its innovative products are connecting people
column29: places and things. These objects span some new and previously unimagined applications within the automotive
column30: broadband
column31: cellular infrastructure
column32: connected home
column33: industrial
column34: medical
column35: military
column36: smartphone
column37: tablet and wearable markets.The company posted strong results for its first fiscal quarter
column38: with revenue for the first fiscal quarter at $914.3 million
column39: up 9.4 percent sequentially and exceeding consensus estimates of $902.7 million.Operating income for the first fiscal quarter of 2017 was $321.9 million with diluted earnings per share of $1.38. Cash flow from operations for the quarter was also a record $495.9 million.""Skyworks delivered exceptional financial results in the first fiscal quarter of 2017 fueled by global demand for ubiquitous mobile connectivity and the Internet of Things
column40: said Liam K. Griffin
column41: president and chief executive officer of Skyworks. ""We are enabling the next phase of the wireless revolution
column42: powering new and previously unimagined applications Skyworks is uniquely positioned to capitalize on this connectivity megatrend.""The company also positively guided that it will beat consensus revenue and non-GAAP EPS estimates in its fiscal second quarter.Even better
column43: the company just launched a $500 million stock buyback program that should further accelerate the upward price trend.Risks To Consider:Whenever one is investing in high tech
column44: there is always a competitive risk. New companies with innovative products cause disruption in the high-tech sector on a consistent basis. The disruption can dethrone leading firms and cause havoc to share prices.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Smartwatch Is Still Dominant Despite All the DoubtAction To Take:Following the trend following theme
column45: enter long on an upside break of $93.00 per share with an upside target of $135.00 per share. Initial stops are suggested at $83.00 per share.Editor's Note:These are ourTop 10 ""win-win"" stocksfor a chaotic 2017. No matter what Trump does (or how the markets respond) these stocks are poised to soar into double-digit gains over the next few months.Check out the list hereStreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent
column46: unbiased - and most of all
column47: profitable - investing ideas. Unlike traditional publishers
column48: StreetAuthority doesn't simply regurgitate the latest stock market news. Instead
column49: we provide in-depth research
column50: plus specific investment ideas and immediate action to take based on the latest market events. Visit us atStreetAuthority.com.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You BackThe postIf You Like Apple Inc.

column1: How Options Traders Nailed Amazon.com
column4: 11:33:22 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn a market known for its power of perfect pricing
column6: nowhere is that more obvious than inAmazon.com
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). But if you're looking for answers from AMZN stock
column8: that's only one-half of this puzzling confirmation.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonIf you're an Amazon shareholder
column9: Friday's early morning low of $801 - off more than 4% - wasn't exactly money in the bank. AMZN stock is on the defensive followinglast night's earnings release
column10: which put investors into profit-taking mode.AMZN Stock by the NumbersAmazon reported better-than-expected profits of $1.54
column11: beating the Street view by 17 cents. Sales
column12: on the other hand
column13: were short of estimates
column14: at $43.7 billion versus a $44.68 billion bar. For the full year
column15: though
column16: profits quadrupled on a 27% increase in revenues.The company's operating income outlook has possibly raised some hairs on the backs of AMZN bulls. A forecast of $250 million to $900 million falls well below the Street's consensus of $1.33 billion. But it's not as bad as it looks
column17: as most of the ""warning"" is tied to aggressive investments in media
column18: fulfillment and India.As well
column19: while investors are failing to rejoice Friday
column20: Amazon also delivered the goods with its operating cash flow
column21: which jumped by 38% to $16.4 billion.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketWhat's more
column22: revenues of $3.54 billion from its coveted Amazon Web Services (AWS) unit climbed an impressive 47% over last year's same-quarter result of $2.41 billion
column23: while contributing 9% to Amazon's net revenues for the year.By the ""Other"" Numbers That said
column24: Amazon's report hasn't been nearly as punishing from the standpoint of professional options traders.Based on last night's 03 Feb $840 straddle market
column25: pricing of $42 for the non-directional spread with AMZN stock at $840 amounted to traders putting the over/under bet at 5% or estimated range from $798 to $882. This weekly contract
column26: which expires today
column27: is the purest play on the earnings event and collectively tells us what traders expect for Amazon shares in the immediate aftermath of the announcement.Further
column28: as most often it's the professional options traders and market makers that sell options premiums
column29: the basic assumption is this more informed and disciplined group is collectively wagering on the ""under"" side of the 5% in AMZN stock.So far
column30: not only has Friday's low of $801 in Amazon shares fallen within the forecast by options traders
column31: but relative to past earnings events of the last few years
column32: call and put premiums were decidedly below average.Thehistorical recordshows that over the past five years
column33: the average up or down move in Amazon stock has been 8.4%
column34: with a median reaction of 8.1%. Fine-tuning the price activity down to the last five quarters
column35: AMZN's average move has been slightly higher at 9%
column36: but a modestly lower median of 7.7%.AMZN Stock Daily ChartClick to EnlargeFinally
column37: Friday's conditions in Amazon shares may not have been as fierce as we've been led to believe.Take a look at the accompanying chart. Ifcharts don't lie
column38: then AMZN stockclearlywas a double-top pattern.I'm being facetious
column39: of course. But even if I wasn't
column40: I'd always look to hedge my directional bet with options and money management opportunities in case I read a chart like Amazon's with less-than-perfect forecasting.Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. The information offered is based upon Christopher Tyler's observations and strictly intended for educational purposes only; the use of which is the responsibility of the individual. column1: Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock: 2 Reasons to Steer Clear;February 03
column4: 10:51:38 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAdvanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ:AMD) is coming off a fourth-quarter earnings beat in which the company reported $1.1 billion in revenue. AMD stock bounced 16% to above the $12 level as a result
column6: continuing a red-hot streak of nearly 500% returns in just 52 weeks.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrThis was a sub-$2 stockjust a year agoamid fears about competition and potential bankruptcy.AMD is a leading maker of graphics cards
column7: including Radeon for consumers and FirePro for workstations. The company operates in two segments: Computing and Graphics
column8: which makes desktop and notebook processors and professional graphics; andEnterprise
column9: Embedded and Semi-Custom
column10: producing server chips
column11: embedded processors for the Internet of Things and chips for gaming consoles.Since taking the helm two years ago
column12: Advanced Micro Devices CEOLisa Su-  an MIT-educated electrical engineer who has authored over 40 technical papers - has presided over a remarkable recovery. Now
column13: AMD
column14: having played second fiddle toIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) for decades
column15: ismaking a playfor the PC and server markets
column16: Intel's bread and butter. AMD's Ryzen CPU will challenge Intel's Core i5 and i7 chips.AMD is moving up the value chain amid a falling PC market
column17: going from low-end to high-end PC processors .Even if prospects for Advanced Micro Devices' business are good
column18: though
column19: investors have to deal with a few issues. AMD hasn't posted an operating profit since the third quarter of 2014
column20: holds a great deal of debt and yet trades at a stratospheric valuation.Amid these high expectations and gains worthy of bubble talk
column21: is AMD stock still a buy? Here are two problems that should have the bulls taking a second look.AMD Has a Not-Great Balance SheetDespite many chipmakers such as AMD going ""fabless"" and outsourcing the fabrication of their chips to contract manufacturers such asTaiwan Semiconductor Mfg. Co. Ltd. (ADR)(NYSE:TSM)
column22: the industry remains capital-intensive.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketAdvanced Micro Devices escaped bankruptcy last year. It took advantage of low interest rates and improved investor confidence to restructure its debt in September 2016. AMD issued$600 million in sharesand $450 million in convertible senior notes. This enabled AMD to pay off $676 million in debt due in 2020. So instead of $600 million in AMD debt maturing in 2019
column23: only $196 million will mature that year.Still
column24: AMD is highly leveraged by several measures. With $1.435 billion in long-term debt and $416 million in shareholder equity as of Dec. 31
column26: AMD's long-term debt-to-equity ratio stands at 3.44. That figure is much lower for Intel
column28: andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA)
column30: indicating less leverage. Likewise
column31: AMD's debt-to-capital ratio of 0.775 stands above 0.27 for both INTC and NVDA.Intel and Nvidia also are better able to service debt. For the year ended December 31
column33: AMD generated only $90 million in operating cash flow
column34: with $2.9 billion in total liabilities
column35: a ratio of 0.031.NVDA earned $1.462 billion in operating cash flow for the four quarters ended October 30
column37: with $4.24 billion in total liabilities
column38: a ratio of 0.34.Intel showed an even healthier balance sheet
column39: with $19.09 billion in operating cash flow for $48 billion in total liabilities
column40: a ratio of 0.396.AMD Stock Is Much More ExpensiveNvidia and Intel are profitable and have a better track record of generating operating cash flow. They earned positive operating cash flow in the four most recent quarters
column41: while AMD's operating cash flow went negative for two quarters.Still
column42: AMD stock trades at a huge premium to both.AMD trades at a whopping 25.66 times book
column43: versus 11.5 for Nvidia (which itself is high)
column44: and 2.61 for Intel. It's not difficult to justify a higher price than Intel given AMD's growth prospects
column45: but for comparison's sake
column46: know that while Wall Street sees Advanced Micro Devices growing revenues roughly 10% this year and next
column47: NVDA should be sitting at roughly 37% annual sales growth after it reports Q4 earnings
column48: with analysts expecting that to slow to ""only"" 16% next year.ConclusionIt's difficult to fight the momentum
column49: but you might just want to in AMD stock. At this point
column50: anyone tussling with Advanced Micro Devices is playing with overpriced fire.Should You Buy FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? 3 Pros
column51: 3 ConsFrom a valuation standpoint
column52: INTC actually looks like the best buy
column53: simply because the market expects less from it than from AMD and NVDA. Also
column54: Intel leads in the production of microprocessors
column55: and this matters in the semiconductor industry
column56: since often only the market leaders can turn a profit
column57: while laggards destroy value.AMD made some mistakes in the past
column58: switching back and forth between ARM and x86 architectures
column59: and never was quite able to catch up to Intel. The stock looks promising
column60: but dislodging Intel and showing a steady track record of profits will not be easy in this industry.As of this writing
column61: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Stock Is Going to BounceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Moved Too Far

column1: More iPhones
column4: 05:26:00 PM EDT;"After three quarters of declining revenue and iPhone sales
column5: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) managed to return to growth during its first   fiscal quarter. Not only that
column6: Apple put up some record numbers.   Revenue was $78.35 billion
column7: up 3.3 % year over year and a new   quarterly record. EPS grew 2.4% to $3.36
column8: also a new quarterly   record.iPhone unit sales surged 5% to 78.3 million
column9: the most ever in   a single quarter. The company also set all-time revenue records   for services
column10: Mac
column11: and Apple Watch. There was a lot to like.Apple stocksurged the following day
column12: with investors relieved that fears of a   continued slide in sales were overblown.While Apple put together a fine quarter
column13: the company's results   aren't quite as good as they seem.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.A profit declineApple managed to grow its per-share earnings during the first   quarter
column14: but a quick look at the income statement reveals a   different story. Apple increased its revenue by $2.48 billion   compared to the first quarter of last year
column15: but cost of sales
column16: the cost of producing its products
column17: surged $2.73 billion. Gross   profit declined by a little less than 1% as a result.So Apple sold more devices
column18: but it accepted a lower gross   margin
column19: and none of that extra revenue flowed through to the   bottom line. This gross profit decline and a 9% increase in   operating expenses led operating income to drop 3.4%. Net income   slumped by a smaller 1.6% thanks to an increase in other income
column20: which includes income for interest and dividends
column21: among other   items.Apple was able to grow its EPS because of its expansive share   buyback program. The company's diluted share count declined by   4.8% year over year
column22: fueled by billions of dollars of share   buybacks. Apple spent $10.9 billion on share buybacks during the   first quarter alone
column23: an 57% increase compared to the prior-year   period.To be fair
column24: Apple still generated $17.9 billion of net income   during the quarter
column25: a staggering sum. But the fact that profit   and revenue are moving in opposite directions should be a concern   for investors. There's nothing wrong with share buybacks
column26: especially when cash continues to pile up. But they're the only   reason Apple was able to set an EPS record.An extra weekDid you know that Apple's first quarter this year had 14   weeks
column27: compared to 13 weeks in the first quarter last year? If   you only read Apple's press release
column28: this fact may come as a   surprise. Amongst all the talk of records
column29: there's no mention of   the extra week. You would have had to delve into the 10-Q or   listen to the conference call in order to find recognition of   this substantial tailwind.If you just take the numbers and adjust them for this extra   week
column30: the quarter doesn't look so good. Revenue would have   slumped 4.1%
column31: iPhone unit sales would have declined 2.8%
column32: and   operating income would have tumbled 10.3%. This is a simplistic   way to adjust for the extra week
column33: as sales weren't spread out   uniformly throughout the quarter. But it gives a sense of how   significant an extra week can be.During the conference call
column34: CFO Luca Maestri pointed to four   factors that offset this extra week. Slower growth of China   inventory
column35: an earlier launch of the iPhone 7 compared to the   iPhone 6s in the previous year
column36: a stronger U.S. dollar
column37: and a   patent infringement payment in the first quarter of last year all   hurt the company's results relative to the prior-year period.Maestri doesn't say by what degree these factors offset the   extra week
column38: and in the absence of an extra week
column39: they would have   read like a list of excuses. Adjusted for that extra week
column40: Apple's first quarter wasn't as solid as the headline numbers   suggest. It almost certainly wasn't as bad as my simplistic   calculation above
column41: but it puts an asterisk next to Apple's   numbers.The good news for Apple investors is that the company's   guidance for the second quarter was positive. Apple expects to   produce between $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion of revenue
column42: up   from $50.6 billion during the second quarter of last year. Gross   margin is expected to decline
column43: which will again pressure Apple's   bottom line. But the major sales declines of the past few   quarters appear to be in the rearview mirror -- at least for   now.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Buy Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock on This Q4 Earnings Dip;February 02
column4: 04:40:35 PM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA few years ago
column6: analysts had to add numbers from dozens of retail companies to see how Christmas went. Now they just wait on the earnings fromAmazon.com
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column8: which came out after the market closed on Feb. 2. Unfortunately
column9: Christmas wasn't as rosy as hoped
column10: and AMZN stock is down about 4% in Thursday's after-market trade as a result.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAmazon's final numbers were somewhat mixed. AMZN beat estimates on the earnings front
column11: bringing in $1.54 per share - better than the consensus mark of $1.40
column12: and the company's seventh straight quarter of profit.But Amazon was light on revenues
column13: at $43.74 billion versus expectations of $44.84 billion. That still was a big jump from the $35.75 billion in revs last year
column14: but not enough to please investors or experts. That caused AMZN stock to drop 4% within minutes.Bad news for most
column15: though some - includingBlue Chip Growtheditor Louis Navellier - were hoping to buy Amazon stock on the dip.CEO Jeff Bezos emphasized the variety of Amazon Prime servicesin his release
column16: mentioning new offerings in gaming
column17: storage
column18: music and its Prime Now same-day shopping services. The company's studio launched hit shows likeThe Grand TourandMan in the High Castle
column19: while the movieManchester by the Seadrew Oscar nominations but will debut on Prime within a few months.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryOur James Brumley was expecting fireworks after earnings
column20: but most options traders were not making big bets either way. Most recently
column21: I took some money off the table on Amazon
column22: which as I noted was becoming a huge piece of my retirement savings.The biggest news from the analyst community was a super-bull call from Bill Miller
column23: chairman of LMM Investments
column24: claiming the value of AMZN stockcould double again in three years- making it more valuable thanApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). He also stating that Amazon now has higher gross margins thanWal-Mart Stores Inc.(NYSE:WMT)
column25: which regularly sells nearly $120 billion of merchandise each quarter - not just at Christmas.The big turn in Amazon stock started when the company started breaking out numbers from Amazon Web Services
column26: its cloud services unit
column27: after the first quarter of 2015. Since then
column28: the company has more than doubled
column29: as the unit has been growing at 50% per year and proving it can book one-fourth of that revenue as operating profit
column30: even when accounting for stock options given its top employees.In the third quarter
column31: for instance
column32: AWS earned $861 million on revenues of $3.231 billion. Yes
column33: that's more thanthe whole company earned. Amazon still loses money regularly on its international expansion
column34: where it now brings in nearly one-third of its revenue. For the fourth quarter
column35: AWS brought in revenue of $3.54 billion
column36: which was seen as disappointing.Why Buy AMZN Stock Now?It's the expectation of huge growth on a massive scale that have made Amazon the fourth-largest company by market capitalization in the U.S. It recently passedBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.B)
column37: whose revenues regularly run 50% better than Amazon's Christmas expectations.Shares dropped 5.1% the day after the third quarter missed expectations oOct. 27
column38: and you could have gotten Amazon for $719 per share two weeks later
column39: on Nov. 14. But since then the stock has been on fire
column40: and closed before earnings near $840 per share.Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Has a Secret WeaponBuyers keep coming for Amazon because every quarter
column41: it seems to do something spectacular.This quarter
column42: for instance
column43: it delivered a new credit card offering 5% all Amazon purchases to Prime members. It announced a new air hub near Cincinnati
column44: sinking sharesofUnited Parcel Service
column45: Inc.(NYSE:UPS) andFedEx Corporation(NYSE:FDX). Its Alexa personal assistant dominated the Consumer Electronics Show
column46: as our Brad Moon reported.All this has made AMZN stock a must-have for a growing number of small investors
column47: who race in whenever the stock stumbles.Just like it did this afternoon.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column48: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column49: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets Profits7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postBuy Amazon.com
column50: Inc. (AMZN) Stock on This Q4 Earnings Dipappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What's Next for iPhones After Strong Holiday Quarter?;February 02
column3: 03:06:00 PM EDT;"AppleAAPLshares jumped over 6% yesterday after the company returned to growth in the first quarter of fiscal 2017. A lot of the optimism was on account of iPhone sales
column4: which grew 4.7% from last year to the highest ever tally of 78.3 million units or around two-thirds of total sales. Street estimates varied between 77-78 million units.Apple Inc. Price and EPS SurpriseApple Inc. Price and EPS Surprise|Apple Inc. Quote""iPhone's Best Performance for Over a Year""Neil Mawston
column5: Executive Director at Strategy Analytics
column6: said in a statement that this was the iPhone's best performance in over a year
column7: putting it back on top as the world's largest smartphone vendor. But he also said that the numbers were helped by the Samsung Note 7 fiasco. As a result
column8: Samsung didn't see as much of the fourth-quarter bump-up as it usually does (it still managed a 29% share in the U.S. compared to Apple's 31%
column9: according to Kantar Worldpanel).Apple's growth rate was also slightly lower than in the year-ago quarter
column10: and was likely impacted by the stronger dollar and by stiff competition from local players in China like Huawei
column11: ZTE
column12: Lenovo
column13: OPPO and Vivo that may have led to a loss in market share. Revenues from China were down 12% in the last quarter. Tim Cook used an optimistic tone: ""I'm encouraged with the significant improvement but we're not without challenges there.""He also said that sales would have been stronger if demand for the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus hadn't been underestimated. As it turned out
column14: the more expensive device was more popular based on new features like better cameras and more RAM
column15: which therefore led to a supply shortage. If it wasn't such a competitive market
column16: this may not have been such a bad problem to have.However
column17: it does reverse an earlier trend that saw the iPhone 6S Plus and iPhone 6 Plus growing slower than their less expensive partners. It also seems to indicate that customers are unwilling to upgrade without meaningful new features
column18: but will pay more for them when they're there.As a result
column19: the two new models that also came with water resistance while ditching the headphone socket accounted for 17% of iPhone sales
column20: according to research firm Localytics
column21: as reported in the media. This also raised the average selling price to $695 from $691 in the year-ago quarter.The Good and Bad Going ForwardSmartphone sales growth rates are not going to come back to where they've been the last few years. For example
column22: consider that the iPhone 6 launch in Sep 2014 was followed by a 46% increase in shipments the following quarter. This kind of growth is history
column23: because penetration continues to increase across the world.Second
column24: Apple's growth rates have also been fueled by market share gains in China
column25: which may not be repeated for a number of reasons including greater penetration
column26: the stronger dollar
column27: a more difficult operating environment
column28: the increasingly strained relations between China and the U.S. and the abundant supply of local makes of varying price tags.Third
column29: Apple is likely to maintain or even grow share in developed markets and markets with higher penetration on the strength of its brand. But these upgrades will be dependent on innovation. Tim Cook says: ""The smartphone is still in the early innings of the game
column30: and ""I think there's lots more to do... We've got some exciting things in the pipeline. I still feel really
column31: really good about it."" But if the upgrades over the past two years are anything to go by
column32: it seems that there's a limit to that innovation.That of course brings us to the question of the upcoming iPhone 8 that is expected to have an all-new design
column33: glass casing and other exciting features. Plus
column34: it's the iPhone's 10thanniversary
column35: so there's some pent-up excitement there. If Apple delivers in line with the hype
column36: it should have blockbuster sales. Beginning in the September quarter when it will launch that is and provided Apple doesn't under-supply the things. Until then
column37: we should expect customers to hold off purchases (more so than in earlier years because the excitement for the new phone is more this time).The other somewhat positive factor is India where Apple's talks with government officials appear to be going well. India is a faster-growing market than China at the moment because of relatively lower penetration
column38: a rising middle class and the Prime Minister's stated goal of digitizing the nation. Once Apple starts building its stores in the region
column39: its brand value is bound to appreciate and translate into increased sales for the company. But it's not a done deal yet
column40: especially considering the concessions Apple is asking for
column41: so some uncertainty persists.Apple shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Technology stocks with better potential are Anixter InternationalAXE
column42: Aspen TechnologyAZPN
column43: KLA-TencorKLACor Inphi Corp.IPHI
column44: all of which have a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks here.Zacks' Best Private Investment IdeasIn addition to the recommendations that are available to the public on our website

You can even look inside exclusive portfolios that are normally closed to new investors. Starting today

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: New AAPL Patent Includes Watch Band Battery;February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is a new patent for a Watch band. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleWatch Band:AAPL has been granted a patent for a possible future Watch band
column6: reports9to5Mac. The patent shows off a Watch band that may be able to keep the company's smartwatch running for multiple days. This band includes a battery that would be able power the smartwatch. The patent also mentions that the band could be charged by the same dock used to charge the Watch. Another small detail to note in the patent is the watch itself. This watch is circular in design
column7: which is different from the current square style AAPL sells.iPad Future:Tim Cook is still excited for the iPad despite declining sales
column8: MacRumorsnotes. Cook recently said that there are ""exciting things"" coming to the iPad. He also said that he is ""optimistic"" about where things are heading for the device. All of this comes on the heels of declining sales in the holiday season. AAPL sold 13.1 million in its most recent quarter
column9: which is down from the 16.1 million sold during the same time in 2015.MacBook Processor:A new rumor claims that Apple is working on its own processor for MacBooks
column10: reportsBloomberg. According to this rumor
column11: the tech company is working withARM Holdingsto design the component. The rumor claims that this processor won't replace the ones provided byIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). Instead
column12: is says that the processor will work alongside the Intel one and will mostly handle low power tasks. This rumor comes from unnamed sources that are close to the matter.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: New AAPL Patent Includes Watch Band Batteryappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock Dip Beckons to Profit-Seekers;February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTraders seeking strength are flocking to theNasdaqin droves. The tech-laden index continues to be the best looking of the bunch
column5: and its dominance has only increased during earnings season. Solid performance fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) following their respective earnings releases has helped keep the good times rolling. But do you know which heavy hitter may be sporting the best opportunity right now?International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM).makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler Via FlickrLet's take a deep dive into the chart of IBM stock to see what kind of trade we can drum up.Like the lion's share of the equities market
column6: IBM jumped into an uptrend following last year's election and it hasn't looked back since. The tech titan entered the new year with a solid high base pattern that created a breakout opportunity for technical traders.And they didn't have to wait long. Big Blue's earnings beat from Jan. 19 served as the excuse for buyers to come rushing in.The action in IBM stock since then has been textbook. After breaching the $170 resistance level
column7: the stock gained a quick ten bucks before the bulls' fury finally faded.5 Safe Dividend Stocks to Buy for RetirementSince then
column8: mild profit-taking has created an attractive four-day pullback. Traders loath to chase now have their opportunity to scoop up shares at a discount.Source: OptionsAnalytixRecent volume patterns have also been favoring buyers. The post-earnings breakout was accompanied by a handful of accumulation days suggesting institutions were entering the fray with aggression. And while the stock has retreated in recent days
column9: the volume has been muted suggesting a lack of any real conviction by sellers here.Throw it all together
column10: and this IBM stock dip looks like a buy.IBM Stock Calendars
column11: Anyone?With earnings fading in the distance
column12: IBM options have become cheap again. And that means long option trades carry much less risk. Let's build a calendar spread to capitalize on further upside in the stock over the coming month.First
column13: buy to open the Apr $170 call for around $7.60. Then
column14: sell to open the Mar $180 call for around $1.25. This creates a diagonal call spread for a net debit of $6.35. The max loss is limited to the initial debit and will be forfeited if IBM sits below $170 at Apr expiration.Why Sony Corp (ADR) (SNE) Stock Should Ditch the Entertainment BizTo minimize the loss
column15: I suggest exiting if the stock breaks the $165 support level.The max profit is around $400 and will be captured if IBM sits right at $180 at March expiration. Since the April option will only have one month remaining at March expiration
column16: I suggesting exiting at that point.At the time of this writing
column17: Tyler Craig had no positions in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsThe postThe International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock Dip Beckons to Profit-Seekersappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Sony Corp (ADR) (SNE) Stock Should Ditch the Entertainment Biz;February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE) saw some great movement back in 2013 when activist investor Dan Loeb delivered ahand-written letterto CEO Kazuo Hirai. In that letter
column5: Loeb
column6: petitioned for Sony to spin off its entertainment division
column7: which includes movies
column8: television and music. Loeb believed the move would increase the value of Sony stock and reward shareholders  and another weak quarter for the division makes that memory all the more painful.makeArticleAd();Source:WikipediaLoeb has since sold his stake
column9: after being the largest shareholder with 6% of shares
column10: but new rumors see Sony selling off part of the unit. SNE stock is ready to roll in 2017 if this move finally comes into play.TheNew York Postreports that Sony is listening to pitches from interested parties in the Sony Entertainment division. Rumors seeCBS Corporation(NYSE:CBS)
