column1: Google Earnings: The Market Has Made The Same Mistake Twice;February 02
column3: 10:07:59 AM EDT;"Google Earnings (Shutterstock photo)As a general rule
column4: the market is pretty good about learning from its mistakes. After all
column5: there is nothing like a hefty loss to teach traders what not to do.That is a simple fact that must be borne in mind when looking for patterns in pricing; if the pattern involves a reaction to news that was ultimately proven wrong
column6: it is unlikely to repeat very often
column7: and the few opportunities when it does should be grabbed with both hands.makeArticleAd();That is what makes Google parent company Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL) look like such a good buy after its reaction to Q4 earnings.As you can see from the chart below
column8: prior to last weeks earnings report Google (Im sorry but I just cant bring myself to call the company Alphabet) had dropped sharply on earnings misses contained in two of the previous three releases
column9: in April and October.On both of those occasions
column10: though
column11: the big drop in price was
column12: with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight
column13: an opportunity to buy the stock at a discount. There are different circumstances this time around
column14: of course
column15: but the dynamic that has made negative reactions to earnings in the past opportunities is still in place
column16: so the end result is likely to be the same.The biggest problems with the Q4 results as far as traders were concerned
column17: it seems
column18: were that cost per click was down
column19: and operating costs had risen to the point where earnings per Class A share (EPS) of $9.36 fell short of the Streets estimates of around $9.64. Still
column20: revenues of $26.06 billion beat the estimated $25.26 billion.There was also a concern lurking in the background regarding Google taking on both Amazon (AMZN)s Echo and Apple (AAPL)s iPhone with recent hardware launches. Google said that they were pleased with the reaction to both Google Home and the Pixel phone without going into specifics
column21: but doubts about the wisdom of the strategy persist.I actually believe that Google has a chance of limited success in each case. The Pixel will be the most uphill struggle as the iPhones dominance of the mobile phone market is well established. Most estimates of sales of the phone so far are around 1 million
column22: which hardly puts a dent in the iPhone
column23: but may prove to be enough of a base to make the Pixel profitable as a niche product.Home has an easier
column24: more logical path to success as Google is the natural choice of those looking for what is
column25: essentially
column26: a free-standing search engine.Ultimately
column27: though
column28: neither Home nor Pixel is going to be the driver of the recovery in the stock price that history suggests will come soon.First
column29: the increase in operating costs that Google reported seems
column30: on a breakdown of the numbers
column31: to be the result of investment in the core business. Losses in what the company calls Other Bets
column32: things like Nest and self driving cars
column33: were actually reduced somewhat in the fourth quarter
column34: but there was significant progress on the autonomous vehicle front.The possibilities of that field are endless and Google
column35: along with Tesla (TSLA) and Apple
column36: are generally seen as the leaders in driverless car research and technology.The other issue
column37: of falling cost per click (CPC)
column38: is also not what it seems on the surface. It reflects a continuing move to mobile that results in that metric falling
column39: but the volume of clicks increasing. The same issue was
column40: in part
column41: responsible for the April and October drops in GOOG after earnings
column42: and the chart tells the story of how long it was until investors realized that volume more than offset falling CPC.Looking at Googles results and the market reaction to them
column43: I get a sense of dj vu. We have actually been here before
column44: twice
column45: and each time the drop in GOOG gave investors a chance to buy cheaply. It seems that in this case the market is still learning from its mistake and over time the outcome here is most likely to be the same."

column1: Zacks Value Investor Highlights: Under Armour
column4: Apple and Williams-Sonoma;February 02
column6: 09:30:00 AM EDT;"makeZacksArticleAd();For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column7: IL - February 02
column8: 2017 - Zacks Value Investor is a podcast hosted weekly by Zacks Stock Strategist Tracey Ryniec. Every week
column9: Tracey will be joined by guests to discuss the hottest investing topics in stocks
column10: bonds and ETFs and how it impacts your life. To listen to the podcast
column11: click here: (https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/247797/are-your-favorite-stocks-cheap)Are Your Favorite Stocks Cheap?Welcome to Episode #28 of the Value Investor PodcastEvery week
column12: Zacks value stock strategist and the Editor ofZacks Value Investor portfolio
column13: Tracey Ryniec
column14: talks about all things happening in the value stock universe
column15: including her top stock picks.It's earnings season so that means some stocks will get a boost off their reports
column16: and others will get sold off. These days
column17: an earnings miss or a warning on guidance can be enough to send a stock down by the double digits.If you're a value investor
column18: your first thought upon seeing a big sell off in a stock is probably ""is that stock cheap enough for me to buy now?""There have been some juicy sell offs already this earnings season. Additionally
column19: some other ""favorite"" stocks that many people own seem out of favor or down on their luck.Are These Favorite Stocks Cheap Enough to Be Values?1. Under Armour (NYSE:UAA-Free Report) sold off 25% on its first earnings miss in 5 years. Shares are now down over 50% from their highs. But is it a value?2. Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX-Free Report) went nowhere after its earnings reports. Shares also fell 9% in the last year
column20: underperforming the market. The company appears to be out-of-favor with investors. (In full disclosure
column21: Tracey is a long-term owner of it in her personal portfolio.) Should value investors be taking a look?3. Shake Shack Inc. (NYSE:SHAK-Free Report) was once the darling of Wall Street but shares have fallen 19% over the last 2 years. Is the growth catching up with the valuation now?4. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) just reported earnings. Revenues surprised the Street. Is it one of the few technology stocks that might be a value stock?5. Williams-Sonoma Inc. (NYSE:WSM-Free Report) owns one of the top brands in home furnishings: West Elm. But it's other brands are struggling. It doesn't report earnings until March but should value investors be keeping an eye on this retailer?Investors should always dig deeper than simply the value fundamentals before making a decision to buy a stock. Does the company have rising earnings estimates? What does the growth picture look like?Just because a company has always been an expensive growth stock doesn't mean it always will be in the future.Find out more about what Tracey thinks about the buying opportunities in these popular stocks in this week's podcast.Have a question for Tracey?Do you have a value investing question for Tracey?Is there a topic you really want covered on an upcoming Value Investor Podcast?She wants to hear from you.Send your questions for Tracey to her e-mail address at:podcast@zacks.com.Want more insights from Tracey?Check out her weekly Value Investor service to receive more in-depth analysis on value companies and see which stocks she thinks are the best bargains now.Click here to learn more.Tracey Ryniec is the Value Stock Strategist for Zacks.com. She is also the Editor of theInsider TraderandValue Investorservices. You can follow her on twitter at@TraceyRyniecand she also hosts theZacks Market Edge Podcaston iTunes.About ZacksZacks.com is a property of Zacks Investment Research

column6: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe bloom is off the rose for the ""Trump rally
column7: and Wall Street is finally taking the new administration at its word as U.S. stock futures are headed broadly lower this morning. A string of geopolitical issues from President Donald Trump has traders worried
column8: including potentialnew sanctions on Iran
column9: the threat ofsending troops to Mexicoand a heated exchange with the Australian prime minister.makeArticleAd();As a result

column14: however

column19: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) extended its blistering 12-month rally to more than 430% on the heels of another blowout quarter.Apple Inc. (AAPL)After posting three straight quarters of declining revenue and faltering earnings
column20: Apple finally hit it big. For the holiday quarter

column22: easily besting expectations for $3.22 per share on revenue of $77.42 billion.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryAccording to CEO Tim Cook

column24: Services

column1: Are Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?;February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRecent statistics from the two wearable rivals suggest thatGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN) is winning the war againstFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT)
column5: making a hypothetical long/short play between the two stocks a very interesting proposition.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitHowever
column6: thinking about buying Garmin and shorting Fitbit stock - and actually following through with it - are two entirely different beasts.I have never shorted a stock and likely never will; I'm just not built that way. Whenever I'm asked byInvestorPlace
column7: or any of the other financial publications I write for
column8: to do a ""sell"" piece on a stock or a group of stocks
column9: I always have a tougher time coming up with recommendations.I like to write about stocks that I would consider owning; negative spin doesn't enter my psyche. I can do it
column10: it's just harder.This brings me to GRMN stock and FIT stock
column11: the crux of this story.Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Can't Fall Much Lower Than ThisIn Q3 2016
column12: Garmin shipped 1.3 million wearable devices
column13: a 12.2% year-over-year increase. That compares to an 11.0% YOY increase for Fitbit. In Q2 2016
column14: Garmin shipped 1.6 million wearable devices
column15: a 106.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier
column16: while Fitbit shipped 5.7 million wearable devices
column17: a 28.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier.So
column18: in the nine months ended September 2016
column19: Garmin shipped 3.8 million wearable devices
column20: a 40.7% increase year over year. Meanwhile
column21: Fitbit shipped 15.8 million wearable devices
column22: a 21.5% increase year over year.Between Q1 2015 and Q3 2016
column23: Garmin's market share dropped by 40 basis points to 5.7%. During the same 18-month period
column24: Fitbit's market share dropped 980 basis points to 23.0%.Fitbit Stock Continues to DeclineSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) and the many others that compete for the 50% market share not held by Fitbit
column25: Xiaomi
column26: Garmin
column27: andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) stand to benefit the most.Garmin is a big company and wearables are but one of many revenue streams. A 40-basis-point decline isn't a big deal for a company that generated $2.2 billion in revenue in the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column28: an increase of 5.8%. If not for its auto segment (its largest by revenue)
column29: which saw a 17% decline year over year to $656.0 million
column30: 2016 has been a winner.Over at Fitbit
column31: the top line has been outstanding
column32: with revenue growing 39.3% through the first nine months of the year to $1.6 billion. However
column33: it's the bottom line that gets a little wonky.In the quarter ended Oct. 1
column35: Fitbit's operating profit declined 33.1% to $44.4 million; for the nine months ended October 1
column37: operating income declined 69.3% to $72.9 million. R&D
column38: sales and marketing
column39: and G&A expenses all have seen huge increases in 2016 as Fitbit struggles to remain on top of a wearables market that's slowing faster than anyone expected.InvestorPlacecontributor Aaron Levitt recently discussed Fitbit stock in relation to aslowing wearables market; he was pretty blunt in his assessment of the job CEO James Park is doing guiding the company through a rough patch that's seen FIT stock decline by 65% over the past year.""Both eMarketer and IDC both cite smartwatches as the big reason for the declines
column40: wrote Levitt. ""Consumers just can't see the need for them as they overlap on features already found in smartphones. And when adding their heftier price tags
column41: smartwatches are a fading fad.""So
column42: what does Fitbit do to counter the fact that wearables' 2016 growth will be less than half the 60% projection at the start of the year? It buys not one
column43: but two companies that make smartwatches.Bottom Line on Fitbit and GarminIf Fitbit continues to waste money on bad acquisitions and wasteful overhead that doesn't move the needle
column44: you can bet that Fitbit's comfy cash position - $672 million in cash and marketable securities as of Q3 - will be gone faster than you can shake a stick at.So
column45: should you go long on Garmin? Absolutely. With$1.1 billionin cash and marketable securities
column46: no debt
column47: and an operating margin of almost 21%
column48: GRMN stock is a long-term hold.3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionAs for shorting FIT stock
column49: I'm of two minds on this.Yes
column50: theshorts represent almost 36% of its floatand its margins are about one-third Garmin's
column51: but with $3 in cash it's got to be attractive to somebody in the industry - maybe even Garmin. That should keep Fitbit stock from dropping much farther.So
column52: I wouldn't recommend investors buy or short Fitbit stock. Neither proposition looks like it will be a winner any time soon.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsHere's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its ThroneWhy Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Be ScrewedThe postAre Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Will NEVER Be About P/E;February 02
column4: 09:08:52 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the biggest negatives surroundingAmazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is the company's sky-high price-to-earnings ratio. According to Google Finance
column7: AMZN stock currently trades at an eye-popping 191 times its trailing earnings of $4.36 per share.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut Amazon has at least given investors the courtesy of growing profits to try to somewhat justify the lofty valuation. That 191x is on trailing 12-month earnings of $4.36 per share. In fiscal 2015
column8: AMZN earned $596 million
column9: or $1.25 per share. In 2014
column10: it lost $241 million
column11: which translates into 52 cents per share.It's obvious Amazon stock investors care about growth
column12: not valuation. AMZN's sky-high P/E has been in place for years
column13: and will likely continue for some time.And that's actually OK. Here are two important reasons why:Amazon Revenue GrowthAmazon is still one of the best growth stories in today's market.When the company releases 2016's final numbers Thursday
column14: Feb. 2
column15: analysts expect Amazon to post revenue of $137 billion. That's an improvement of more than 25% versus 2015's top line - a difficult feat when you're talking about 12-digit sales. And Amazon's $107 billion in revenue last year was 20% better than 2014.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryWe live in a world in whichS&P 500constituents are doing well if they're posting just single-digit increases on the top line. You can blame this at least partly on the strong U.S. dollar
column16: which is weighing down American multinationals. But the fact remains that meaningful growth is a scarce quality in today's stock market - especially among blue-chip stocks.Thus
column17: AMZN stock is an easy way for investors to get access to big growth with relatively little risk.And Amazon is hardly running out of fuel. The company has only begun to expand into grocery and apparel - two huge categories. Trillions of dollars are spent worldwide each year at physical stores. That's not to mention the other gains Amazon still could make via the smart home
column18: Amazon Web Services cloud offerings and other newer initiatives.Analysts predict Amazon's revenue will increase another 22% in 2017
column19: hitting $168 billion. So again - the growth story is still well intact.But it's not all about growth. Many AMZN stock bulls argue that we're just looking at earnings the wrong way.Amazon Earnings: Better Than They Seem?One thing that separates Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos from many other executives is his ability to look at the really
column20: reallylong-term. He's also willing to spend billions of dollars on ideas
column21: and is OK with hitting a few duds if it means spawning great new ideas.Remember the company's smartphone? The Amazon Music Importer? How about a website called Askville? I'm guessing you might remember the Fire smartphone
column22: but not the other two. Amazon lost $170 million on its smartphone alone.This kind of risk taking is an inherent part of Amazon's culture. It's the line of thinking that prodded the company to introduce some of its biggest winners to date
column23: like cloud services
column24: Prime shipping and the Kindle.Thus
column25: many investors look at AMZN stock in a different way. They look at the company's operating profit
column26: then they add back its substantial research and development costs to get a ""truer"" sense of profitability.Admittedly
column27: that changes the picture dramatically.Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL)In its most recent quarter
column28: Amazon produced net income of $252 million
column29: which across 485 million diluted shares became diluted earnings of 52 cents per share. At the time
column30: AMZN was trading at $822 per share. If we annualize that profit (not a perfect measure
column31: as quarterly earnings fluctuate - this is just for an example)
column32: we're looking at a P/E of 395.But Amazon also reported operating profits of $575 million
column33: and spent $4.14 billion on R&D - a significant expense. Add those together
column34: and you get $4.715 billion
column35: or $9.72 per share. Annualize that
column36: then divide the share price by that
column37: and you get a P/E of about 21.Let's take the actual numbers. Amazon currently trades for 190 times trailing 12-month earnings
column38: as we said above. However
column39: over the past four quarters
column40: Amazon spent $15.11 billion on R&D and posted operating profits of more than $4 billion. That comes to $40.19 per share combined
column41: and puts AMZN stock at a P/E of just more than 20.That's a lot of creative accounting
column42: so take that with a spoonful of salt. But it's an interesting argument.Bottom Line on AMZN StockAmazon continues to be one of the best growth stories in today's market. As long as that continues
column43: investors aren't going to care about the headline P/E ratio. It just doesn't matter. AMZN stock has doubled several times over despite it.Amazon is solidly profitable
column44: even if the bottom line isn't as large as investors typically would like. But those earnings are being reinvested back in the business - which is what a high-growth company like Amazon should be doing anyway.As of this writing
column45: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhy Amazon.com

column1: Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL);February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rallied a strong 6% on Wednesday following the company's latest earnings report. While the rally was impressive
column5: AAPL stock is now bumping into some critical technical resistance that bulls and bears alike should be aware of.makeArticleAd();Simply put
column6: Apple's near- to possibly medium-term upside is limited at best.Apple's revenues in the latest quarter came in at a record $78.4 billion
column7: which in part was helped by strong holiday demand for the new iPhone 7 series. These numbers are impressive
column8: and I continue to be a longer-term believer in the company - particularly around the potential of AAPL being able to monetize deeper on the devices ecosystem through more services.When Ilast discussed shares of Appleon Dec. 28
column10: I offered that if AAPL stock could clear above the $118 price level
column11: then a next upside target around $123 would come into sight. Apple met and surpassed this target on Wednesday following the earnings announcement.From that perspective
column12: Apple shares have now reached an important upside price target.AAPL Stock ChartsLet's take a step back and look at the multiyear weekly chart of AAPL stock. We see that despite the big swing lower from the 2015 highs into the mid-2016 lows
column13: and most recently back up toward the 2015 highs
column14: Apple has
column15: largely speaking
column16: not really accomplished much since early 2015.Click to EnlargeBulls
column17: however
column18: note that the May 2016 lows coincided with critical technical support made up of horizontal support (lower purple-dotted line) as well as the 200-week simple moving average (red). Equally important
column19: on the other hand
column20: is that after Wednesday's post-earnings rally
column21: AAPL is now within a few points of these aforementioned previous all-time highs from 2015. Through a technical lens
column22: this could offer up as much resistance as the 2015 lows offered support.In other words
column23: before Apple stock can sustainably break to new all-time highs
column24: a consolidation phase most likely is in order.Looking at the daily chart
column25: we see that since mid-November 2016
column26: AAPL stock has now rallied approximately 25%
column27: which is not a small move for the stock to accomplish in a matter of two-and-a-half months.Click to EnlargeA simple yet accurate observation through the lens of technical analysis is that old all-time highs are not easily overcome on the first try
column28: particularly if the stock has not consolidated below or near those previous all-time highs for some time.Apple's current chart thus is in dire need of some consolidation before it can make a better attempt at fresh all-time highs on a more sustainable basis.How to Trade Apple Stock HereI see two specific trades setting up:If AAPL stock breaks and holds below Wednesday's intraday lows around $127
column29: then the stock could be played from the short side for a mean-reversion move back into the mid- to low $120s. Alternatively
column30: options traders could also look to sell out-of-the-money call spreads on the stock at that time.Quicker traders could look to buy AAPL stock for fast profits should the stock push and hold above Wednesday's intraday highs around $130.50 for a move toward the 2015 highs around $133.Either way
column31: upside in AAPL stock through a multiweek/multimonth lens is likely limited. Trades should be constructed accordingly.Like what you see? Sign up for our dailyBeat the Belle-letter and get Serge's investment advice delivered to your inbox every morning! Download Serge's Free Special Report:6 Keys for Successful Trading and Investing.The postApple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The S&P 500 Holds in the Face of Uncertainty;February 02
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Wednesday
column5: shares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) jumped 6.1% following a report that showed an increased demand for its iPhone 7. The record increase in revenues of $78.4 billion ended a record of three consecutive quarters of declines
column6: and helped theDow Jones Industrial Averagegain 0.1% by adding 51 points to the index. Apple's gain also helped propel theNasdaqto a gain for the day of 0.5%.makeArticleAd();Apple's gain helped the session to open higher
column7: but the positive impact of one stock's opening didn't' last long. All of the gains of the opening were lost by noon. However
column8: following the noon hour's lows
column9: a Federal Reserve decision to leave interest rates unchanged
column10: and several positive economic reports helped gain back about half of the morning's losses enabling the major indices to close with modest gains.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryAt the close
column11: the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 27 points at 19
column13: theS&P 500eked out a point at 2
column15: the Nasdaq rose 28 points to close at 5
column16: 643 and theRussell 2000closed at 1
column18: unchanged. The NYSE's primary exchange traded 1 billion shares with total volume of 3.9 billion shares. The Nasdaq crossed 2.2 billion shares. On the Big Board
column19: decliners edged out advancers by 1.1-to-1
column20: while the Nasdaq broke even. The NYSE's blocks were reported as 6
column21: 510 down from 6
column22: 786 on Tuesday.Click to EnlargeIn spite of the many underlying uncertainties
column23: the S&P 500 (and the Nasdaq) have maintained support. The S&P 500's December high at 2
column24: 277 is the ""line in the sand"" for this major index
column25: as is Nasdaq's January high at 5
column26: 574.Conclusion:The January closing highs of the major indices are breakout points that must hold if the short-term and intermediate-term trend is to remain intact.A gap exists on the 500 from 2
column28: 286. That gap was partially closed by yesterday's intraday high at 2
column29: 289. This technical issue is an important focus for this major index
column30: since a failure to proceed higher could easily lead to a 5% to 10% correction. So far the major indices have resisted the anxiety produced by many uncertainties
column31: choosing to hold or buy rather than give in to the sellers.The line at 2
column32: 277 was pierced but recovered. The question now is
column33: ""Can it hold?""Today's Trading LandscapeTo see a list of the companies reporting earnings today

column1: 5 Top Dividend Aristocrats to Buy in February;February 02
column3: 08:09:00 AM EDT;"makeZacksArticleAd();The Federal Reserve maintained interest rates in February
column4: providing no update on the next hike. The Fed's reluctance in raising rates should stand in good stead for dividend aristocrats.President Donald Trump's travel ban
column5: in the meanwhile
column6: could result in a possible rise in erratic share price movement this month. The stock market has also
column7: traditionally
column8: seen weak results this month
column9: especially after an election. In such a scenario
column10: investing in dividend aristocrats  seems prudent as they provide higher total returns with lower volatility
column11: which are undoubtedly the 'holy grail' of investing.Fed Leaves Rates UnchangedAs widely expected
column12: the Fed has kept rates unchanged following a two-day policy meeting on Feb 1. The central bank kept its benchmark overnight lending rate target at a range of 0.5% to 0.75%. The bank had lifted rates by a quarter percentage point in December
column13: marking the second hike in more than 10 years.In fact
column14: the central bank penciled three quarter-point moves this year in December. More importantly for investors
column15: the central bank didn't drop any hints of raising rates in the March meet
column16: placing the probability of such a move at only 18%
column17: according to CME Group.In this case
column18: high qualitydividend stockshave become more appealing as their stock prices don't suffer when rates aren't rising. Conversely
column19: bond markets
column20: which tend to benefit from a rise in interest rates
column21: have lost its lure.Trump Stirs Up a TempestThe Fed's positive view of the economy and Apple Inc.'sAAPLstellar earnings helped stocks rally a little higher on Feb 1. However
column22: investors have not yet recovered from the blow of Trump's immigration ban. An executive order by Trump banned immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries
column23: including legal residents and visa holders. Trump had earlier fostered expectations that his administration will be business friendly and therefore should bode well for the equity market. This decision has drawn congressional criticism and widespread protests. These protectionist measures may also cloud the path for pro-business initiatives as several world and corporate leaders condemn the ban.Airlines bore the brunt as well as several airports across the country saw violent protests
column24: disrupting operations to a great extent. Tech firms also faced obstacles in sourcing labor from foreign lands. Trump's first press conference since July also disappointed investors due to lack of policy detail. He severely criticized pharmaceutical companies over high drug prices
column25: dealing a blow to leading biotech stocks.Such uncertainties make dividend paying stocks more attractive as they tend to outperform when the broader markets are subject to gyrations. Notably
column26: the month of February has traditionally seen weak numbers just after the election.February: Traditionally a Weak MonthFebruary has been the weakest month for stocks over the past four decades
column27: averaging just a 0.06% gain. In fact
column28: in post-election years
column29: February tends to be weaker. The average return has decreased 1.85% since 1977.Lest we forget
column30: markets have gone 74 days without a 1% daily decline
column31: hence
column32: the seasonality pattern increases the odds of a wider decline in February.Why Dividend Aristocrats? 5 Solid ChoicesDividend aristocrats outperform other dividend payers on better quality business. This category of stocks reflect a solid financial structure and healthy underlying fundamentals. Such stocks are immune to market vagaries and have also raked in excellent risk-adjusted returns over the last decade. In fact
column33: in the last one year
column34: the S&P High Yield Dividend Aristocrats Index rallied 19.6%
column35: above the S&P 500's 17.5%.Dividend Aristocrats generated an annualized return of 9.7% over the past 10 years
column36: easily topping the broader market's 6.3% rate. During this period
column37: dividends accounted for 31% of the market's total return
column38: highlighting their importance in determining total shareholder return.We have
column39: thus

column1: Nokia Corporation (NOK) Q4 Earnings Beat
column4: 07:41:00 AM EDT;"makeZacksArticleAd();Finland-basedNokia Corporation'sNOKfourth-quarter 2016 earnings per share of 0.12 (approximately 13 cents) beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 8 cents. In the year-ago period
column5: Nokia had reported earnings of 0.15 (17 cents) per share.Net sales declined year over year (on a comparable combined company basis) to 6.7 billion (approximately $7.1 billion). Moreover
column6: the top line missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $7.38 billion. The disappointing performance by the Nokia Networks division was due to the challenging market conditions. Moreover
column7: weak sales in Mobile Networks
column8: which is part of Ultra Broadband Networks
column9: contributed to the significant decline.Quarterly adjusted gross margin was 42% in the reported quarter compared with 42.4% a year ago. Operating margin decreased 260 basis points (bps) to 14% on a year-over-year basis. In the fourth quarter
column10: Nokia generated net cash from operating activities of 510 million as against 460 million at the end of 2015.Nokia is rapidly expanding in the field of technology and wireless infrastructure. The company has entered into collaborations and agreements with leading names globally despite competition from peers like Motorola Solutions Inc.MSIand Clearfield Inc.CLFD. In fact
column11: the fourth quarter was a busy one for Nokia
column12: as it sued Apple Inc.AAPLfor patent infringement.Segmental RevenuesIn theNokia Networkssegment
column13: total revenue was approximately 6
column14: 069 million (around $6
column15: 372 million)
column16: down 14% year over year (on a comparable combined company basis). The segment includes Ultra Broadband Networks
column17: and IP Networks and Applications. The decline in the Ultra Broadband Networks sub-group by 15% to 4
column18: 332 million hurt the segmental sales. The segment's sales also suffered due to a reduction of 12% to 1
column19: 976 million in net sales of the IP Networks and Application segment.Notably
column20: net sales declined in all regions
column21: apart from Middle East & Africa

column1: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Better Dividends Than Apple;February 02
column4: once the domain of high-flying growth investors
column5: are becoming an increasingly generous source of dividends for income investors. The information technology sector led the market by total dividends paid both for the third quarter of 2016 and for the 12 months that ended September 30
column6: according to a FactSet analysis of the 419 dividend payers in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple (symbolAAPL) was tops in the IT sector
column7: paying $12.2 billion in dividends over the 12-month stretch.But just because Apple handed out the most money to its shareholders doesn't mean it's the best source of income in the sector. In fact
column8: Apple's stock currently yields just 1.8%
column9: even less than the S&P 500's 2.1%. So we set out to find mature tech stocks with solid business outlooks that offer superior yields to Apple. Our search turned up three blue-chip names. How blue? Like Apple
column10: all three of our picks are components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Take a look.makeArticleAd();Cisco SystemsCisco Systems
column11: which makes the routers
column12: switches and modems that form the backbone of the internet
column13: is poised for better-than-expected sales growth
column14: analysts say. A recent survey of its customers by UBS Securities revealed that spending on Cisco products remains a top budgetary priority. The tech company gets good marks for being easy to work with
column15: and two-thirds of respondents said it has the best overall security offering. The growth of cloud-based computing (storing data and applications on remote servers) and the Internet of Things (the expanding digital interconnectivity of everyday items
column16: from cars to refrigerators) are long-term tailwinds for the company and the stock. UBS has a ""buy"" rating on Cisco shares.Analysts
column17: on average
column18: expect Cisco's earnings to rise by just a penny this fiscal year ending July 30
column20: according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Sales are forecast to slip 1.9% in fiscal 2017. The more bullish case for Cisco stems from projections for the following fiscal year (ending in July 2018)
column21: when profits are projected to climb 5% to $2.49 a share
column22: and revenue is expected to gain 2.4%.Cisco's dividend
column23: which dates back to 2011
column24: has increased annually. The company disbursed $5 billion in common dividends for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. That was supported by $12 billion in free cash flow
column25: or cash left over after spending the money required to operate and expand the business.SEE ALSO:10 Stocks Every Retiree Should OwnIntelConsumers are increasingly forgoing desktop computers for mobile devices. As a result
column26: PC sales have become a slowly melting iceberg. Market research firm Gartner found that PC sales fell for eight consecutive quarters as of the third quarter of 2016. That has forced Intel
column27: the world's largest maker of the central processing units that serve as a PC's brain
column28: to find new ways to generate revenue growth.The expansion of cloud-based services has been a boon to Intel
column29: thanks to its market-share dominance in server chips. True
column30: Intel faces changes in customer demands and competition from rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column31: but analysts at Stifel say it's responding well. ""Intel has been acquiring technologies and recruiting outside managerial talent to prepare for the changing market
column32: Stifel analyst Kevin Cassidy
column33: who rates Intel shares a ""buy
column34: said in a recent note to clients.Analysts expect 2017 earnings to rise to $2.79 from $2.72 a share in 2016
column35: according to Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to increase 1% to $60.1 billion. Intel paid its first cash dividend in 1992
column36: and the company resumed annual dividend hikes two years ago. Intel's payout ratio
column37: or dividends as a percentage of earnings
column38: is a conservative 37% and below even the S&P 500's average ratio of 40%.SEE ALSO:3 Reasons to Own Apple Stock in RetirementMicrosoftMicrosoft is another tech company that's benefiting from the rise in cloud computing. An increasing number of customers now pay a recurring subscription fee to use its software rather than purchasing it outright. It's proving to be a hot area of growth. ""The closely watched commercial cloud business -- which includes Office 365
column39: Azure and Dynamics 365 -- continued to grow at a torrid rate
column40: reaching over $14.0 billion in annualized revenue in the second quarter [which ended December 31
column42: William Blair & Co. analyst Jason Ader said in a recent note to clients.Importantly
column43: the analyst expects Microsoft to become more profitable over time because of its ""disproportionate growth in its commercial cloud business
column44: which is being boosted by rapid customer adoption of Office 365 and Azure."" Azure is Microsoft's cloud-computing platform
column45: and Office 365 is the subscription version of its popular Office applications. Cloud-based services can have higher profit margins than traditional licensed software.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters project earnings to rise to $2.97 a share for the current fiscal year ending June 30
column46: from $2.79 in fiscal 2016. Revenue for fiscal 2017 is expected to increase 4.9% year over year
column47: to $96.5 billion. For its second quarter
column48: which ended December 31
column49: Microsoft generated $1.3 billion in free cash flow after disbursing $3 billion worth of dividends. The company has paid a dividend to its shareholders since 2003. By contrast
column50: Apple resumed paying a regular quarterly dividend only in 2012
column51: following a 17-year layoff.SEE ALSO:10 Best Dividend-Paying Stocks for 2017"

column1: Is Apple (AAPL) A Double From Here?;February 01
column3: 05:37:13 PM EDT;"I talked yesterday about the Fed.  As I said
column4: I think we'll find that the Fed will shift gears again to stay behind the curve on inflation
column5: to let the economy run a little hot.  They met today and it was a non-event. They said nothing to build momentum on their rate hike from December.The news of the day has been Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) earnings.  People over the past couple of years have been calling for the decline in Apple.  They've said it's topped.  They can't innovate in the post-Steve Jobs era.  The iPhone was magic. But reproducing magic isnt easy.  Once you put a computer in everyone's pocket
column6: there's not much more they can do to it with it. These are all of the quips about Apple's peak.  They may be right.  But Apple's peak
column7: at least as a stock
column8: is greatly exaggerated.They reported a huge positive surprise on earnings yesterday after the close.  The stock was up 6% on the day.  But even before that
column9: I suspect it has become a much loved stock in the past two months in the ""smart money"" investor community.We should see in the coming weeks
column10: as big investors disclose their positioning for the end of Q4
column11: Apple will have returned to a lot of portfolios again.  Warren Buffett
column12: an investor that has made his fortune buying when others are selling
column13: built a big stake at the lows of the year last year.  And it's a perfect Buffett stock.Its incredibly cheap compared to the market.The stock still trades at 15x earnings.  Much cheaper than the market.  Apple trades at 13x next years projected earnings.  The S&P 500 trades at 16.5x.  What about Apple's monster cash position?  Apple has even more cash now -- a record $246 billion. If we excluded the cash from the valuation
column14: Apple market cap goes down from $675 billion to $429 billion.  That would equate to Apple trading at closer to 9x earnings. Though not an apples to apples that valuation would group Apple with the likes of these S&P 500 components that trade around 9 times earnings
column15: like:  Dow Chemical
column16: Prudential Financial
column17: Bed Bath & Beyond
column18: a Norwegian chemical company (LBY)
column19: and Hewlett Packard Enterprise. It's safe to say no one is debating whether or not Hewlett Packard is at the pinnacle of its business. Yet
column20: if we strip out the cash in Apple
column21: AAPL shares are trading closer to an HPE valuation.Add to that
column22: Apple now has afresh catalystcoming in
column23: Trump policies. The new President Trump is incentivizing Apple (and others) tobring offshore cash hoards back homewith a flat 10% tax.  And Apple makes money  a lot of it.  Acut in the corporate tax ratewill be a boon for earnings.  Two years ago

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Earnings: 3 Answers From CEO Tim Cook;February 01
column4: 05:06:00 PM EDT;"Ahead ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) first-quarter earnings report on Tuesday
column5: investors were primarily looking for the company to show that it   can reverse its recent declining iPhone business. And Apple didexactly this
column6: reporting 5% year-over-year growth in both iPhone unit and   revenue growth
column7: helping the company's total revenue increase 3%   year over year. Even better
column8: the company said it expected more   growth in its second quarter.But beyond Apple's financial performance
column9: investors likely had   other questions on their minds -- questions more suitable for   management's earning call following the release. To this end
column10: I   laid outthree questions Apple management would hopefully   addressduring the call. As it turns out
column11: Apple management addressed all   three of these important topics.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Here's how Apple CEO Tim Cook and his management team answered   these three questions on Tuesday:1. How confident is management in its product pipeline?While the iPhone did return to growth in Apple's first   quarter
column12: it was still relatively slow growth. The iPhone's   headwinds have put the pressure on the company to develop new   products to help accelerate growth. While investors obviously   shouldn't have expected Apple to spill the beans on anything   specific on Tuesday
column13: Tim Cook did express confidence in the   company's pipeline of upcoming products.In Apple's first-quarter earnings press release
column14: Cook said   Apple is ""very excited"" about the products in its pipeline. And   during Apple's earnings call
column15: Cook showed even more enthusiasm
column16: saying
column17: ""we've got some exciting things in the pipeline; I feel   really
column18: really good about it.""2. What could Apple's services revenue growth look like going   forward?Services continue to grow in importance to Apple
column19: and the   company's first quarter was no exception. Services revenue   climbed 18% year over year
column20: growing to about 9% of total sales
column21: up from about 8% last year. And even this growth understates how   sharply the segment is climbing
column22: as the company's services   segment benefited from a one-off $548 million patent-infringement   payment in the year-ago quarter.App Store sales are helping fuel services growth. Image     source: Apple.Going forward
column23: Cook said (here's aReuters transcriptof the earnings call) that he expects services to become even   more integral to Apple's business:Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column24: and we     expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company     this year. Our services offerings are now driving over 150     million paid customer subscriptions. This includes our own     services
column25: and third-party content that we offer on our stores.     We feel great about this momentum
column26: and our goal is to double     the size of our services business in the next four years.These expectations for Apple's services segment translate to a   forecast of about 20% annualized growth over the next four   years.3. If there's a tax break for repatriation
column27: does Apple plan   to take advantage of it?With President Donald Trump saying he plans to offer a one-off   tax holiday for U.S. companies to repatriate their overseas funds   at a lower tax rate
column28: investors have good reason to be interested   in what Apple's CEO thinks of this. After all
column29: of Apple's $246.1   billion in cash and marketable securities
column30: an incredible $230.2   billion is outside of the United States.Fortunately
column31: Cook talked about this potential holiday
column32: signaling he expected Apple to take full advantage:I am optimistic given what I'm hearing
column33: that there would     likely be some sort of tax reform this year
column34: and it does seem     like there's people in both parties that would favor a     repatriation as a part of that. So I think that's very good for     the country and good for Apple.But Cook said investors will have to wait to see how   repatriated funds would be allocated:What we would do with it -- let's wait and see exactly what     it is -- but as I've said before
column35: we are always looking at     acquisitions. We acquired 15 to 20 companies per year for the     last four years
column36: and we look for companies of all sizes
column37: and     there's not a size that we would not do based on just the size     of it. It's more about the strategic value of it.Beyond acquisitions
column38: Apple could obviously allocate funds   toward other capital investments in its own business
column39: a dividend   increase
column40: a special dividend
column41: share repurchases
column42: or even all of   the above.While these were some of the more important topics covered   during the call
column43: management also covered more details on the   company's services business
column44: its regional results
column45: the smartphone   market
column46: and more. Investors can find a copy of the earnings call   on Apple's investor-relations website.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple's Earnings Shine As iPhone 7 Cycle Turns Out Better Than Expected;February 01
column3: 04:30:58 PM EDT;"Apple (AAPL) posted a record set of first quarter earnings on Tuesday
column4: beating market expectations on both revenues and earnings
column5: amid a strong uptake for its iPhone 7 smartphones
column6: higher Mac sales and a fast growing services business. Below
column7: we provide some of the key takeaways from Apple's earnings release.We have a$127 price estimate for Apple
column8: which is slightly ahead of the current market price.See Our Complete Analysis For Apple HeremakeArticleAd();iPhone Has A Solid Quarter Amid Shipment And   ASP GrowthShipments of the iPhone touched record highs
column9: growing by 5% year-over-year to about 78.3 million units
column10: driven by strong demand for the iPhone 7 and carrier promotions in the United States. Sales growth could have been higher (~8%) on a sell-through basis
column11: as Apple reduced channel inventory over the quarter. iPhone ASPs came in at a record high of $695 per unit
column12: as the demand mix for the larger 7 Plus was higher compared to previous iterations. Moreover
column13: the increasing shift towards mechanisms such as equipment installment plans and leases
column14: where buyers do not pay anything upfront for their devices
column15: are also helping to skew the demand mix towards higher-tier models. Apple's total revenue guidance for Q2 FY'17 stands at $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion (4% year-over-year at the mid-point). This is relatively strong
column16: considering that the iPhone 7 is largely viewed as a bridge device
column17: with Apple prepping to unveil a completely overhauled 10th anniversary iPhone this fall.Greater China Sees An Improvement On Constant Currency   BasisApple's gross margins came in at 38.5% for the quarter. While this was at the high end of the company's guidance range
column18: it was roughly 150 bps lower than last year's figure. There are likely to be two key factors driving this reduction. Firstly
column19: the strong dollar is hurting Apple's price realizations in many key emerging markets. Moreover
column20: there is a possibility that manufacturing costs on the new iPhones are higher
column21: on account of the more advanced components and higher memory capacity per devices. (Related:Apple's Flagship iPhone Keeps Getting More Expensive To Build) However
column22: this is likely to have been partially offset by a higher mix of service revenues (9.1% of total sales
column23: up from 8% last year)
column24: which have significantly higher gross margins. Apple is projecting gross margins of between 38% and 39% for Q2 FY'17.Greater China Sees An Improvement On Constant Currency   BasisApple's performance in Greater China saw some improvement
column25: driven by a strong uptake for the iPhone 7
column26: which emerged the best selling smartphone in the country during the holiday quarter
column27: as well as double digit growth in iPad shipments. Revenues from the region came in at $16.23 billion
column28: marking a 12% year-over-year decline
column29: amid depreciation of the Chinese Yuan (down 6% year-over-year) as well as a significant decline in sales from Hong Kong.  However
column30: the company says that sales from Mainland China would have actually been up by about 6% on a constant current basis
column31: marking a significant improvement over the firm's performance in the recent quarters.Services Growth Remains Strong
column32: Watch Could Be Gaining   MomentumServices revenues rose by roughly 18% year-over-year to an all time record of $7.17 billion
column33: driven primarily by the App Store
column34: which saw revenues grow by 43% over the quarter and the Apple Music streaming music service. This is positive
column35: considering that the rate of growth in Apple's iDevice installed base is likely to be slowing down
column36: potentially indicating that per-device spending on services is trending upwards. Apple indicated that it was looking to double its services revenues over the next four years. Apple also noted that the Apple Watch had its best quarter ever both in terms of units and revenues
column37: with demand outstripping supply.View Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis   Research"

column3: 04:24:00 PM EDT;"What happenedShares ofInvenSense(NYSE: INVN) took a sudden dive on Wednesday
column4: plunging as much as   11.4% with little warning.So whatUnconfirmed chatter that InvenSense might lose a component   supply contract withApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) cast a shadow over the company's pending merger   with Japanese electronics veteranTDK(NASDAQOTH: TTDKY) . Apple accounted for 40% of InvenSense's   revenue in fiscal 2016
column5: so any weakening of that crucial business   relationship would clearly undermine InvenSense's value to TDK as   well.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Now whatTDK wants to establish itself as a major supplier of sensor   solutions
column6: and picking up InvenSense for $1.3 billion in cash   would go a long way toward that goal. It's unclear how the rumors   of a fallout between Apple and InvenSense got started
column7: and the   whispers could very well turn out to be mere hearsay and   gossip.I see no reason for InvenSense investors to take this report   too seriously
column8: because the pending merger provides a comfortable   buffer for any newfound risks. If nothing else

column1: Are Your Favorite Stocks Cheap?;February 01
column3: 04:07:00 PM EDT;"(1:30) - Under Armour misses earnings first time in 5 years!(3:15) - Is Starbucks out of favor with investors? Tracey talks   restaurants.(5:48) - Apple and William & Sonoma: Are they value stocks?(10:40) - Stock ticker summaryWelcome to Episode #28 of the Value Investor PodcastEvery week
column4: Zacks value stock strategist and the Editor ofZacks Value Investor portfolio
column5: Tracey Ryniec
column6: talks about all things happening in the value stock universe
column7: including her top stock picks.It's earnings season so that means some stocks will get a boost off their reports
column8: and others will get sold off. These days
column9: an earnings miss or a warning on guidance can be enough to send a stock down by the double digits.If you're a value investor
column10: your first thought upon seeing a big sell off in a stock is probably ""is that stock cheap enough for me to buy now?""There have been some juicy sell offs already this earnings season. Additionally
column11: some other ""favorite"" stocks that many people own seem out of favor or down on their luck.Are These Favorite Stocks Cheap Enough to Be   Values?1.      Under Armour (UAA) sold off 25% on its first earnings miss in 5 years. Shares are now down over 50% from their highs. But is it a value?2.     Starbucks (SBUX) went nowhere after its earnings reports. Shares also fell 9% in the last year
column12: underperforming the market. The company appears to be out-of-favor with investors. (In full disclosure
column13: Tracey is a long-term owner of it in her personal portfolio.) Should value investors be taking a look?3.     Shake Shack Inc. (SHAK) was once the darling of Wall Street but shares have fallen 19% over the last 2 years. Is the growth catching up with the valuation now?4.     Apple (AAPL) just reported earnings. Revenues surprised the Street. Is it one of the few technology stocks that might be a value stock?5.     Williams-Sonoma Inc. (WSM) owns one of the top brands in home furnishings: West Elm. But it's other brands are struggling. It doesn't report earnings until March but should value investors be keeping an eye on this retailer?Investors should always dig deeper than simply the value fundamentals before making a decision to buy a stock. Does the company have rising earnings estimates? What does the growth picture look like?Just because a company has always been an expensive growth stock doesn't mean it always will be in the future.Find out more about what Tracey thinks about the buying opportunities in these popular stocks in this week's podcast.Have a question for Tracey?Do you have a value investing question for Tracey?Is there a topic you really want covered on an upcoming Value Investor Podcast?She wants to hear from you.Send your questions for Tracey to her e-mail address at: podcast@zacks.com.Want more insights from Tracey?Check out her weekly Value Investor service to receive more in-depth analysis on value companies and see which stocks she thinks are the best bargains now.Click here to learn more.Soundcloud:TuneIn:Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? column1: Wednesday Apple Rumors: APPL Releases New AirPods Update;February 01
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of an update for the AirPods. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Wednesday.makeArticleAd();AirPods Update:AAPL has released a small update for its AirPods
column6: reportsAppleInsider. The new update was quietly pushed out by the company to solve issues with the wireless headphones. The tech company hasn't said what these bug fixes are. However
column7: it is likely that they addressed issues with device synchronization and connectivity. The update downloads when the AirPods are in the charger
column8: the charger is plugged in and the linked iPhone is nearby with a Wi-Fi connection.Original Content:Apple CEO Tim Cook says that the company may be looking into making original TV content
column9: MacRumorsnotes. According to the AAPL CEO
column10: the company has its ""toe in the water"" due to its experience with Apple Music. Cook didn't say much else about the company's original content efforts. However
column11: he did note that the company's TV set-top box has come a long way and says that it may give them a ""clear platform"" to work with.Immigration Ban:Tim Cook is considering taking legal action over President Donald Trump's recent immigration order
column12: reportsThe Wall Street Journal. The executive order signed by Trump on Friday banned refugees from seven countries from entering the United States. Cook argues that this has affected hundreds of the company's employees. He didn't say exactly what legal action AAPL may take against the order
column13: but said it should be ""constructive and productive.""Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postWednesday Apple Rumors: APPL Releases New AirPods Updateappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc.'s iPhone 7 Plus Is a Smash Hit;February 01
column3: 01:19:00 PM EDT;"The first quarter of anApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) fiscal year is usually the company's peak quarter
column4: as it follows the launch of Apple's latest flagship iPhone   device. The iPhone generates the bulk of the company's revenue
column5: and so the quarter in which Apple sees the most iPhone shipments   is the quarter in which it sees its greatest revenue.Apple's iPhone 7 Plus. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Although there were rumors that Apple was seeing relatively   tepid demand for its latest iPhone models -- the iPhone 7 and the   iPhone 7 Plus -- the company's financial performance tells a   different tale.Apple reported shipping a record 78.29 million iPhones in the   first quarter
column6: handily beating its previous quarterly record of   just shy of 75 million units. CEO Tim Cook said that it saw   ""exceptional demand"" for iPhones that ""beat [Apple's] own   internal expectations.""This robust unit demand didn't come at the expense of average   selling prices
column7: either -- iPhone average selling prices in the   quarter came in at just a hair under $695.Just as the iPhone business is the star of the company's most   recent earnings report
column8: the iPhone 7 Plus appears to be the star   of the iPhone business.iPhone 7 Plus is a smash hitCook said that the iPhone 7 is the company's ""most popular   model
column9: but he highlighted the fact that the company saw   ""especially strong demand for iPhone 7 Plus.""Demand was so strong
column10: in fact
column11: that Cook says that the iPhone   7 Plus made up ""a higher portion of the new product mix than   [Apple has] ever seen with Plus models in the past.""To further drive the point home
column12: even given the   stronger-than-expected unit shipment performance during the   quarter
column13: Apple reported that ""demand for iPhone 7 Plus exceeded   supply throughout the quarter"" and that the company only ""came   into supply/demand balance in January.""And
column14: finally
column15: it's worth pointing out that Apple is seeing   this unexpectedly strong iPhone 7 Plus demand even though it   priced the devices at a $20 premium to where it had priced   previous iPhone Plus models (which previously carried $100   premiums over their non-Plus counterparts).Clearly
column16: Apple's customer base likes what the company did with   the iPhone 7 Plus and was willing to pay a premium for the added   features.In the past
column17: Apple had differentiated its Plus models with   larger
column18: sharper displays as well as some very minor camera   enhancements (i.e.
column19: optical image stabilization). However
column20: this   time around
column21: in addition to the usual points of differentiation
column22: Apple included a dual-lens camera on the iPhone 7 Plus which   enabled an interesting optical zoom feature.The key lesson here is that if Apple brings interesting   innovations and features to premium products and tries to charge   a premium for those features
column23: then it may very well get paid for   those features.Open sesameAt this point
column24: it's obvious what Apple should do next --   introduce even higher-priced iPhones with even more interesting   features and points of differentiation. Apple shouldn't go wild   adding in every feature under the sun
column25: but its product definition   and marketing teams should now have the freedom to go ahead and   build products with higher cost structures that are intended to   sell at higher price points.Such products
column26: launched in conjunction with models priced at   the more ""typical"" price points
column27: could be quite successful for   the company. In fact
column28: current rumors suggest that Apple is   planning to launch two straightforward successors to this year's   iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus
column29: and then higher up in the product   stack
column30: the company may launch an iPhone with a curved OLED   display and other goodies.If the upcoming OLED iPhone is a fundamentally compelling   product -- and I think it will be -- then I could see Apple   successfully charging even more for it than it does for its top   iPhone 7 Plus models.The next couple of years could be very interesting for Apple's   iPhone product line and
column31: ultimately
column32: its business!10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column4: 12:35:36 PM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOnce left for dead
column6: semiconductor giantAdvanced Micro Devices
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD)

column10: AMD stock haspunished those who bet against it. But is it now time to take profits?makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrNope.AMD stock had a slow start to 2017
column11: off about 6% before Tuesday night's fourth-quarter earnings report
column12: is back in the black thanks to a Wednesday surge after showing off some of the operational dominance it sported in a rip-roaring 2016.Expectation for the QuarterFor the quarter that ended December
column13: Wall Street expected the company to report a loss of 2 cents per share on revenues of $1.07 billion. AMD beat on both fronts
column14: recording revenues of $1.11 billion and a loss of just 1 cent per share.Recent results fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) hinted that Advanced Micro might be in for a Street-beating quarter.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018On Friday John Vinh
column15: analyst at Pacific Crest noted that Intel's results
column16: which reflected less-bad personal computer trends
column17: suggests strong growth for the sector. Notably
column18: Vinh cited AMD as benefiting from ""strength in gaming and high-end PCs."" To that end
column19: the analysts also said the improvements in high-end PCs could reduce concerns about high-end GPU inventory at desktop graphics card manufacturers.Well
column20: a beat is what we got
column21: and that came on the power of AMD's graphics chips
column22: which saw revenues grow 15% year-over-year.The Key to AMD: GPUsGPU
column23: or Graphics Processing Unit
column24: is a big business for AMD. Those chips render images
column25: animations and video for display on computer's screens. And the strength of that business has been a key component of AMD's turnaround. In the third quarter
column26: reported in October
column27: AMD posted a 23% year-over-year jump in revenue of $1.3 billion. The company benefited from strong growth in its popular Radeon line GPUs as revenue from that segment rose 11% year over year.This quarter
column28: GPUs helped once more. Revenues in Computing and Graphics grew 28% year-over-year
column29: thanks in part to higher average GPU selling prices.The company recently announced that its FirePro server GPUs have been selected byAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) to power its cloud platform in 2017. All told
column30: AMD's GPU strength has begun to gain traction in different verticals
column31: which should help it narrow the market share gap with leaderNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA).Bottom Line for AMD StockAMD's report was full of other positives
column32: such as an expansion of gross margins from 30% to 32%
column33: and slight gains in its Enterprise
column34: Embedded and Semi-Custom business (4%).Still
column35: graphics and high performance are the name of the game.AMD stock surged 14% higher on Wednesday's reaction to fourth-quarter results
column36: putting shares at highs last seen in 2017. The stock has returned more than 400% in 12 months - better than the 20% one-year gain in theS&P 500.And even still
column37: AMD is showing that there's little let-up in the growth ramp.I expect AMD stock to reach $13 in 2017
column38: delivering 22% gains on the back of greater GPU adoption and rising margins.As of this writing

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Earnings: Why Shares Are Trading Higher;February 01
column4: 12:33:00 PM EDT;"Following the company's first-quarter earnings report on   Tuesday
column5: shares ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) are up sharply on Wednesday. At the time of this   writing
column6: Apple stockis trading at about $123
column7: up more than 5% for the trading day.   The move helped the stock hit a new 52-week high. Apple stock's   move higher on Monday adds to the increasingly bullish sentiment   toward the stock recently. In the past six months
column8: shares are up   about 23%
column9: easily outperforming the S&P 500's 5% gain during   the same period.Investor optimism toward Apple stock recently is likely due to   a wide range of factors
column10: including its conservative valuation
column11: speculation about a major redesign for Apple's expected iPhone   launch this fall
column12: and Samsung's recall of its Galaxy Note 7. But   one trend in Apple's business is likely serving as a primary   driver for the company's rising stock price: a rebound in iPhone   sales.iPhone 7. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Rebounding iPhone salesTo understand why recently rebounding iPhone sales are so   important to investors
column13: it's important to realize how steeply   iPhone sales were declining on a year-over-year basis just a few   quarters ago.MetricQ3 2016Q2 2016iPhone unit sales growth (YOY)(15%)(16%)iPhone revenue growth (YOY)(23%)(18%)Total revenue (YOY)(15%)(13%)Fiscal quarters shown. Data retrieved from Apple's earnings   releases. Table by author.At the iPhone segment's worst point last year
column14: unit sales and   revenue in the company's fiscal third quarter of 2016 declined   15% and 23%
column15: respectively
column16: dragging total revenue 15% lower   compared to the year-ago quarter. As Apple was reporting   significant year-over-year declines in its largest product   segment
column17: investors were concerned about how the product segment   would perform over the longer term.But as early as Apple's fourth-quarter earnings report in   October
column18: it was clear that the tech giant's iPhone business could   soon end a three-quarter streak of year-over-year declines in   total revenue. The company guided for first-quarter revenue to be   between $76 billion and $78 billion
column19: up from $75.9 billion in the   year-ago quarter. Considering that iPhone accounts for over 60%   of Apple's trailing-12-month revenue
column20: this meant management was   optimistic about the company's new September-launched iPhone 7   and 7 Plus.Sure enough
column21: iPhone sales rebounded.Fiscal quarters shown. Data retrieved from Apple's earnings     releases. Chart by author.Apple's first-quarter earnings release this week confirmed the   company's return to iPhone growth
column22: with Apple reporting   year-over-year iPhone unit and revenue growth of 5%
column23: helping the   company's total revenue rise 3%.Can iPhone growth persist?The big question going forward
column24: of course
column25: is whether Apple's   iPhone business can keep growing. In the near term
column26: it looks like   management expects another quarter of growth. Apple said it   expected total second-quarter revenue to be between $51.5 billion   and $53.5 billion
column27: up from $50.6 billion in the year-ago quarter.   With iPhone accounting for the bulk of Apple's total revenue
column28: this guidance for growth in total revenue likely means management   expects growth for the iPhone
column29: too.Beyond Apple's second quarter
column30: however
column31: it's not as certain   that Apple's iPhone sales growth can be sustained throughout   fiscal 2017. However
column32: a return to growth for iPhone 7 -- a   product with a three-year-old form factor -- is promising news
column33: highlighting how well the company's products continue to resonate   with customers.Combining Apple stock's conservative valuation with growth in   the company's biggest product segment
column34: it's easy to see why   investors are optimistic about the stock's potential
column35: recently.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
