column1: Intel Corporation Gets an Apple Inc. iPhone 7 Boost;January 31
column4: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) has managed to achieve a real degree of success in   the market for chips that go into smartphones. A while back
column5: it   was revealed thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had chosen to use Intel as a second source for the   LTE modems that power its iPhone.Apple's iPhone SE. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Now
column6: while some investors may have worried that Intel might be   ""giving away"" these cellular modems -- in a move similar to what   the company did with its Bay Trail tablet processors (i.e.   providing platform cost offsets valued more than the selling   prices of the chips) -- the company's most recent financial   results show that this is very clearly not the case.The big modem boostIntel's modem sales fall under its Client Computing Group   (CCG)
column7: which derives the bulk of its revenue from sales of   processors and other components that go into personal   computers. When Intel reports financial results for CCG
column8: it   gives investors two numbers to chew on: platform revenue and   ""other"" revenue. Platform revenue is made up of processor and   accompanying chipset (also known as a PCH) sales
column9: while ""other""   revenue refers to a smorgasbord of other complementary   technologies
column10: including cellular modems.We can see that Intel is seeing a very large boost in cellular   modem sales because Intel's revenue from ""other"" went from $356   million in the fourth quarter of 2015 -- when Intel sold   precisely zero modems to Apple -- to $773 million in the fourth   quarter of 2016 -- when Intel is known to be selling modems to   Apple.Of course
column11: it's likely that not all of that increase is due to   the ramp up in cellular modem shipments -- Intel did take the   time to highlight that it enjoyed record Wi-Fi chip shipments   last quarter -- but there's really nothing else that can explain   the substantial majority of that increase.What does this revenue increase tell us?The bad news is that we can't deduce too much about the   profitability of these modems solely from these results -- though   Intel did indicate later in the call that cellular modem   shipments during 2017 would serve as a headwind to the company's   gross profit margins. So we know that the modems are sold at   lower than corporate average margins.What we can deduce is this
column12: however: Intel isn't providing   excessive ""contra-revenue"" payments to get these modems into the   iPhone because Intel is generating positive revenue -- and   significant revenue at that -- from its modems. (Although we   already knew this because Intel would almost have certainly   disclosed to investors in advance that a ramp of its modem   shipments would detract from operating profit.) If that were the   case
column13: some investors may have wanted to see the financial   evidence before believing it.Looking aheadIf we assume that Intel is going to continue to supply Apple   with modems beyond the iPhone 7 -- and the odds of this look good   -- then there are some interesting financial   implications. First
column14: Intel's share at Apple may be set to   grow in the coming product cycle. Right now
column15: Intel is in some   portion of the iPhone 7 models
column16: but is completely absent from the   iPhone SE
column17: iPhone 6s
column18: or iPhone 6s.Once Apple releases new models and waterfalls the iPhone 7 and   iPhone 7 Plus to serve as its mid-range offerings -- and if we   assume that Intel and Qualcomm get roughly equivalent order   allocations during the next iPhone cycle to what we're seeing   with the iPhone 7 series -- then Intel's share will necessarily   go up. I also wouldn't be surprised to see Intel inside of a   future iPhone SE
column19: as well.It's reasonable to expect that Intel will see some nice   year-over-year growth in the ""other"" portion of CCG over the   course of 2017
column20: with acceleration happening in the second half of   the year
column21: due to the launch of the new iPhone models.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Is Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?;January 31
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDon't look now
column5: butMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) looks to be taking another run atAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column6: NASDAQ:GOOG) Chrome operating system. References have begun popping up in builds of the Windows 10 Creators Update (which is due to arrive in April) to Windows 10 Cloud.makeArticleAd();Source: MicrosoftSpeculation is growing that Windows 10 Cloud is in fact a new simplified version of Microsoft's operating system
column7: designed to run on devices powered by inexpensive ARM chips fromARM Holdings plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:ARMH).In other words
column8: it appears that Microsoft is preparing to take on the threat of Chromebooks - the cheap
column9: popular laptops running Google's Chrome OS. And it seems to be doing so by resurrecting the idea of Windows RT.Windows 10 CloudWindows 10 Creators Build is the next major revision of the Microsoft Windows PC operating system. It's due to begin rolling out to users around April 17.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsBut developers have been testing pre-release builds of Microsoft's software and recently some of them began to notice something strange: The code references different variations of the operating system. For example
column10: Windows 10 Pro for Workstation and Windows 10 for Enterprise are spiked out. Nothing unusual there. But then
column11: references to Windows 10 Cloud began to appear. And that started raising eyebrows - what is Windows 10 Cloud?ZDNet'sMary Jo Foley put the pieces together yesterday. Quoting unnamed sources
column12: she says that the mysterious Windows 10 Cloud is a new
column13: simplified version of Microsoft Windows that will run only Unified Windows Platform (UWP) apps. In other words
column14: it's a""simpler
column15: safer
column16: cheaper"" version of Windows 10.You might also think of it as another crack at Windows RT Windows RT? But Why?Everyone remembers the mess that wasWindows RT. The attempt to shoehorn a version of Windows onto a consumer tablet running ARM chips -the ill-fated Surface RT - very nearly dealt MSFT's tablet aspirations a fatal blow.However
column17: despite the failure of Windows RT
column18: Microsoft has never given up on the idea of Windows on ARM chips. By doing so
column19: it can get Windows onto mobile devices that can't use the more powerful and expensive chips fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). The company has already been showing offWindows 10 running in emulation on high-end ARM chips. As part of that effort
column20: it could also be working on a ""lite"" version that can deliver much of the Windows 10 experience on less expensive
column21: lower powered ARM hardware.So why
column22: why
column23: whywould Microsoft risk falling flat on its face again with what essentially amounts to another crack at Windows RT? There are two reasons.The first is that dream of ""Windows everywhere."" Having the full Windows 10 experience on high-powered ARM chips is great
column24: but only flagship smartphones and tablets can afford to use those chips. Windows 10 Cloud would get Microsoft Windows (and Bing) onto a whole lot more mobile hardware.The second is Google's Chrome OS and Chromebooks. These cheap laptops have been under Microsoft's skin for years. They've become extremely popular in the education sector thanks to low cost
column25: ease of use and built-in security. And Chromebooks have just kept selling
column26: to the point where last year they passed evenApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL)MacBooks in sales.Microsoft has tried fighting back by helping manufacturers put out cheap Windows 10 laptops
column27: but that hasn't stemmed the Chromebook flood. Windows 10 makes for a sluggish experience on inexpensive Intel hardware
column28: it's far more complex than Chrome OS to use and lacks the drop-dead easy security of Chromebooks.Cash Out of Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Before EarningsWindows 10 Cloud running on laptops with ARM processors would compete head-to-head with Chromebooks running Chrome OS: simpler
column29: safer and cheaper than Windows 10.Microsoft refused to comment on theZDNetpost
column30: but the pieces pointing to Windows 10 as a Chrome OS-fighting
column31: second crack at Windows RT make sense. Naturally
column32: MSFT is going to avoid all references to Windows RT - that's poison - and the Windows 10 Cloud name could end up being a code name.It could also be an attempt to steal some of the Chrome OS ""cloud"" thunder. Expect to get the final answer on Windows 10 Cloud from Microsoft prior to that April 17 Windows 10 Creators Build release.As of this writing
column33: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 ""Golden"" Ammo Stocks to Buy for Big 2017 Returns3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionThe postIs Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Intel Corporation's Personal-Computer Business Beats Expectations;January 31
column4: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) announced its financial results for the fourth   quarter of 2016 and
column5: by extension
column6: the entirety of 2016.A rendering of an Intel seventh-generation Core processor.     Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();The company had previously guided to $15.7 billion in revenue   for the quarter and gross profit margin of 61%
column7: representing   sequential declines from $15.8 billion and 63.3%
column8: respectively.Intel's actual financial results were much more impressive;   the company reported $16.4 billion in revenue for the quarter and   a gross profit margin percentage of 61.7%
column9: up from $14.9 billion   and down from 64.3% in the prior year
column10: respectively.For the full year
column11: Intel raked in $59.4 billion at 60.9% gross   profit margin -- a little above the midpoint of its long-term   gross margin range of 55% to 65%
column12: though down 170 basis points   year over year.This upside appears to have been driven
column13: ironically enough
column14: by   the company's Client Computing Group (CCG) business
column15: which   derives the bulk of its revenues from sales of components into   personal computers
column16: generally viewed as a declining market.Let's take a closer look at the company's revenue and profit   performance in this segment.Solid improvements in revenue and     profitabilityIntel reported that total CCG revenue hit $9.13 billion in the   most recent quarter
column17: up from $8.76 billion in the same quarter a   year-ago -- a respectable 4% year-over-year boost.Operating income vastly outpaced revenue
column18: though
column19: with this   figure growing from $2.72 billion in the year-ago quarter to   $3.52 billion in the most recent quarter -- up almost 30% year   over year. Management attributed this to lower operating   expenses
column20: a ""richer product mix
column21: and improved product margins as   14-nanometer chip manufacturing yields improved. The same story   has been playing out all year in CCG.Now
column22: it's worth noting that Intel reported that the ""platform""   portion of its CCG revenue
column23: which consists of sales of processors   and chipsets
column24: were roughly flat
column25: at $8.36 billion in the prior   year compared with $8.4 billion in the most recent quarter. But   its ""other"" segment -- which includes complementary products
column26: such as wireless chips -- saw revenues more than double to $773   million
column27: from $356 million a year-ago.It is likely that this large boost in ""other"" revenue within   CCG was due primarily to the ramp-up of the company's XMM 7360   cellular modem in theApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus devices.Good full-year resultsFor the full year
column28: Intel reported that CCG revenue was up 2%
column29: while expectations going into the year were for a decline
column30: with   operating profit up a smidgen more than 30%. Platform revenue was   roughly flat
column31: at $30.75 billion versus $30.68 billion
column32: with   ""other"" revenue surging from $1.54 billion in 2015 to $2.16   billion in 2016.The iPhone win clearly contributed to a large part of the   ""other"" segment growth here
column33: but the driver of the increased   platform revenue is a little bit subtler.Indeed
column34: Intel reported that shipments of its notebook computer   processors declined by 1% year over year and that shipments of   its desktop computer processors dropped by 6%. Key to keeping   platform revenues flat was a 2% increase in notebook platform   average selling prices
column35: as well as a 2% increase in desktop   platform average selling prices.What's happening
column36: then
column37: is that computer makers are selling   fewer computers than they were before
column38: as evidenced by the   notebook and desktop platform unit shipment drops
column39: but the   computers that they do sell
column40: on average
column41: contain more expensive   processors.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column44: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Intel wasn't one of them! column1: 5 Reasons I Don't Buy MeetMe's Growth Story;January 31
column4: I highlightedMeetMe(NASDAQ: MEET) as apotentially undervaluedgrowth play in a frothy market. The social networking app maker   posted eye-popping numbers last quarter -- 32% annual growth in   monthly active users (MAUs)
column5: 20% growth in total revenues
column6: and   30% non-GAAP earnings growth.Analysts expect MeetMe's revenue and non-GAAP earnings to   respectively rise 38% and 16% next year. Yet the stock trades at   just 7 times trailing earnings and 10 times forward earnings.   Let's take a look at the five key reasons investors aren't buying   MeetMe's growth story
column7: despite its high growth figures and low   valuations.MeetMe's mobile app. Image source: Google Play.makeArticleAd();1. A troubling history with sexual predatorsMeetMe lets users find new people in their area to chat with
column8: similar toMatch's(NASDAQ: MTCH) Tinder. While there's nothing inherently   sinister about the app
column9: there have been multiple reports of   MeetMe being used by sexual predators.In 2014
column10: the City of San Francisco sued MeetMe for the   unlawful publication of minors' profiles
column11: photos
column12: and geolocation   data
column13: and claimed that  the app ""enabled"" sexual predators   to find their victims. The city cited several cases involving   adult men and minors in which MeetMe was used. MeetMe settled the   case for $200
column14: 000 the  following year
column15: agreeing to clarify   and simplify its user agreements and settings
column16: and reducing the   amount of data displayed on minors to their city and state.But the cases involving MeetMe didn't cease -- last February
column17: a Buffalo man was  charged with multiple counts of child   pornography after using MeetMe to find minors. MeetMe's troubles   raised red flags at Tinder
column18: which hiked its age limit from 13 to   18 last June. Yet MeetMe still hasn't followed suit
column19: presumably   because it would lose a large portion of its users.2. The potential loss of ad revenuesYou'd think that big companies would be reluctant to advertise   on MeetMe
column20: but plenty of big brands still advertise on the app.   That's because MeetMe generates most of its ad revenues from   programmatic ads delivered byTwitter's(NYSE:TWTR) MoPub.This means that MoPub's customers simply pick a demographic --   in MeetMe's case
column21: younger users and Millennials -- and the   platform feeds the ads to various apps. This means that many   companies probably don't realize that their ads are appearing on   MeetMe.Therefore
column22: a common bear thesis is that MoPub could decide to   drop MeetMe due to violations of its terms of service
column23: or   advertisers could ask MoPub to pull their ads from the   controversial app. There's no evidence either of these scenarios   will occur
column24: but it raises a troubling question -- if MeetMe's   reputation worsens
column25: can it still keep growing its ad   revenues?3. Being booted from the app storesIn its 10-K filing for fiscal 2015
column26: MeetMe admits  that   its business will suffer if it is ""unable to maintain a good   relationship"" withAppleandAlphabet's Google. It notes that its app could be pulled from their app   stores ""if we violate"" or the companies believe ""that we have   violated"" their terms and conditions.The bulls might believe that's just a typical ""risk factor""   warning
column27: but MeetMe admits in the same filing that ""on more than   one occasion
column28: Apple rejected its app ""because of user generated   content and other concerns."" This indicates that another   high-profile lawsuit could knock MeetMe out of the app stores and   kill its business.4. Tinder is crushing MeetMeMeetMe arrived before Tinder
column29: which was initially launched in   2012. But over the past five years
column30: mainstream interest in MeetMe   waned in correlation with Tinder's growth
column31: as seen in this chart   from Google Trends:Image source: Google.That decline also explains why MeetMe acquired its competitor   Skout last  October. That move boosted the company's MAU   count from about 5 million to  8.5 million
column32: and greatly   inflated MeetMe's top and bottom line growth for fiscal 2016.5. The lack of insider confidenceIf MeetMe is as undervalued as the fundamentals suggest
column33: you'd   expect insiders to be loading up on shares. However
column34: MeetMe CEO   Geoffrey Cook just  sold 250
column35: 000 shares (16% of his entire   position) at an average price of $5.02.Including Cook's sales
column36: insiders sold  1.96 million   shares over the past 12 months
column37: but only bought 334
column38: 000 shares.   It's understandable that MeetMe's insiders would sell after the   stock's 50% rally over the past 12 months
column39: but it also indicates   that its upside potential could be limited.The key takeawayThe main lesson here is to always look beyond the valuations   and growth forecasts. On the surface
column40: MeetMe looks like a rapidly   growing social app maker trading at a discount to its peers. But   dig deeper
column41: and you'll see an app that's struggling to prove that   it's not a tool for criminals while remaining relevant against   Tinder
column42: which dominates the space with  over 50 million   active users.10 stocks we like better than MeetMeWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and MeetMe wasn't one of     them! column1: Why Expedia Inc Will Profit From This Global Market Trend (EXPE);January 31
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs an analyst who spends every day looking at numbers
column5: I have a tendency to try and quantify everything. We humans
column6: as a species
column7: tend to do this all the time.makeArticleAd();For the most part
column8: it serves us well. But it can also sometimes be a trap
column9: diminishing the value of what is simply unquantifiable.I learned this lesson a few years ago on a trip to the green highlands and snow-capped mountains of Peru.During the planning phase
column10: I contemplated every detail of the trip
column11: from number of hours spent on flights nights spent in hotels how many sites I could see within a certain amount of time. Everything had to be just perfect.But even during the early phases of the journey
column12: I found myself countingThere were four grueling days of hiking. At about 20.5 miles in total length
column13: it took four days to complete. Each night
column14: we camped at about 13
column15: 000 feet. And at the summit of our hike
column16: we would reach 14
column17: 928 feet.Strenuous hiking at such a high elevation for such an extended period of time meant that every breath
column18: every step
column19: was a laborious effort. But we pressed on
column20: young and old
column21: encouraged each other and offered a helping hand until we reached the end of our journey. And best of all
column22: we knew that each painstaking step meant that we were just that closer to seeing one of the most truly remarkable sights in the world: the ancient Incan city of Machu Picchu.It was only during those little moments when I was able to move past this tendency to quantify everything that I truly lost myself in the mystery and wonder the world has to offer.Hopefully
column23: you've had the chance to have experiences like this at some point in your life
column24: too. All too often
column25: we in the developed world tend to take for granted the fact that most of us have the means to do these kinds of things.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018But there are hundreds of millions of people who don't - but they soon will.The World's Burgeoning Middle ClassGlobal demand for travel is surging. Hundreds of millions of people are entering the global middle class right now and in the years to come. One of the first things these people will look to do is travel.By 2030
column26: two-thirds of the global middle class will be residents of the Asia-Pacific region. That's up from just under one-third in 2009. And China alone is expected to have a staggering one billion members of the middle class by then.China's budding middle class is already traveling in greater numbers than ever before. A United Nations tourism report showed that the number of Chinese citizens traveling overseas has surged from 10 million in 2000 to more than 83 million in 2013.This is a huge opportunity for the online travel business. Consumers in the Asia-Pacific region currently book only about 27% of their travels online
column27: while Latin America lags even further at 21%. In China
column28: only about 15% of consumers currently book their travel online. This is compared to rates over 50% in the United States and Europe.It's not hard to imagine that the rest of the world will quickly catch up to the United States and Europe in terms of booking their travel online. And that sets up a tremendous opportunity.That's where my colleague Jimmy Butts comes in with one of his most recent picks in his premium newsletter
column29: Top Stock AdvisorHow To Profit From This TrendIn last month's issue of his newsletter
column30: Jimmy reported on the incredible growth of the online travel market. Citing much of the information I referenced above
column31: he went on to recommend two publicly-traded online travel companies.I don't like to make a habit of giving away too many picks from our premium publications
column32: since our subscribers pay good money for this information (to learn how to subscribe
column33: go here). But I can reveal that one of them isExpedia Inc(EXPE)
column34: the world's largest online travel company.Surging industry growth is reflected in Expedia's gross bookings. In 2015
column35: the company booked a staggering $60 billion worth of flights
column36: hotels
column37: rental cars and cruises. It's on track to crush those figures in 2016
column38: already racking up gross bookings of more than $56 billion through the first nine months of this year
column39: which is 23% more compared with the first nine months of 2015.Expedia has made major strides in the international market. In 2005
column40: international revenue made up only 22% of its portfolio; last year that soared to approximately 45%. But that's just the tip of the iceberg in terms of potential for growth. Despite being the largest player in online travel
column41: the company still has only a 4% share of the global market.This speaks to the highly-fragmented nature of the market
column42: but also for the potential to grow through acquisitions
column43: which Expedia has been doing for some time now already. Between the growth in the global middle class and growth in the online travel market
column44: Jimmy thinks Expedia should benefit greatly over the next 5-10 years.As such
column45: it's a good long-term holding to consider adding to your portfolio.3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 EarningsJimmy's other pick
column46: however
column47: may have even more potential. I won't give away the name here (to get it
column48: you'll have to subscribe toTop Stock Advisor.) But it has a hold on 50% of the online travel market in China - which by all accounts should be the prime growth market in in the years ahead.While the real value of travel may not be quantifiable
column49: investors who back this company now could be counting sizeable gains within a few years. If you'd like to get the name and ticker symbol of this pick

column1: Alphabet Employees Protest Against Trump's Immigration Ban;January 31
column3: 09:49:00 AM EDT;"Protests against Donald Trump's anti-immigration policy are gaining steam and the technology sector appears to be leading the way.  More than 2000Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle employees staged protests against Trump's immigration ban by walking out of eight offices worldwide including the company's headquarters in Mountain View on Monday. Photos and videos of the walkouts have been tweeted using hashtag #GooglersUnite.Google co-founder Sergey Brin and CEO Sundar Pichai have extended their full support to the opposition.Concurrent with the protest
column4: Google created a $4 million fund to support immigrant rights groups like the Immigrant Legal Resource Center
column5: the American Civil Liberties Union
column6: the U.N. Refugee Agency and the International Rescue Committee.The protest was particularly against Trump's executive order to ban nationals of seven Muslim majority countries - Iraq
column7: Iran
column8: Somalia
column9: Libya
column10: Syria
column11: Sudan and Yemen - from coming to the U.S. Pichai denounced the order and stated that the ban affects about 187 Google employees.We note that not quite long ago
column12: Trump had called up technology leaders and urged them to create and retain jobs within the U.S. to which most of them had given their nods. However as the immigration ban order rolled out
column13: the sector is sending clear indications that it will not create jobs at the cost of preventing entry to external talent.Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteProtests Across the Technology IndustryTrump's immigration restrictions have faced the flak of tech leaders in the form of tweets
column14: memos and statements. Chief executive officers of MicrosoftMSFT
column15: AppleAAPL
column16: NetflixNFLX
column17: Uber
column18: Airbnb and Tesla Motors have all indicated that they are against the decision.The technology sector recruits a big chunk outside talent and the survival of the sector could be at stake if immigration reduces or stops completely.The sector fears that Trump may overhaul the H1-B program that allows Silicon Valley to bring foreign engineers and technical experts to the U.S. for three to six years.Zacks Rank and Stock Price MovementAt present

column20: the stock has underperformed the ZacksInternet Servicesindustry. It has gained 6.87% compared to the industry's gain of 7.74%.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: 3 Questions for Apple
column4: 09:06:00 AM EDT;"After the market closes today
column5: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) will report results for its first fiscal quarter   of 2017. Ending Dec. 31
column6: the quarter includes the important   holiday period
column7: raising the stakes for the company's performance.   Thanks to seasonality and the timing of Apple's latest iPhone   launch
column8: the quarter is expected to include record-high   revenue.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();While Apple's earnings release will give investors a useful   window into the company's financial performance
column9: the tech giant's   earnings call will likely provide investors with some useful   nuggets
column10: too. Ahead the earnings call
column11: which will take place   shortly after Apple releases its financial results for the   quarter
column12: here are three topics Apple CEO Tim Cook will hopefully   address.1. How confident is management in its product pipeline?Recently
column13: Apple's iPhone business has not only leveled off
column14: but it has also been in decline. In Apple's fourth fiscal quarter   of 2016
column15: for instance
column16: iPhone revenue and unit sales were down   13% and 5% year over year
column17: respectively. While some investors may   be hoping the iPhone can return to growth in Apple's first   quarter
column18: investors -- or Apple -- shouldn't count on the iPhone   to be a major growth driver for the company in the future.Since iPhone accounts for about 60% of Apple's total sales
column19: the segment's headwinds make the health of the tech giant's   product pipeline more important than ever. Of course
column20: given the   company's tendency to keep things secret
column21: investors shouldn't   expect to get any specific information on new products from Cook   during Apple's earnings call
column22: but investors can still look for   the CEO to talk about his level of confidence in the company's   upcoming products.2. What could Apple's services revenue growth look like in   2017?As Apple's iPhone
column23: iPad
column24: Mac
column25: and other products segments   turning to year-over-year revenue declines recently
column26: the   company's services segment
column27: which includes sales from iTunes
column28: Apple Music
column29: the App Store
column30: iCloud
column31: Apple Pay
column32: licensing
column33: and   other services
column34: has continued to grow nicely. In Apple's most   recent quarter
column35: services revenue increased 24% year over   year.During Apple's earnings call
column36: investors should look to see if   Cook discusses how the company expects this segment to fair in   2017 and beyond. This question could come in many forms
column37: including:Does Apple expect Apple Music to evolve into a significant     driver for the company?Is growth for Apple Pay accelerating? Or has it leveled     off?Are there new services Apple could launch to continue     building out its services ecosystem?How significant of a role does Apple expect services to     play in the long-term?3. If there's a tax break for repatriation
column38: does Apple plan   to take advantage of it?Considering President Donald Trump's plan to offer a one-off   tax holiday for U.S. companies to repatriate their overseas funds   at a lower tax rate
column39: investors are interested in whether Apple   plans to take part in such a tax break
column40: and
column41: if it does
column42: to what   extent.Image source: Getty Images.Of Apple's enormous $238 billion cash hoard reported in the   company's fourth quarter
column43: a whopping $216 billion is held outside   of the Unite States. If Apple has aggressive plans for taking   advantage of this tax break
column44: the company could significantly   increase its dividend
column45: boost its share repurchase program
column46: pay   out a special dividend
column47: or even do all three.Investors can listen online to Apple's live conference call
column48: which can be found on the company's investor relations website
column49: on Tuesday
column50: Jan. 31
column51: at 2:00 p.m. PT.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column52: it can pay to listen. After all
column53: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column54: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column55: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Apple (AAPL) Earnings on Tap: iPhone
column5: 08:31:30 AM EDT;"Apple iPhone (Shutterstock photo)Apple (AAPL) is set to report first quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday. The Cupertino-based tech giant
column6: which has beaten Wall Street earnings per share estimates in two straight quarters
column7: is expected to break its streak of declining revenue at three. And the revenue increase will be driven by the barrage of new products Apple launched in the past three months.Notably
column8: Apples iPhone 7 and 7 Plus devices. Beyond the new line of MacBooks and iPads
column9: analysts may get a glimpse of the degree of demand Apple enjoyed for its wireless AirPods
column10: of which CEO Tim Cook in December hinted that Apple couldnt make them fast enough. Investors are also eager to learn how well Apples services business has performed.makeArticleAd();Apple earlier this month disclosed its App Storeexperienced a 40% year-over-year surgein revenue in 2016. Apple says on New Year's day alone
column11: customers spent nearly $240 million on apps and in-app purchases
column12: marking the App Store's largest single-day of sales ever. For that matter
column13: the App Store in December logged its highest-grossing month in its history
column14: generating some $3 billion in revenue. How much of that total trickled to the bottom line during the quarter remains to be seen.The company also said it posted a 74% surge in billings from subscription services like Netflix (NFLX)
column15: popular dating app Tinder and Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now
column16: reaching to $2.7 billion.Why is all of this important? Apple has increasingly emphasized the cash flow generated from its Services segment. The Services business
column17: which includes the App Store
column18: revenues from Apple Pay and Apple Music
column19: rose 24% in the fourth quarter
column20: posting revenue of $6.3 billion. This was preceded by a 19% rise in the third quarter.In other words
column21: Apple realizes it can not live by iPhones alone. Can it maintain the uptrend? On Tuesday analysts will scrutinize just how much closer Apple is to that reality. But for now
column22: the iPhone remains Apples cash cow. And
column23: beyond the headline earnings and revenue numbers
column24: thats where the focus will be. Despite fears about longer upgrade cycles
column25: increased competition and slow growth in emerging markets
column26: analysts are generally positive about the recantation the iPhone 7 has received.In the three months that ended December
column27: analysts expect Apple to report earnings per share of $3.23
column28: down from $3.28 in the year-earlier on revenue of revenue of $77.4 billion. This compares to Apple's guidance range of $76 billion to $78 billion when it last reported earnings in October. Analysts expect Apple to have sold 78 million iPhones
column29: which would be a 4% rise from the 75 million sold a year ago.Average selling prices
column30: meanwhile
column31: are projected to be $687 per unit
column32: down $735 a year ago. However
column33: thanks to prospect of higher shipments
column34: iPhone revenues are expected to rise 3% to $53.1 billion. Meanwhile
column35: data compiled by FactSet suggests Services revenue will reach $6.9 billion
column36: up 13% year over year. To the extent Apple can beat on both the top and bottom lines
column37: exceeds iPhone unit salesandprovide confident guidance
column38: Apple stock should continue to climb.Apple shares

column1: Amazon (AMZN) Film Division to Premiere Patriot on Feb 24;January 31
column4: Amazon Studios
column5: has scheduled the premiere of its original one-hour series
column6: Patriot
column7: on Feb 24.For now
column8: the series will be available for Prime members on Prime Video in the U.S.
column9: UK
column10: Germany and Austria. Later this year
column11: the show will be available on PrimeVideo.com for Prime Video members in more than 200 countries and territories.The series can be viewed via the Amazon Video app on TVs and connected devices like mobile
column12: Fire TV
column13: and online at Amazon.com/originals
column14: at no additional cost to prime membership.Over the last one year
column15: shares of Amazon have been steadily treading higher. The stock has returned 44.46% compared with the Electronic Commerce industry's gain of 41.77%.About the SeriesPatriot is based on the life story of intelligence officer John Tavner who makes efforts to prevent Iran from going nuclear. In the story
column16: Tavner will forgo all safety nets and assume a mid-level employee at a Midwestern industrial piping firm to complete his mission. However
column17: the federal government's incompetence and his own day job in an industrial piping company will put his mission in danger.The start cast includes Michael Dorman
column18: Terry O'Quinn
column19: Kurtwood Smith and Michael Chernus.The series will make its world premiere at the Berlin Film Festival Berlinale. It has been executive produced by Steven Conrad
column20: James Parriott
column21: Glenn Ficarra
column22: John Requa
column23: Charles Gogolak and Gil Bellows.Our TakeThe increasing popularity of tablets
column24: smartphones and web-connected TVs has enhanced online-video viewing and continues to attract consumers as well as leading technology companies
column25: like AlphabetGOOGLand Apple Inc.AAPL.Therefore
column26: Amazon is leaving no stone unturned to boost its digital media sales and attract new viewers
column27: by adding varied series and movies to its content lineup and making Prime Video more attractive.With intense competition in online video content
column28: majors such as Netflix
column29: Inc.NFLX
column30: Hulu and HBO
column31: are seeing substantial success. It is natural for Amazon to compete against them with successful acts of its own. These new shows are expected to help Amazon penetrate further into the growing streaming market
column32: at a rapid pace.Amazon.com

column1: 15 Best Short-Term Stock Investments;January 31
column3: 08:17:07 AM EDT;"As any stock trader can tell you
column4: the market can be volatile. That's why investment professionals typically recommend investors take a long-term approach to investing to reduce the risk of losing principal. If you invest at the wrong time
column5: you could lose a significant amount of your money overnight
column6: so keep in mind that stocks are not always the best short-term investments.That said
column7: stock prices work both ways. A prudent  or lucky  investor could make a great deal of money just as rapidly as he could lose it. If you have a tolerance for risk and are willing to do the research
column8: short-term trading might be a solution for at least part of your portfolio.If you decide to go this route
column9: don't hesitate to contact a financial professional if you need assistance. Most important
column10: if you're looking for stocks to buy now
column11: do your homework to find good ones in which to invest. You can begin here with this list of 15 stocks to buy that might be thebest short-term investments for your portfolio.makeArticleAd();1. Apple:AAPLApple is one of the best-known companies in America
column12: thanks in no small part to the iPhone. It's also the largest U.S. company in terms of market capitalization  the value of a company that's traded on the stock market  a number you can calculate by multiplying a company's stock price by the number of its outstanding shares. In the case of Apple
column13: this number topped $618 billion as of late December 2016
column14: coming in ahead of competitors Alphabet at $548 billion
column15: Microsoft at $494.6 billion
column16: Amazon at $366 billion and Facebook at $343.1 billion.Apple stock is positioned to move even higher in 2017. The company is aggressively buying back stock
column17: which reduces the number of outstanding shares and increases earnings per share. Its latest iPhones
column18: the 7 and 7 Plus
column19: are the best-selling phones in its history. Apple also holds roughly $200 billion in overseas cash
column20: which might move home this year if corporate taxes on repatriation are lowered. To top it all off
column21: the stock is trading at just about 10 times earnings.2. Gilead Sciences:GILDIf you're looking for a short-term stock that had a rough go of it in 2016
column22: Gilead Sciences might be your pick. The biotechnology company's sales of its hepatitis C drug declined and the stock fell 29 percent in 2016.Gilead could turn out to be one of the best stocks for 2017
column23: however. The company trades at the compelling valuation of 6.99 times estimated earnings over the next year. It's bought back 14 percent of its stock over the past three years
column24: and with its $32 billion cash hoard
column25: the company might continue to buy more or make strategic acquisitions. Gilead also uses its cash to pay out a 2.5 percent dividend to shareholders. The stock could very well hit $101 in 2017
column26: according to analysts at JP Morgan.3. Alphabet:GOOGAlphabet
column27: formerly known as Google
column28: is one of the world's great businesses
column29: according to Barron's. The company owns numerous products and services including Google Maps and Google Play
column30: YouTube
column31: Nest
column32: Chrome
column33: Android
column34: and Gmail. Analysts project 2017 revenues for the company in excess of $103 billion
column35: which would represent a growth rate of more than 18 percent.Given the current political climate
column36: Alphabet might see a short-term boost in the form of repatriated cash. The company currently holds about $80 billion in cash overseas
column37: which translates to around $115 per share. Additionally
column38: it has a lot of room for cost cutting because it spends freely on noncore businesses. Some analysts are estimating $41 per share in earnings this year
column39: which would be huge since the company currently trades at just 18 times earnings.4. Facebook:FBEven if you don't use Facebook at home or on your smartphone
column40: it's hard to avoid its presence in store windows or on advertising asking you to ""like"" something. The key to Facebook's financial success is its monetization of its enormous customer base. It has 1.79 billion monthly active users  and that number continues to rise. Lately
column41: Facebook's stock price has gone up and exceeded analyst earnings estimates by an average of 21.11 percent.Facebook is still investing in ways to grow its earnings even more
column42: with mobile ads and video revenues currently doing the heavy lifting. The company is also expecting big things out of its virtual reality investments. With a long-term growth rate of 27.6 percent
column43: the company is expected to continue its rise.5. Citigroup:CCitigroup could benefit from a number of factors in 2017
column44: including rising interest rates. TheFederal Reserve raised interest ratesfor just the second time in a decade in 2016. The Fed indicated that it expects to hike rates an additional three times in 2017. In response
column45: the two-year Treasury note hit its highest rate since 2009. When interest rates rise
column46: banks can charge more money on loans and credit cards
column47: potentially increasing their profitability.Citigroup's stock has lagged compared with its peers' so far in 2017
column48: which gives it room to catch up. The stock trades at just about 11 times its expected earnings for next year  and it trades at the widest discount-to-book value of the major banks. This means the stock is discounted more than 25 percent compared with the price-earnings ratios of its peers
column49: making it a possible value play.6. IBM:IBMIBM is another turnaround candidate for 2017. The company used to dominate the computer hardware and services business sector but has been surpassed in recent years by its competitors. However
column50: its slow turn toward the more modern businesses of artificial intelligence
column51: cloud computing
column52: mobility and security is showing signs of bearing fruit.The company spent more than $5 billion in acquisitions in 2016 alone
column53: and its new product lines now account for more than 40 percent of firm revenues. Its analytics division showed revenue growth of 16 percent
column54: and its cloud business jumped by 42 percent  both hopeful signs for future growth. IBM's artificial intelligence business has generated positive buzz thanks to its Watson cognitive system
column55: which is known for beating two human ""Jeopardy!"" contestants. The stock trades at a 12.19 price-earnings ratio based on expected 2017 earnings.7. Norwegian Cruise Line:NCLHNorwegian Cruise Line is poised to benefit from the rapidly growing cruise segment and could be one of the best stocks to buy now. With the core demographic of aging baby boomers on the rise
column56: cruise lines are a growing market. The company doesn't pay dividends to shareholders but reinvests its cash flow into building more ships and expanding its routes. Norwegian has already won approval to sail to Cuba
column57: and it has repositioned its calendar to deploy ships into the fast-growing Asian market for the first time in 15 years.Norwegian boasts the newest fleet among its major North American competitors
column58: making it attractive to customers looking for the latest and greatest offerings. The company owns a diversified portfolio of maritime brands including Oceania and Regent Seven Seas. Analysts estimate the stock will grow earnings by more than 18 percent in 2017  the stock trades at just 14 times 2017 estimates.8. Amazon:AMZNAmazon has grown from an online bookseller to the eighth-largest retailer in the world
column59: and it hasn't shown any signs of slowing down. Amazon will become the largest apparel seller in the U.S. by 2021
column60: when it will be selling $62 billion in apparel annually  more than TJ Maxx and Macy's combined  according to analysts at Cowen Group.Amazon is firing on multiple fronts: It's poised to capitalize on streaming media's popularity via its Amazon Prime subscription service. Additionally
column61: its Web Services business is more advanced than competitors Microsoft and Alphabet's cloud offerings
column62: thanks to it being first to market. Analysts at Evercore ISI Institutional Equities cite Amazon as the best internet stock for 2017. Excitement is also brewing over Amazon's latest foray into the grocery business
column63: Amazon Go. In true disruptor fashion
column64: Amazon's take on the grocery store is to use sensors rather than grocery clerks.9. Restoration Hardware:RHRestoration Hardware is a well-known
column65: luxury home furnishings brand that suffered through 2016. Its earnings fell and triggered a stock sell-off in which shares lost more than half their value. However
column66: the company has shown some signs of being a possible candidate for short-term traders. In its most recent quarter
column67: revenue actually rose 3 percent and beat analysts' estimates by more than $20 million. Earnings also beat Wall Street expectations by 4 cents per share.In addition to rebounding sales and earnings
column68: Restoration Hardware conducted an image makeover. Going forward
column69: the company will be called simply ""RH."" Additionally
column70: the company has launched a new
column71: RH Modern line. In an attempt to capitalize on a more current type of revenue stream
column72: RH is now offering annual memberships. As a result
column73: analysts peg the company's five-year earnings growth rate at 20.33 percent
column74: with earnings for the upcoming year jumping 61.27 percent.10. Toll Brothers:TOLToll Brothers is a leading luxury home builder
column75: a business that's been hit hard on many fronts. Although risks remain
column76: the fear of rising interest rates dampening homebuying activity has sent Toll Brothers stock to a bargain price. The company now trades at less than 10 times its anticipated 2017 earnings
column77: which are expected by some to rise 20 percent.Some concerns over the luxury condo market in New York City also hang over the stock
column78: but company reps indicate that earnings will hold up. With the stock seemingly priced for a worst-case scenario
column79: its valuation of about 1.2 times book value is compelling. If housing markets hold firm or interest rates don't rise dramatically
column80: Toll Brothers stock could prove surprising to those anticipating the worst.11. Deutsche Telekom:DTEGYDeutsche Telekom is a German stock that many investors might recognize as the former parent of U.S. T-Mobile. The company still owns a 65 percent stake in the independently traded T-Mobile  and that stock has been skyrocketing. Deutsche's core European telecom business trades at a discount compared with its peers  it fell by 13 percent in 2016  even though it's the leading wired and wireless operator in Germany. Sporting a nearly 4 percent yield
column81: some analysts describe the stock as undervalued.A takeover play might happen in 2017: Comcast has had its eye on T-Mobile as a potential purchase. T-Mobile might also make another attempt to merge with Sprint
column82: which could end up being a catalyst for Deutsche's stock. If everything falls into place
column83: a share price of $20 isn't inconceivable.12. Sprouts Farmers Market:SFMSprouts Farmers Market flies under the radar of many investors because it's not really a headline-making stock. This lack of publicity might work to its advantage
column84: however
column85: as more investors become aware of its potential. Sprouts is drawing customers from the growing natural and organic food segment  and it prices its goods below that of its notable peer
column86: Whole Foods Market. As a result
column87: some analysts see the company generating mid-teens earnings and revenue growth in the foreseeable future.The company is growing out of its base in the American Southwest and moving east
column88: growing 14 percent in square footage every year. Coupled with its favorable market segments
column89: Sprouts is generating positive cash flow and returning cash to shareholders via a stock buyback program. At 20.5 times estimated 2017 earnings
column90: the stock could be ready to move.13. Delta Air Lines:DALDelta Air Lines has greatly improved its financial performance but still trades at a typical airline multiple of about nine times estimated 2017 earnings. Since 2009
column91: Delta has worked to cut its debt in half. As a result
column92: it now has an investment grade rating from independent ratings service Moody's. To further entice shareholders
column93: Delta pays a 1.7 percent dividend and has aggressively repurchased stock.Delta management feels the stock should be valued more like a diversified industrial company
column94: which would dramatically raise its multiple
column95: and
column96: therefore
column97: its share price. If you need another short-term catalyst
column98: look at the company's free cash flow. Delta is a cash-flow machine  it generated $4.1 billion in cash flow in the last 12 months alone and put just 9.8 percent of that into dividend payments
column99: according to Forbes.14. Novartis:NVTSAnother value play for 2017 could be Novartis
column100: a Swiss diversified drug company and the world's biggest prescription drugmaker. The company's share price had a difficult 2016 but now trades at about 15 times next year's earnings. With a yield of about 3.75 percent
column101: Novartis has an analyst consensus price target of $87
column102: some $15 north of its current price.Part of what held Novartis back in 2016 was fear over the slow start of Entresto
column104: but some analysts think sales will soon accelerate and could go as high as $3 billion. Novartis also gets 25 percent of its sales from high-growth
column106: which makes it less dependent on the more mature U.S. drug market. The company's recent purchase of Encore Vision should also shore up its vision sales and further enable it to diversify its holdings.15. General Motors:GMGeneral Motors has been an integral part of the global auto industry for more than 100 years and has recently faced headwinds. Some market participants feel that global auto sales have peaked
column107: and concerns over themovement to electric vehicleshave held back GM stock. Whatever the reasons are
column108: General Motors currently trades at a low price-to-earnings ratio of 4.3. Even industry competitors  like Ford
column109: which trades at a ratio of 6.6
column111: which trades at 9.7 times  trade at higher multiples
column112: and GM's average price-earnings ratio over the past five years is 12.2.GM could move higher as the market appreciates its emerging electric and hybrid portfolio. Some analysts feel GM has the bankroll and technology to undersell rivals such as Tesla and perhaps even compete on quality at some point. GM stock began rallying at the end of 2016
column113: which leads some analysts to predict it could double in price over the next one or two years.Data is accurate as of Jan. 25
column114: 2017. This information is provided to you as a resource for informational purposes only. It is being presented without consideration of the investment objectives
column116: or financial circumstances of any specific investor and might not be suitable for all investors. Past performance is not indicative of future results. Investing involves risk
column117: including the possible loss of principal. This information is not intended to
column119: form a primary basis for any investment decision that you might make. Always consult your own legal
column121: or investment advisor before making any investment
column124: or financial planning considerations or decisions.This article was originally published on GOBankingRates.com.Plus:How to Protect Your Credit When Traveling on Vacation5 Tax Mistakes Made by Baby BoomersWhat You Can Buy With the Average Social Security Check"

column1: 3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earnings;January 31
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEven ifApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) weren't the biggest company in the world (as measured by market cap)
column5: its quarterly earnings reports would still arguably be the most-watched reports for any given earnings seasons. Not only are a wide swath of many other companies linked to Apple's success
column6: but AAPL stock itself is something of a barometer for the broad market.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleYet
column7: the last few quarterly earnings announcements have also raised questions
column8: not the least of which is whether or not iPhone-mania has run its course. The growth pace has been undeniably tapering off.That's going to be the hot button on Tuesday
column9: after the close
column10: when the Apple earnings report for its fiscal first quarter is due.Apple Earnings PreviewAs of the most recent look
column11: Apple isexpected to post earnings of $3.22 per shareon revenue of $77.42 billion for the quarter ending in December. The company itself had guided for Q1 revenue of between $77 and $78 billion. That bottom line would be a tad lower than the $3.28 per share of AAPL stock reported for the same quarter a year earlier
column12: though the top line would be up just a bit from the prior year's first fiscal quarter tally of $75.87 billion.Apple needs a strong showing on Tuesday. Although it has been a strong growth machine since unveiling the first iPhone a little over a decade ago
column13: per-share profits have been lower on a year-over-year basis in each of the prior three quarters. Ditto for revenue.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAAPL stock investors have been patient thus far
column14: giving CEO Tim Cook time to adjust to a maturing market. A shortfall and/or another quarter of shrinking numbers
column15: however
column16: may push those traders' patience over the edge.3 Things to Watch for AAPLNot that Apple doesn't have a myriad of things going on at any given time
column17: but for the most part
column18: investors tend to focus on what they perceive as the biggest three. The three items that will be doing most of the driving for AAPL stock after Tuesday's report are (in no particular order)iPhone 7 salesIt's the 800-pound gorilla in the room. Strong sales of the company's flagship device can cure all other ills
column19: but if sales of the company's most recent iteration of the iPhone fall short
column20: little else matters.Expectations are widely varied on this front too. Cowen & Co.thinks Apple sold 58.5 million units of the iPhone 7 last quarter
column21: while Drexel Hamilton believes Applesold 76 million iPhones- not just the iPhone 7 - during its fiscal Q1. The overall consensus
column22: though
column23: isan average of 77.3 million units. Presumably most of those are the 7 and 7 Plus models.Apps and Digital ContentWhile Apple used to be a hardware company that also happened to facilitate the purchase of smartphone apps
column24: music and video media
column25: digital content is increasingly becomingan important part of the revenue mixas saturation becomes a real issue.The company doesn't offer much in the way of expectations for how its revenue breaks down
column26: but we do know that in the previous quarter
column27: Apple enjoyed revenue of $6.3 billion for its ""Services"" division
column28: which is mostly made up of its video
column29: audio and apps arms. That was a 24% year-over-year improvement. That makes it thesecond-biggest category of product for Apple
column30: though it's still well behind the biggest - the iPhone.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock: New All-Time Highs or New Problems?AAPL is even mulling the creation ofits own original television shows and movies
column31: following in the footsteps of on-demand video rivalsNetflix
column32: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAmazon.com
column33: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Donald Trump AgendaIt remains to be seen to what extent
column34: if any
column35: it will be discussed within the Apple earnings report and conference call. Maybe it won't come up at all
column36: but there's no denying AAPL is one of the more vulnerable companies to President Donald Trump's policy plans.Not only might a strict foreign worker and immigration policy limit Apple's access to technical talent
column37: but much-discussed tariffs on Chinese-made imports could start a trade war that leaves Apple right in the middle of it. Not only does Apple sell products to Chinese consumers
column38: it relies on China to make many of the iPhone's key components.Bottom Line for AAPL StockWith a trailing P/E of 14.5
column39: Apple shares are priced fairly  maybe even undervalued. That's apt to be a large part of the reason the pros are collectively rating AAPL a bit better than a ""Buy"" right now (leaning toward a ""Strong buy."") That optimism
column40: though
column41: is a bit suspicious in light of the lackluster results we've seen for the prior three quarters. Apple is going to have to outperform most expectations if the stock's to build any further on the 34% gain it has mustered since May of last year.As of this writing
column42: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeThe post3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earningsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Isn't Qualcomm's Pain Intel's Gain?;January 30
column3: 09:28:00 PM EDT;"Shares ofQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) recently plunged to a multi-month low after the   chipmaker was hit by an FTCantitrust lawsuitin the U.S. andadditional lawsuitsfrom its longtime customerApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . Apple
column4: which exclusively used Qualcomm's   baseband modems in its iPhones between 2011 and 2016
column5: claims that   Qualcomm withheld $1 billion in rebate payments (compensation for   that deal) after it cooperated with Korean FTC regulators
column6: which   were probing Qualcomm.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();This strained relationship between the two tech giants sounds   like great news forIntel(NASDAQ: INTC)
column7: which started supplying Apple with modems for   the iPhone 7 after its exclusive deal with Qualcomm ended. The   reason is simple -- Apple could potentially buy all of its modems   from Intel if it severs its relationship with Qualcomm.But Intel shares barely budged after Apple sued Qualcomm
column8: and   only recently rallied following its fourth quarter earnings beat.   Let's take a closer look at why investors don't seem convinced   that Qualcomm's pain can generate significant gains for   Intel.Understanding Intel's mobile strategyIntel doesn't report its modem sales separately. They're   included in its massive Client Computing Group
column9: which includes PC   and mobile chips. The group was created in 2015 to divert   attention from the ongoing losses at its mobile division
column10: which   previously reported its results separately. Those losses were   caused by its generous subsidization of OEMs
column11: with co-marketing   agreements
column12: steep discounts
column13: and financial aid for using its   mobile Atom chipsets.By the timeIntel killed offmost of its mobile Atom chips last year
column14: the unit had spent   billions of dollars to capture just 1% of the market. Intel's   fatal mistakes are easy to see in retrospect -- it sold off its   ARM-based Xscale unit in 2006 to focus on x86 chips in 2006
column15: then   rejected Apple's offer to produce application processors for the   first iPhone.Since much of the Android market uses Qualcomm SoCs
column16: which   bundle baseband modems together with ARM-based processors
column17: Intel   realized that the Atom couldn't gain much ground in the mobile   market. Instead
column18: it had to develop modems for OEMs like Apple
column19: which developed their own ARM-based processors without integrated   modems.Image source: Apple.Why Intel investors aren't excitedThe problem with Intel is that it was likely negotiating terms   with Apple from a position of weakness
column20: due to its need to stay   relevant in the mobile market. Since Intel has a long record of   taking losses to gain market share in the mobile market
column21: it's   reasonable to assume that Intel sold its modems to Apple at very   favorable prices for the hardware maker.Last year
column22: Cowen & Co. analysts estimated that the deal   could  generate $1.5 billion in revenues for Intel -- which   would only equal 2.5% of its projected revenues this year. Even   if Apple dropped Qualcomm and doubled its orders from Intel
column23: that   growth wouldn't significantly offset Intel's sluggish growth in   PC and data center chips. Moreover
column24: those modems would likely   only generate low-margin revenues
column25: which wouldn't significantly   boost its bottom line growth.To make matters worse
column26: Apple throttled the speed of    Qualcomm modems in the iPhone 7 to match the slower speed   of the Intel modems. This indicates that Apple didn't choose   Intel chips because they could match Qualcomm's -- it likely only   did so to reduce Qualcomm's negotiating power. This means that   other OEMs that use stand-alone Qualcomm modems won't likely   switch over to Intel modems anytime soon. This misstep mirrors   Intel's failure in mobile application processors -- several OEMs   initially gave the Atom a chance
column27: but it was doomed by its   inability to match the power efficiency of ARM-based designs.What Intel investors should expectIntel investors shouldn't assume that Apple's battle with   Qualcomm indicates that the two longtime partners will part ways   anytime soon. Apple andSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) have been suing each other for years
column28: yet the   Korean tech giant is still one of its top suppliers. Therefore
column29: Apple is likely trying to get Qualcomm to lower its chip prices   and licensing fees instead of completely parting ways with the   chipmaker.Even if Apple abandoned Qualcomm
column30: investors shouldn't assume   that Intel will inherit the entire modem business. Apple often   splits component orders from multiple manufacturers
column31: and it has   enough resources to develop its own modems -- which would cut   both Intel and Qualcomm out of the loop.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column34: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column36: 2017Leo Sunowns shares of Qualcomm. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Intel. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: How Much Can Apple's Services Drive Profit Growth?;January 30
column3: 06:11:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.Much has been made ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) services revenue over the last year or so. After   it was clear Apple would struggle to continue growing iPhone   sales following the outstanding success of the iPhone 6
column4: CEO Tim   Cook commented that a ""growing portion of our revenue is directly   driven by our existing install base."" That is
column5: sales of apps
column6: content
column7: iCloud
column8: Apple Care
column9: and other Apple Services will   account for an outsized portion of Apple's revenue growth going   forward.makeArticleAd();To be clear
column10: Apple is still very much a hardware company.   Apple's services revenue accounted for just 11% of Apple's total   sales in fiscal 2016. The iPhone
column11: by comparison
column12: made up 63% of   revenue. But services revenue grew 22% last year
column13: faster than any   other segment.With stalling hardware sales growth
column14: investors may be   wondering if growing services revenue is enough to move the   needle on Apple's bottom line.All about the marginsDespite its relatively small size
column15: Apple's services business   generates higher margins than its hardware sales. That's simply   the nature of software
column16: which sees wider margins as products   reach scale. And very few companies have the scale of Apple; the   company has over 1 billion devices in use.Apple's App Store sales have a gross margin of about 90%
column17: according to estimates from Macquarie Securities analyst Ben   Schachter. Overall
column18: he estimates the rest of Apple's services   have a gross margin of 65%. That means Apple's services revenue   has a gross margin about twice as large as its hardware   sales.Importantly
column19: the App Store -- Apple's highest-margin product   -- is one of the fastest-growing pieces of Apple's services. Last   year
column20: App Store revenueclimbed over 33%. Schachter expects it to climb 28% on average over the next five   years while non-App Store services grow just 10% annually. That   means Apple's services margin will continue to expand.How it all impacts Apple's gross profitEven if hardware sales remain flat
column21: that won't prevent Apple   from expanding its install base. As Cook mentioned in the   company's first-quarter earnings call last year
column22: ""Because of the   enduring value of the device
column23: their replacing is likely higher to   be given or sold to someone who will also love and use it often.""   In other words
column24: even if Apple isn't selling more devices directly   to consumers
column25: the user base can grow through third-party resales   or gifting.A growing user base combined with growing service sales per   unit ought to continue driving revenue growth for the segment for   several more years.A dollar in sales growth from services will carry twice the   gross profit
column26: on average
column27: as a dollar in sales growth of Apple's   hardware. So
column28: even though services is a relatively small business   right now
column29: it outpunches its weight class
column30: providing   approximately 21% of gross profits in 2016. That number is set to   expand as more of Apple's sales growth comes from services.As an illustration of the impact of Apple's service revenue   growth
column31: a 20% increase in services revenue in fiscal 2017 would   result in about a 4% increase in the company's total gross profit   and a 70 basis point expansion in gross margin if all else   remains equal. Considering the size of Apple
column32: that's pretty   significant growth. Schachter estimates Apple's gross margin will   expand as much as 400 basis points over the next five years.Gross margin expansion combined with modest revenue growth and   share buybacks should continue to boost Apple's earnings per   share at a fairly steady pace. Analysts expect 13.8% EPS growth   over the next five years
column33: but there could be even more upside   depending on how much margins expand. With shares trading at a   price-to-earnings ratio of just 14.4
column34: shares may still be   undervalued if Apple can maintain hardware sales and continue   growing services revenue as expected.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is the Bar Higher for the Q4 Earnings Season?;January 30
column3: 03:56:00 PM EDT;"Even as Earnings growth appears to have improved notably relative to the last couple of years
column4: positive surprises appear hard to come to by. This becomes evident from looking at the proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates in the ongoing Q4 earnings season. You can see that in the comparison chart below that compares the proportion of Q4 companies beating EPS and revenue estimates with what this same group of companies reported in the preceding quarter
column5: as well as the 4-quarter and 12-quarter averages.With results from 171 S&P 500 index members already out or 34.1% of the index's total membership
column6: positive surprises are tracking below historical periods
column7: particularly with respect to EPS surprises. If we see this trend continue in the coming days as the rest of Q4 reports come in
column8: then it would mean that estimates likely hadn't dropped enough ahead of the start of this earnings season. In other words
column9: the bar may have been bit higher this time around relative to other recent quarters.makeArticleAd();With respect to the Q4 earnings season scorecard
column10: we now have results from 171 S&P 500 members that have reported as of January 30th. Total earnings for these 171 index members are up +6% from the same period last year on +3.1% higher revenues
column11: with 64.3% beating EPS estimates and 54.4% beating revenue estimates. We discussed earlier how the proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates has been tracking below historical periods. But we don't have that issue on the growth front
column12: with both earnings and revenue growth tracking above other historical periods for the same group of 171 index members.The chart below shows how the Q4 earnings and revenue growth rate for these 171 companies compare with other recent periods.The Finance sector is a big contributor to the aggregate growth picture at this stage. For the Finance sector
column13: we now have Q4 results from 57.9% of the sector's total market cap in the S&P 500 index. Total earnings for these Finance sector companies are up +11.3% from the same period last year on +3.1% higher revenues
column14: with 67.5% beating EPS estimates and 45% beating revenue estimates. Excluding the Finance sector from the results thus far
column15: total earnings for the rest of the S&P 500 companies that have reported would be up +3.9% from the same period last year on +3% higher revenues. This is still better growth than we have seen from the same group of ex-Finance S&P 500 members
column16: as the comparison chart below shows.Looking at Q4 as a whole
column17: combining the actual results from the 171 index members that have reported results with estimates from the still-to-come 329 companies
column18: total earnings for the S&P 500 index are expected to be up +5.3% from the same period last year on +4% higher revenues. Excluding the Finance sector
column19: the Q4 earnings growth drops to +1% on +4.2% higher revenues.For the Technology sector
column20: total Q4 earnings are expected to be up +5.9% from the same period last year on +4.4% higher revenues.Apple(AAPL)
column21: which alone brings in roughly a quarter of the sector's total earnings
column22: is expected to report -7.8% lower earnings on +0.4% higher revenues as it comes out with its quarterly results after the close on Tuesday January 31st. Excluding the Apple drag
column23: total Q4 earnings for the rest of the Tech sector would be up +11.4% on +5.5% higher revenues.Facebook(FB)
column24: which reports after the market's close on Wednesday February 1st
column25: doesn't carry as much weight in the sector as the iPhone maker. But Facebook's Q4 earnings are expected to be up +91% from the same period last year on +44.5% higher revenues.Amazon(AMZN) isn't technically a Technology stock (it's a retailer)
column26: but it is also expected to show strong growth in its quarterly report that comes out after the close on Thursday February 2nd.Looking beyond Q4
column27: the growth pace is expected to ramp up notably in the current and following quarters
column28: as the chart below shows.As you can see
column29: total 2017 Q1 earnings for the S&P 500 index are currently expected to be up +8.7% from the same period last year. The chart below shows Q1 earnings growth expectations have evolved over the last few weeks.It is not unusual for 2017 Q1 estimates to be coming down at this stage of the 2016 Q4 reporting cycle
column30: but a lot will depend on the pace and magnitude of these negative revisions in the coming days. At this stage
column31: Q1 estimates aren't falling by as much as has historically been the case. This should add to confidence in market expectations for the following quarters when growth is expected to really ramp up.Note: Note: Sheraz Mian regularly provides earnings analysis on Zacks.com and appears frequently in the print and electronic media. His weekly earnings related articles includeEarnings TrendsandEarnings Preview. If you want an email notification each time Sheraz publishes a new article

This wide range for potential   net sales growth for the quarter will likely have many investors   watching the important holiday quarter's revenue.Analysts are betting Amazon's sales for the quarter will fall   at the high end of management's guidance
