column1: 3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great Recession;January 30
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTheS&P 500has more than tripled since it hit its low point of the Great Recession on March 9
column5: 2009. There were plenty of stocks to buy back then that offered incredible value. For investors that weren't old enough or didn't have the resources to invest back then
column6: it may seem like you've missed the boat. After all
column7: the old investing adage is to buy low and sell high.makeArticleAd();Source:PixabayAlmost every stock worth owning has a much higher share price now than it did on the day the S&P 500 bottomed in 2009
column8: but just because share prices were lower back in 2009 doesn't necessarily mean that buyers were getting a better deal.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAs the stock market has risen
column9: so have corporate earnings. Even though investors are now paying more for each share of stock
column10: they are also getting more earnings bang for their buck. Here's a look at three stocks that are a better value today than they were on March 9
column11: 2009.Stocks to Buy: Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS)Source:Erik DrostGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS) was right in the eye of the Great Recession storm. The company even received a $10 billion bailout from the government during the meltdown.In the years since the crisis
column12: new regulations and capital requirements severely hindered bank earnings. For GS stock
column13: the heaviest weight has been the Volcker Rule. The Volcker Rule is a provision in the Dodd-Frank Act that prevents banks from performing certain types of speculative trading.Despite the regulatory headwinds
column14: GS has found a way to ramp up its earnings in recent years. Goldman's net income is up more than 180% since 2009
column15: making GS stock an even better value today than it was back then. Goldman's current price-to-earnings ratio is only 14.2
column16: 19% lower than it was on March 9
column17: 2009.Looking ahead
column18: Donald Trump has pledged to eliminate many of the regulations that have been holding back the big banks. Goldman stock is in an even better position and it is a better value today than it was in the years following the Great Recession.Stocks to Buy: Visa Inc (V)Source:K rlis Dambr ns via FlickrThe market forVisa Inc(NYSE:V) is dramatically changing. While mobile competition fromPayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL)
column19: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others may certainly disrupt the traditional payment business
column20: Visa should be just fine. A recentBI Intelligencereport concluded that merchant service providers (MSPs) are much more threatened by mobile payment competition than the credit card companies themselves.The proof is in the pudding. Even with the emergence of platforms like Apple Pay
column21: Visa's profits have exploded more than 400% since 2009. BMO Capital analystPaulo Ribeiroexpects Visa's double-digit earnings growth to continue in the long-term. He believes V stock will continue to benefit from the slow death of cash and check payments.7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeEven though V stock has been a top performer in the market since the Great Recession
column22: that incredible earnings growth means Visa's P/E ratio is down 60% from where it was when the market bottomed in 2009. In other words
column23: V stock is a much better value today than it was back then.Stocks to Buy: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. ( BRK.B)Source:Pete Souza via Wikimedia (Modified)If you're looking for stocks to buy in the market today that would make 2009 investors envious
column24: it doesn't get much better thanBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column25: NYSE:BRK.B). The holding company of the most iconic and successful value investor of all time is currently trading at a better value than it was during the Great Recession.Warren Buffett's BRK.B stock now has a P/E of 17
column26: which is down roughly 21% since March 9
column27: 2009. Buffett and Berkshire have done very well since the Great Recession. But thanks to BRK.B's 823% income growth
column28: investors now get a better value for Berkshire shares than they did at the market bottom.If anyone can find value in the stock market after it climbs 235% in eight years
column29: it's the Oracle of Omaha. Instead of losing sleep over stocks to buy with the market at an all-time high
column30: why not just invest in Buffett? Unlike high school
column31: there's no penalty for cheating off of the smart kid's paper.As of this writing
column32: Wayne Duggan did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The post3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great Recessionappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 6 Reasons Why Investors Should Take A Bite Into Apple;January 30

column54: $11.12 billion

column1: Apple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL);January 30
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) first introduced its new
column5: big and bigger smartphones - the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus - the company opted to offer a few minor features for buyers of the largest model. The 6 Plus had longer battery life
column6: and an image stabilized camera. That basic strategy continued with the 6s Plus in 2015. But last year with the iPhone 7 Plus
column7: AAPL included a more significant carrot in the signature Dual Camera feature.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThe move of making a key feature exclusive to its larger phones appears to have paid off with a big increase in iPhone 7 Plus sales compared to regular iPhone 7 sales.Having more of the costlier iPhone 7 Plus models in the mix means AAPL can generate more revenue
column8: even if overall unit sales are soft.Differentiating Between Big and BiggerHistorically
column9: the larger-sized iPhone hasn't sold nearly as well as the ""standard"" 4.7-inch model.When AAPL first introduced the two model strategy in 2014
column10: the iPhone 6 Plus had an immediate bump in demand from Apple fans who were hungry for a phablet. It was also very popular in Asian markets
column11: where phablets
column12: which can take the place of both smartphone and tablet
column13: are often preferred. However
column14: overall the bigger and more expensive iPhone 6 Plus only accounted foraround 20% of overall iPhone salesglobally.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatIn 2015
column15: AAPL added a little more appeal to the bigger iPhone
column16: adding increased RAM to the optically image stabilized camera for the iPhone 6 Plus. However
column17: that saw just a small uptick in sales of the bigger model.Last year
column18: Apple rolled the dice: It decided to release a dual camera smartphone
column19: a premium upgrade that it heavily promoted as a must-have feature. With this advanced camera system
column20: users could take DSLR-like portraits and optically zoom in on subjects. AAPL made this key feature an iPhone 7 Plus exclusive
column21: at the same time boosting the price of its larger iPhone. Previously
column22: it had charged $649 and $749 respectively for the two sizes. In 2016
column23: the company still started the iPhone 7 at $649
column24: but to get the dual camera smartphone feature required shelling out at least $769 for the iPhone 7 Plus.iPhone 7 Sales See Big Increase in iPhone 7 Plus AdoptionTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Apple's iPhone 7 Plus strategy appears to have paid off. Citing numbers from Cowen & Co. UBS
column25: Cowen and Creative Strategies Inc.
column26: theWSJsays that in AAPL's first quarter (ending in December)
column27: theiPhone 7 Plus is estimated to have accounted for 40% of total iPhone 7 sales
column28: globally.Breaking the numbers down regionally
column29: it's estimated that 52% of Chinese iPhone buyers opted for the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus
column30: while in the U.S. it accounted for 47% of total iPhone 7 sales.Why Increased iPhone 7 Plus to iPhone 7 Sales MatterThe difference between the two iPhone models is material to AAPL's bottom line.Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL)It's likely that the iPhone 7 Plus costs Apple more to manufacture than previous Plus versions - it does have more RAM
column31: a larger battery and that dual camera system - but at least some of the additional cost is offset by the boost from $749 to $769.The profit margin for Apple on the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus probably remains roughly the same. However
column32: with a base price that's $120 higher
column33: having more Plus models in the mix means that even if overall iPhone 7 sales are soft
column34: the average selling price of a new iPhone goes up. As a result
column35: iPhone revenue could get a boost
column36: despite sales that may not meet expectations.And
column37: as theWSJarticle points out
column38: there's another positive point for AAPL in the iPhone 7 Plus numbers. The fact that pricing the iPhone 7 Plus so high still resulted in big gains for the premium smartphone bodes well for later this year when the company will release the10th anniversary iPhone 8. The iPhone 7 sales numbers indicate that AAPL has additional room to price the iPhone 8 as an ultra-premium
column39: special edition model if it chooses.As of this writing
column40: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postApple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: AAPL Is Taking Down Apps from Iranian Developers;January 30
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of apps from Iranian developers being taken down. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleIranian Apps:Apple has started taking down apps from the App Store that are made by developers in Iran
column6: AppleInsidernotes. The tech company doesn't operate an App Store in Iran
column7: but it has been allowing citizens in the country to use the American version of the app. This resulted in several apps from Iranian developers making it onto the American App Store. However
column8: the company is now pulling those apps from the App Store. This is likely due to Iranian Transactions Sanctions Regulations (31CFR Part 560)
column9: which limits trade with the country.watchOS 3.2 Beta:AAPL is now letting developers play with the first watchOS 3.2 beta
column10: reportsMacRumors. This new beta includes features that will likely be coming to the device when watchOS 3.2 gets a final release. The beta includes the new Theater mode that previous patch notes from AAPL have mentioned. This feature silences the device for movie watch. It also includes SiriKit
column11: which lets users have Siri perform tasks without taking out their connected iPhone devices.UltraFine Display:There are problems with the new LG UltraFine 5K Display that Apple recommends to MacBook Pro users
column12: 9to5Macnotes. The problem affecting the LG UltraFine 5K Display has to do with routers. When the device is within a 2 meters of a router
column13: it will become unstable. This problem can cause the display to flicker and not work properly. AAPL andLGworked together on the monitor. LG is aware of the issue and is advising customers not to use the displays within 2 meters of a router.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: AAPL Is Taking Down Apps from Iranian Developersappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) andUnder Armour Inc(NYSE:UAA) are all reporting their latest quarterly numbers this week - and all investors should be paying attention.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatLet's take a look at what's in store for these picks.Earnings to Watch:Apple (AAPL)Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrApple

column13: will report earnings on Tuesday after the market close.The tech giant is looking to notch its third straight earnings beat-although a beat would still translate to an earnings decline. Wall Street is expecting $3.22 per share compared to last year's $3.28 per share
column14: and that fall is despite expectations for a slight uptick in revenue.Apple has suffered several straight quarters of falling sales
column15: but analysts expect a strong holiday season driven by the iPhone 7 to return the company to organic growth. Even if that growth is meager and earnings shrink slightly
column16: I expect investors to be pleased.Remember
column17: Apple is no longer the growth darling it once was. But 20% gains over the last year plus a solid dividend make a pretty strong case for the stock. I think investors will be reminded of the new Apple's appeal when earnings are released tomorrow.Earnings to Watch:Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrAdvanced Micro Devices is another company that doesn't have too much growth in its near-term forecast despite sales growth. Oftentimes
column18: companies fail to grow sales
column19: but still manage to grow earnings thanks to cost savings or accounting tricks.But in the case of AMD
column20: the loss per share is expected to be a penny worse than it was a year ago due to higher costs and despite double-digit sales growth.The pain isn't expected to end after this quarter either; the full-year earnings forecast is also in the red. But I do like AMD's long-term prospects
column21: as it's introduced new products and inked new partnerships and deals
column22: including one withAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column23: NASDAQ:GOOGL.7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayIf AMD happens to get battered after its earnings report Tuesday
column24: I wouldn't hesitate to buy some shares on the cheap.Earnings to Watch:Under Armour (UAA)Source: ShutterstockUnder Armour is the only stock on this list that has earnings growth on-tap for the current quarter. And while the 4% growth Wall Street expects isn't that mind-blowing
column25: it's a fraction of the growth that's expected down the road.Full-year earnings are expected to enjoy 13% year-over-year growth
column26: while the five-year average is expected to top 20%. Meanwhile
column27: sales growth is also expected to come in north of 20% and stay there in quarters to come.So far
column28: UAA stock has been battling some headwinds: Shares are currently right at their 50-day moving average and are under the 200-day. A good earnings report could be the catalyst needed to turn that long-term average to a floor instead of a ceiling.Under Armour stock also reports on Tuesday.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: What to Expect When Cirrus Logic Inc. Reports Earnings This Wednesday;January 30
column3: 11:34:00 AM EDT;"Image Source: Cirrus LogicWhen audio codec supplierCirrus Logic(NASDAQ: CRUS) releases its fiscal 2017 third quarter results on   Feb. 1
column4: investors can expect another period of rapid growth from   the company. Cirrus Logic has benefited fromApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) decision to remove the headphone jack from the   latest generation of iPhones
column5: leading to strong sales of its   wireless headset solutions. This should drive a strong quarterly   performance at Cirrus
column6: but the company's over-dependence on Apple   for 78% of its revenue could be a deal-breaker as far as the   broad investor outlook is concerned.makeArticleAd();Apple will drive strong growth for Cirrus in the third     quarter . . .Cirrus expects to post third quarter revenue of $475 million   to $515 million with a gross margin of 48%. The midpoint of this   guidance puts its year-over-year growth at an impressive 42%
column7: which is not surprising given the content gains that Cirrus has   witnessed in the iPhone 7.A teardown of the latest smartphone by Chipworks revealed that   the device uses three audio amplifiers from Cirrus
column8: as compared   to two in the iPhone 6S. Now
column9: the actual device is not the only   place where Cirrus is going to make money. iFixit's X-ray of the   Lightning-to-3.5mm adapter
column10: used to connect legacy headphones to   the iPhone 7
column11: reveals the presence of audio codecs from Cirrus as   well.What's more
column12: Cirrus has also supplied digital-to-analog   converter chips for the Lightning EarPods
column13: according to a   teardown of the device by the Vietnamese site Tinhte. All of this   indicates that Cirrus has received a serious bump in its chip   content at Apple. In fact
column14: Pacific Crest Securities forecasts   additional content gains of $2.50 for Cirrus Logic with the   iPhone 7
column15: including the Lightning EarPods and the second stereo   speaker.Encouraged by the booming business
column16: Cirrus seems to have   directed most of its manufacturing capacity toward making chips   for the iPhone and related accessories. This is why revenue from   its largest customer shot up to 78% of total sales in the July to   September quarter
column17: when iPhone production was being ramped up
column18: as   compared to 63% in the year-ago period.iPhone orders from suppliers for the December quarter   reportedly stood at 89 million units. Now
column19: the iPhone 7 and 7   Plus won't account for 100% of Apple's device sales. To provide   some perspective
column20: sales of these two models reportedly made up   72% of total iPhone sales in the U.S. in the fourth quarter
column21: according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners.Assuming that 72% of the 89 million iPhone unit orders Apple   placed in the fourth quarter were for the two new devices
column22: that   would account for approximately 64 million units. Multiplying   this estimated unit count by additional content gains of $2.50   for each device
column23: Cirrus revenue would increase by $160 million   from the prior-year period when it reported total revenue of $348   million.This alone puts Cirrus revenue at about $508 million for the   fiscal third quarter
column24: which falls at the higher end of its   guidance range. But apart from the dollar content gains
column25: Cirrus will also benefit from the production of an additional   nine million iPhone units as compared to the Dec. 2015 quarter
column26: when estimated volume stood at 80 million. Therefore
column27: Cirrus is   poised to outperform even the higher end of its guidance   range.. . . but hurt its longer term outlookHowever
column28: Cirrus Logic's outlook could prove to be a problem as   iPhone production in the first calendar quarter of 2017 is   expected to decline to about 42 million units
column29: as indicated by aUBSreport. Earlier
column30: Apple was expected to produce 43 million iPhones   during the period
column31: but it has reportedly downsized production in   order to avoid an inventory glut.Assuming the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus maintain a 72% share of   overall production
column32: these two devices will account for   approximately 30 million units in the current quarter. With the   $2.50 per unit of additional content
column33: the new devices will add   $75 million to Cirrus' top line in the fiscal fourth quarter.To factor in the lower production volume
column34: iPhone builds in the   year-ago quarter stood at an estimated 55 million units. This   puts the anticipated year-over-year decline in volume at 13   million units. Assuming that the production cut pertains to the   older iPhone 6S
column35: Cirrus' revenue could drop by as much as $45   million since it was making $3.50 on each unit of the prior   generation device.Therefore
column36: the revenue gains from the iPhone 7 will be reduced   to just $30 million after accounting for the decline in overall   production. This indicates that Cirrus could post sales of   approximately $262 million in the fiscal fourth quarter as its   revenue in the prior-year period was $232 million. Barring major   gains in other business areas
column37: Wall Street analyst estimates   of between $312 million and $350 million in fiscal fourth   quarter revenue will be tough to beat.This tough outlook could lead to a potential sell-off since   investors will consider booking profits as Cirrus Logic shares   have already doubled in the past year. Investors can find out   more when the company reports after the close this Wednesday.10 stocks we like better than Cirrus LogicWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cirrus Logic wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column42: 2017Harsh Chauhanhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Cirrus Logic. column1: Can Apple (AAPL) be a Suitable Value Pick at the Moment?;January 30
column3: 09:55:00 AM EDT;"Value investing is easily one of the most popular ways to find great stocks in any market environment. After all
column4: who wouldn't want to find stocks that are either flying under the radar and are compelling buys
column5: or offer up tantalizing discounts when compared to fair value?makeArticleAd();One way to find these companies is by looking at several key metrics and financial ratios
column6: many of which are crucial in the value stock selection process. Let's putApple Inc.AAPLstock into this equation and find out if it is a good choice for value-oriented investors right now
column7: or if investors subscribing to this methodology should look elsewhere for top picks:PE RatioA key metric that value investors always look at is the Price to Earnings Ratio
column8: or PE for short. This shows us how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of earnings in a given stock
column9: and is easily one of the most popular financial ratios in the world. The best use of the PE ratio is to compare the stock's current PE ratio with: a) where this ratio has been in the past; b) how it compares to the average for the industry/sector; and c) how it compares to the market as a whole.On this front
column10: Apple has a trailing twelve months PE ratio of 14.75. This level compares favorably with the market at large
column11: as the PE ratio for the S&P 500 comes in at about 20.11.If we focus on the long-term PE trend
column12: Apple's current PE level puts it slightly above its midpoint over the past five years
column13: with the number having risen rapidly over the past few months. Hence
column14: this does not provide us with a conclusive direction as to the relative valuation of the stock in comparison to its own historical trend.Meanwhile
column15: the stock's PE compares favorably with the Zacks classified Computer & Technology sector's trailing twelve months PE ratio
column16: which stands at 22.08. At the very least
column17: this indicates that the stock is relatively undervalued right now
column18: compared to its peers.We should also point out that Apple has a forward PE ratio (price relative to this year's earnings) of just 13.70
column19: so it is fair to say that a slightly more value-oriented path may be ahead forApple stockin the near term too.P/S RatioAnother key metric to note is the Price/Sales ratio. This approach compares a given stock's price to its total sales
column20: where a lower reading is generally considered better. Some people like this metric more than other value-focused ones because it looks at sales
column21: something that is far harder to manipulate with accounting tricks than earnings.Right now
column22: Apple has a P/S ratio of about 3.05. This is a bit higher than the Computer & Technology sector's average
column23: which comes in at 2.96 right now. In fact
column24: over the last year
column25: Apple's figure has been quite close to the sector's average
column26: as we can see in the chart below:However
column27: the current level lies near to the median of the stock's own historical trend (which stands at 2.93). This again does not provide us with any conclusive direction as to the relative valuation of the stock in comparison to its own trend.Broad Value OutlookIn aggregate
column28: Apple currently has a Zacks Value Style Score of 'B'
column29: putting it into the top 40% of all stocks we cover from this look. This makes Apple a solid choice for value investors
column30: and some of its other key metrics make this pretty clear too.For example
column31: the PEG ratio for Apple is just 1.20
column32: a level that is far lower than the industry average of 5.06. The PEG ratio is a modified PE ratio that takes into account the stock's earnings growth rate. Clearly
column33: AAPL is a solid choice on the value front from multiple angles.What About the Stock Overall?Though Apple might be a good choice for value investors
column34: there are plenty of other factors to consider before investing in this name. In particular
column35: it is worth noting that the company has a Growth grade of 'D' and a Momentum score of 'F'. This gives AAPL a Zacks VGM score-or its overarching fundamental grade-of 'D'. (You can read more about the Zacks Style Scoreshere >>)Meanwhile
column36: the company's recent earnings estimates have been trending downwards slightly. The current quarter has seen one estimate go higher in the past sixty days compared to three lower
column37: while the full year estimate has seen one upward revision and eight downward revisions in the same time period.This has had just a small impact on the consensus estimate though as the current quarter consensus estimate has inched lower by 0.3% in the past two months
column38: while the full year estimate has declined nearly 2%. You can see the consensus estimate trend and recent price action for the stock in the chart below:Apple Inc. Price and ConsensusApple Inc. Price and Consensus|Apple Inc. QuoteThis somewhat dull trend is why the stock has just a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) and why we are looking for in-line performance from the company in the near term.Bottom LineApple forms a part of the Zacks Computer-Mini industry. The industry is highly competitive and thus Apple faces significant competition in most of its operating markets from respective segment leaders like Hewlett-Packard
column39: Google
column40: Samsung
column41: etc. Moreover
column42: the demand for high-end devices has been soft recently
column43: owing to global macroeconomic weakness
column44: especially with currency volatility and declining commodity prices in some key regions across the globe.In fact
column45: over the past two years
column46: the Zacks Computer-Mini industry has clearly underperformed the broader market
column47: as you can see below:Apple is an inspired choice for value investors
column48: as it is hard to beat its incredible lineup of statistics on this front. However
column49: with a sluggish industry rank (Bottom 14% out of more than 250 industries) and a Zacks Rank #3
column50: it is hard to get too excited about this company overall.So
column51: value investors might want to wait for estimates and analyst sentiment to turn bullish in this name first
column52: but once that happens
column53: this stock could be a compelling pick.Zacks' Top Investment Ideas for Long-Term ProfitHow would you like to see our best recommendations to help you find today's most promising long-term stocks? Starting now

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Microsoft
column4: Alphabet and Intel;January 30
column6: 09:30:00 AM EDT;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column7: IL - January 30
column8: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column9: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column10: Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column11: Alphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) andIntel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report).Today
column12: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This QuarterAnalysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column13: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column14: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column15: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column16: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column17: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column18: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) for one has strongly resisted government demands as have Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report). Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report); networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column19: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column20: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column21: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column22: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column23: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column24: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column25: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column26: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column27: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column28: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column29: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter
column30: that's nearly up by a billion dollars and will mostly be spent on data centers to support its cloud business.Now See Our Private Investment IdeasWhile the above ideas are being shared with the public

column13: click here.Earnings Growth Returns. Will It Continue?Corporate earnings have started growing again

Growth is still modest - the Q4 earnings growth is currently on track to reach +5.2% and the final growth tally for the quarter will at best be a couple of percentage points higher. column24: with 64.1% beating EPS estimates and 54.7% coming ahead of top-line expectations.The Q4 growth pace is notably tracking above what we had seen from the same group of 170 index members in other recent periods. But positive surprises are tracking on the low side at this stage

column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) enters this week's fourth-quarter earnings report in a peculiar position: Despite the fact that FB stock is trading near all-time highs
column5: Facebook absolutely has something to prove.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's because FB has spent the past three months recovering from a rough Q3 report that sent the stock to one of its biggest dips since coming public in 2012. While the company reported a strong earnings beat
column6: Facebook CFO warned about a slowdown in revenue growth for Q4
column7: and said ad load might ""come down meaningfully"" in the second half of this year.The news sparked a selloff from which Facebook wouldn't really recover until the start of 2017. But recover it has - FB stock is up roughly 15% in the past month to trade near all-time highs around $113.So
column8: what's in store for Facebook this time around?If you believe Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald

column10: and expects Q4 revenues to grow 46% year-over-year to $8.54 billion - slightly ahead of Wall Street's broader estimates for $8.5 billion. He also projects GAAP profits of $1.05

column12: bottom-funnel ad units like DPAs
column13: and Live video

column1: Heres How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its Throne;January 30
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has its day of reckoning fast approaching. Tim Cook has turned out to be a game manager for AAPL stock. That's not a slight against him
column5: but a game manager comes in when your first-string QB is out for a quarter or two. The problem is that Apple needs a visionary. There's no replacing Steve Jobs
column6: and being a game manager in a sector that moves like lightning is not what the company needs.makeArticleAd();Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrAAPL stock generates almost 70% of revenue from the iPhone
column7: and that product is seeing increasing competition.The good news is that Apple has well over $200 billion in cash and investments. It can literally do anything it wants. The problem is that most of that cash is stuck overseas - although that may change under Trump - and what Cook might do with that cash is a mystery.Without a vision
column8: Apple would probably have to make acquisitions in rapidly growing companies. However
column9: there is one other area that AAPL stock can venture into
column10: one that I've been saying it must get into: original content.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018News has surfaced that AAPL is finally looking seriously at creating original TV and film content. For years
column11: Apple has begged off of this direction. It seemed content to play around with music streaming
column12: and licensing content from other providers for iTunes.TheWSJreported:""The technology giant has been in talks with veteran producers in recent months about buying rights to scripted television programs. It also has approached experienced marketing executives at studios and networks to discuss hiring them to promote its content
column13: said people with knowledge of the discussions. In addition to TV
column14: Apple indicated to these people that it is considering offering original movies
column15: though those plans are more preliminary. Executives at Apple have told people in Hollywood they hope to start offering original scripted content by the end of 2017.""The apple is ripe for AAPL to get involved
column16: and in a very big way. We've seen thatNetflix
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) has shifted its model toward original programming and is producing really great stuff. So isAmazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). YouTube Red
column19: though
column20: is kind of floundering right now.One thing people want is not only more content
column21: but good content. Because Apple is so flush with cash
column22: it can literally do anything in this arena. There is a ton of talent out there
column23: and so many models to play with for AAPL stock.Obviously

column1: How Skyworks Solutions Inc Is Growing Beyond Apple;January 29
column3: 01:45:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Skyworks Solutions.Skyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) investors couldn't have asked for a better start   to its fiscal 2017. A first quarterearnings beatand a stronger outlook for the ongoing quarter sent its stock   soaring to new 52-week highs
column4: as it rose over 13% in a single   day.makeArticleAd();For the fiscal second quarter
column5: Skyworks believes that its   revenue will grow 8% year-over-year to $840 million
column6: exceeding   the consensus forecast of $818 million
column7: while earnings of $1.40   per share should significantly outpace analyst estimates of $1.24   per share.Skyworks also delivered some solid long-term takeaways in its   latest quarter. The company is now boasting of design wins at   high-volume smartphone companies in China
column8: as it is growing its   revenue outside ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . Still
column9: Apple reportedly contributed 40% of   Skyworks' top line in fiscal 2016.However
column10: the company has been gradually working toward winning   more business from other clients
column11: and it has found some   success.Growing beyond AppleSkyworks' business outside of Apple increased 8% in the last   fiscal year
column12: as Vivek Arya of Merrill Lynch pointed out on the   latest conference call. Though this might not seem really big   right now
column13: the fact that overall revenue fell 1.3% year-over-year   in the first quarter makes the growth beyond Apple a crucial   factor for long-term success.In fiscal 2015
column14: Apple wasreportedly44% of Skyworks' business. Thus
column15: it can be assumed that of   Skyworks' total revenue of $927 million in the first quarter of   2016
column16: Apple contributed about $408 million of that. By   comparison
column17: the smartphone giant should have contributed $366   million to Skyworks' revenue (40% of $914 million) in the most   recently reported quarter. This indicates that revenue from Apple   fell about 10% year-over-year.That indicates Skyworks' growth from other clients powered its   revenue and earnings beat last quarter. This is why Skyworks   needs to aggressively pursue client diversification if it wants   to mitigate the slowdown in business with Apple.Diversifying in the right areasSkyworks Solutions is building an army of clients in China.   One of the most prominent names is Huawei. The company has been   supplying its SkyBlue technology to the Chinese smartphone maker   for its flagship Mate 9 smartphone. In fact
column18: according to   Skyworks CEO Liam Griffin
column19: Huawei is now the company's second   biggest client.This is a big deal for Skyworks since Huawei is now a   formidable name in the smartphone industry. According to the   latest data available from IDC
column20: Huawei's smartphone market share   stood at 9.3%
column21: trailingSamsung's 21% share and Apple's 12.5% share in the third quarter of   2016. More importantly
column22: the Chinese smartphone giant has been   selling more of its high and mid-range phones
column23: which account for   57% of its total shipments.With a higher share of Huawei's sales being driven by premium   and mid-range devices
column24: it has been able to increase the average   selling price of its phones. When the company had released its   2015 results
column25: its average selling price of smartphones was up 17%   to $204 per unit. Though the company has not released 2016   numbers yet
column26: Huawei is capable of increasing its selling prices   once again as it has been introducing its flagship phones in   global markets.The higher average selling price
column27: along with higher volumes
column28: is good news for Skyworks since it will be able to enhance its   dollar content in Huawei devices
column29: which are in turn enjoying   higher selling prices. Market research firm TrendForce   points out that smartphone production will increase 4.5% this   year to 1.4 billion units. Chinese smartphone companies will   account for 634 million units of this production
column30: with Oppo
column31: Vivo
column32: and Huawei being the biggest names. As Skyworks counts all   three of them as clients
column33: it will witness a rise in chip sales   this year as the top Chinese smartphone companies are expected to   sell 39% more phones in 2017 as compared to 2016.Therefore
column34: higher component demand by Chinese companies to   make more smartphones will push up Skyworks' average selling   prices
column35: since it should be able to charge a premium in the wake   of tight supply. Skyworks can also make up for the volumes that   it is losing due to Apple's slowing iPhone sales
column36: as it can now   sell more components to Chinese smartphone makers.Moving beyond mobileSkyworks' opportunities beyond mobile. Image Source:     Skyworks Solutions.The great thing about Skyworks is that it is pursuing   opportunities beyond mobile as well. The Internet of Things
column37: or   IoT
column38: is one such opportunity where the company is aggressively   enhancing its presence by launching new offerings.Skyworks released new front-end connectivity modules for   machine-to-machine connectivity and IoT operations a few weeks   ago. With its latest IoT product
column39: Skyworks should be able to   accelerate the deployment of IoT applications by encouraging   migration from 2G networks due to its low cost and compact   packaging.This product development move by Skyworks is a smart one
column40: since the number of cellular devices communicating with each   other will rise from 300 million at present to around two billion   by 2020
column41: according to GSMA. As the number of machine-to-machine   connections increases
column42: Skyworks' connectivity modules that enable   the IoT will gain more traction and lead to higher shipment   volumes.However
column43: the company does not single out its revenue or   shipments from the IoT segment
column44: or any segment for that matter.   But the sheer growth in the size of this market
column45: coupled with the   company's product development efforts
column46: should prove to be a   tailwind in the long run.The Foolish takeawaySkyworks revenue is expected to increase 8.7% in the current   fiscal year
column47: followed by stronger growth of 10.5% next year. It   appears to be pulling the right strings to diversify its revenue   away from heavily concentrated clients such as Apple
column48: which seems   to have hit its ownroadblocks. As a result
column49: Skyworks is well-positioned for long-term success   as it focuses on markets that have significant room for growth   versus areas approaching saturation.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks     SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple Stock Has a Lot to Prove on Tuesday;January 29
column3: 10:07:00 AM EDT;"Image source: The Motley Fool.One of the biggest earnings reports this week will beApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . The world's most valuable consumer tech company   will be reporting its fiscal first quarter results after the   market close on Tuesday
column4: and it wouldn't be a surprise if the   numbers move bothApple stockand the market in general.makeArticleAd();Apple stock hit a fresh 52-week high on Thursday
column5: and with the   shares trading 36% off their springtime lows
column6: it's easy to see   how proving mortal can trigger a sell-off. The silver lining here   is that just a sliver of its gains have come in the past three   months. Apple shares have risen a mere 3% since its last   quarterly report.Wall Street pros aren't holding out for much. They see $77.38   billion in revenue for the holiday quarter
column7: just 2% more than   what Apple scored during the prior year's holiday quarter.   Analysts are also forecasting a profit of $3.22 a share
column8: just   below the $3.28 Apple delivered a year earlier.Grate expectationsIf a 2% uptick in revenue and a 2% dip in earnings per share   seem uninspiring

column10: respectively

column12: and no match for selling fewer iPhones

Apple used to routinely   blast through analyst profit targets with ease when the iPad was   new and the iPhone was all the rage during the early years of the   mobile revolution. They're getting closer to the truth these   days. Apple hasn't topped Wall Street profit estimates by more   than 3% over the past year

Apple's outstanding share count has declined in   each of the past four years.Analysts who have chimed in with updates in the days leading   up to Tuesday's report have been mixed. Mark Moskowitz at   Barclays downgraded Apple from ""overweight"" to ""equal weight

Analysts are looking beyond the fiscal first quarter
column21: and the   stock hasn't kept up with the market since its last quarterly   report. After three quarters of year-over-year revenue declines

column1: Will Lawsuits Force Apple
column2: Inc. To Prevent Texting And Driving?;January 29
column4: 10:00:00 AM EDT;"Distracted driving is a big and growing problem. In 2014
column6: 179 Americans were killed in traffic accidents involving   drivers diverting their attention to activities like eating
column7: talking on their phone
column8: or texting. It's the third most deadly   factor in modern car accidents
column9: behind only drunk driving and   speeding.You'll be delighted to hear that iPhone makerApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has patented a way to reduce this menace. But the   patented solution is not yet implemented on any of Apple's   devices.What gives? Let's have a look.makeArticleAd();What's new?Last week
column10: a survivor of a distracted-driving incident filed a   class action lawsuit against Apple. The suit is not seeking a big   payout from Cupertino. Instead
column11: it calls for an injunction   against sales of Apple devices in California until the company   implements its patented prevention method against texting and   driving on devices both new and already sold.""If texting and driving is a vessel of trouble
column12: Apple is the   captain of the ship
column13: the court filing states. ""The company   enjoys 40 percent of the smartphone market share -- far more than   the nearest competitor. And its profits are enormous. Fortune   Magazine reports that in the third quarter of 2016
column14: Apple   generated 91% of the smartphone market's profits
column15: equating to a   cool $8.5 billion in net profit -- or about $95 million in profit   per day.""So the suit argues that Apple plays a significant part in the   distracted driving problem
column16: and has both a responsibility and the   financial wherewithal to do something about it. Indeed
column17: there is   a tool on the table. The filing cites an Applepatentfor disabling a mobile device when its motion sensors and other   systems detect patterns consistent with driving a car. Filed in   2008
column18: when the ancientiPhone 3Gwas brand new
column19: and approved by the Patent Office in 2014
column20: Apple   has had an eye on this issue since the very beginning of its   smartphone exploits.But again
column21: nearly three years after that patent got an   official approval
column22: the technology remains unused.This lawsuit is not the first legal challenge to cite Apple's   anti-distraction patent. It's just the first one that primarily   wants to force Apple's hand into doing something with this   allegedly life-saving technology. Others have been more concerned   with cash payments for damage done by iPhone-wielding   drivers.Image source: US Patent and Trademark Office.Why isn't Apple using this patent yet?Many fully granted patents never see the light of day in a   real-world implementation. This particular one could be among   those for a variety of good reasons. For example:Apple could be working on a better solution than the one     described in the '143 patent
column23: but the new and improved solution     isn't ready for a date with the Patent Office yet.The company might have found flaws in its original     technology
column24: which was developed and filed at a time when     smartphones were a poorly understood novelty. Real-world     experience and deeper research could have changed Apple's     design requirements in a hurry.Other companies may have unveiled better solutions for the     dangers of distracted driving
column25: perhaps as part of efforts to     come up with fully automated driving platforms. Nearly every     major auto maker is on board with theautonomous drivingtrend now
column26: alongside plenty of technology experts. I'd be     surprised to learn that Apple's efforts from way back in 2008     provided a better solution than what all of Detroit and Silicon     Valley could whip up nearly a decade later.That's just scratching the surface of about a zillion reasons   not to take a patented technology to market. I'm sure that Apple   will come up with many more if the lawsuit ever hits a   courtroom.Image source: Apple.What's next?No
column27: I don't think that Apple will ever actually implement this   particular deterrent to texting and driving. Lawsuits won't   change that. Halting iPhone sales in California would be a   powerful incentive
column28: but Apple's top-shelf legal eagles can surely   head that threat off at the pass. However
column29: the fact that   consumers are standing up to ask Apple for help with this   conundrum could accelerate Apple's arrival at a more complete   solution.The company must balance the benefits of a life-saving safety   feature against the risk that users might find the new   restrictions too overbearing. If your phone came with opt-in   restrictions on how you can use it in the driver's seat of a car
column30: would you enable them? If not
column31: you'd be part of the problem.   Therefore

column3: 03:46:00 PM EDT;"Investing in the tech sector can be tricky. Competition     tends to be fierce
column4: which makes it difficult to stay one step     ahead. Two companies that have a strong history of maintaining     their edge areSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS)  andInfinera(NASDAQ: INFN) . Both of these businesses have been taking     market share in their industries for years
column5: which is     impressive. But which of these two tech companies is the better     investment today? Let's review the bull thesis for each company     so we can make an informed decision.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The case for Skyworks SolutionsSkyworks designs and builds chips that allow devices to   connect to each other. The company's semiconductors are found in   a wide range of products such as routers
column6: tablets
column7: cars
column8: and   smartphones.While this industry is quite competitive

column11: including those made bySamsung

column13: andApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) .The massive boom in smartphone sales over the last few   years has been a godsend for Skyworks. The company's revenue

column17: Skyworks looks well positioned to continue delivering   for investors from here. However
column18: Skyworks does have   an Achilles heel that investors should be aware of.   Apple is responsible for more than 40% of Skyworks' total   revenue
column19: which is a blessing and a curse. When iPhone sales are   booming
column20: Skyworks' results soar. However
column21: when the Mac maker   decides to reduce its channel inventory
column22: Skyworks reallyfeels the pain.While Skyworks has been signing deals in recent years to help   reduce its customer concentration
column23: Apple is such a huge component   of Skyworks revenue that these two companies will remain attached   at the hip -- for better or worse -- for the foreseeable   future.The case for InfineraInfinera is a fast growing player in the   optical networking equipment market. column24: Infinera has also benefited from a number of   tech trends. The rise of cloud computing and streaming high-def   video is making it difficult for providers to keep up with   demand. That's forcing them to invest huge sums of money to   expand their networks
column25: which has been a boon to Infinera's   business.Image source: Getty Images.That's a wonderful backdrop
column26: but Infinera hasstruggledover the last few quarters to translate that bandwidth   demand growth into financial success. While there are several   factors to blame
column27: one of the biggest problems is   competition.Ciena-- a much larger rival -- has caught up to Infinera's   technological edge and has been eating the company's lunch as of   late. While Infinera's management is aware of the problem and is   investing heavily to recapture its edge
column28: it might be a long-haul   until the company returns to top-line growth.Of course
column29: those worries have now beenpriced into the company's stock
column30: so investors could be in a position to win big if the company   can grow faster than market watchers expect.The better buyWhile I'm hopeful that Infinera can right its ship

column32: I think that   the better choice for investors today is Skyworks. Not only does   Skyworks promise high growth rates ahead

column3: 12:00:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.If you read throughApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) blockbuster lawsuit againstQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)

column6: and there wasn't a whole lot that Apple could do   since the iPhone fundamentally relies on cellular connectivity.   This is easily the only time that Apple has not had the upper   hand with a supplier relationship. Look no further than Apple's   ownnegotiating tacticswith now-defunct GT Advanced to see how hard Apple could squeeze   its suppliers. Yet Qualcomm was able to become the most powerful   Apple supplier ever.This story has at least a decade of history that you need to   know to fully appreciate why Apple felt desperate enough to sue.   ""I've always hated litigation and I continue to hate it

column23: Qualcomm has instead     entered into confidential licenses with specific Apple contract     manufacturers (""CMs"")
column24: the third-party manufacturers who make     and assemble Apple products. The CMs pay the exorbitant     royalties Qualcomm demands and pass the costs along to Apple in     full.As a way to get relief on excessive royalties
column25: Apple entered   into a ""Marketing Incentive Agreement"" with Qualcomm in 2007 that   prohibited it from marketing WiMAX devices
column26: an emerging 4G   standard that would compete with LTE -- and which Qualcomm lacks   meaningful patents for. Obviously

column1: This Week in Solar;January 28
column3: 08:15:00 AM EDT;"There's a lot to get to this week in solar
column4: so let's dive   right in.The fast and furious progress of solar energyIn 2011
column5: then Secretary of the U.S. Department of Energy   Steven Chu launched the SunShot initiative with a goal of cutting   the cost of installing a utility-scale solar system for $1 per   watt by 2020. At the time
column6: I called the 74% reduction in the cost   of solar in a decade ""an audacious goal.""Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Less than six years later and three years ahead of schedule
column7: I'm here to say that I underestimated the solar industry.   Projects are being built for less than $1 per watt today
column8: and   cost reductions continue to amaze even the most bullish   observers. Everything from solar panels to inverters to   permitting costs have come down in the last six years with the   SunShot program helping with the reductions. And $1 per-watt   solar will lead to a whole new surge in demand
column9: which is very   bullish for solar companies around the world.Apple and NV Energy find common groundBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) subsidiary NV Energy has taken its   share of lumps from the renewable energy industry over the last   few years. Solar advocates helped drive a ballot measure in   November that will give customers more choice than buying energy   from the monopoly. And casino companies
column10: which are its largest   customers
column11: are starting tocut their ties to the utilityand buy energy elsewhere.NV Energy may be learning that it can't take such an   adversarial approach to renewable energy and customers' desires   to buy renewables after agreeing to help Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)   build a 200 MW solar power plant by early 2019. The utility will   buy energy from the solar plant and sell the energy to Apple for   a data center in Reno
column12: continuing Apple's growth in solar   adoption.Corporate customers will likely be big drivers of renewable   energy in 2017
column13: demanding clean energy to power their businesses   around the country. Maybe utilities are finally learning that   it's better to go along with the renewable-energy revolution than   fight it and lose their customers to someone else.Don't freak out about the ITC... yetThe solar industry is abuzz with speculation about the solar   investment tax credit (ITC)
column14: which helps fund every solar project   in the country today. The subsidy was extended at the end of 2015   and is currently set to startstepping down from 30% in 2019to a permanent 10% from commercial projects
column15: and 0% for   residential projects
column16: starting in 2022.It's no secret that most of the new Trump Administration is   less in favor of renewable energy than the past administration
column17: so there's concern the ITC could be in trouble. But comments from   Treasury Secretary nominee Steve Mnuchin in support of wind   subsidies
column18: and Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson in   relation to climate change
column19: have eased some of those   tensions.Keep in mind that the ITC stepdown is current law and would   require an act of Congress
column20: including 60 votes in the Senate
column21: to   be repealed. I think that's unlikely to happen
column22: especially when   you consider the 200
column23: 000+ jobs in solar and extreme popularity of   the energy source. The ITC seems safe
column24: despite the likelihood   that it's unpopular inside the White House. Unless something   changes
column25: solar investors can breathe a sigh of relief.News and notesHere are the other notable items of the week that investors   shouldn't lose sight of.Eos Energy Storage andSiemens(NASDAQOTH: SIEGY)announced a partnershipto integrate
column26: install
column27: and service utility-scale energy-storage   solutions. It's hard to state how big it is that a giant in   electricity-distribution equipment is taking a role in energy   storage
column28: which will help solar provide more value to the grid. We   don't know exactly what will happen with the partnership in terms   of costs or demand for utility-scale storage
column29: but the fact that   it's on the radar of giants of the industry is big for renewable   energy.Pattern Energy Group(NASDAQ: PEGI) announced the closing of $350 million in senior   notes due 2024 with a 5.875% interest rate. The financing will   help the company pay down short-term debt and acquire more   renewable-energy projects. If this is a sign that yieldco   financing is opening up
column30: it would be good for the entire   industry.Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ) signed a contract earlier this week with the   Sacramento Municipal Utility District to sell energy from a 60 MW   solar farm over the course of 20 years starting in mid-2017. column1: Microsoft's Surface Lineup Is Now a $4.3 Billion Business;January 27
column3: 04:10:00 PM EDT;"Surface lineup. Image source: Microsoft.WhenMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) first launched itsSurface lineup in 2012
column4: I had my doubts as to whether or not the company could   successfully jump into hardware. The company has had its fair   share of missteps for the Surface
column5: but it's safe to say at this   point that Microsoft has exceeded most early expectations for its   first-party devices. Microsoft has adapted quickly to flops like   Surface RT
column6: which resulted in a $900 million writedown back in   2013
column7: and pushed forward with expanding the portfolio
column8: most   recently with Surface Studio.makeArticleAd();Surface revenue during the fourth quarter came in at $1.3   billion
column9: representing a sequential increase of over 40% for the   busy holiday shopping season. That's enough to bring full-year   2016 Surface revenue to an impressive $4.3 billion.Data source: Microsoft. Chart by author. Calendar years     shown.It also probably helps that CEO Satya Nadella is a stronger   leader than his predecessor
column10: even though the Surface strategy was   conceived under Steve Ballmer. The push with Surface hardware   created a rift between Ballmer and Bill Gates
column11: and may have also   contributed to Ballmer's ouster.Out with the old
column12: in with the newDuring the earnings call
column13: Nadella noted that Surface has   enjoyed three consecutive quarters of 25%-plus growth. Sales mix   is transitioning toward the newer products like Surface Pro 4 and   Surface Book
column14: and Surface 3 sales are expected to continue   winding down.The customer reception for Surface Studio in particular has   been strong
column15: which is especially impressive for two reasons:   Surface Studio was not widely available during the fourth   quarter
column16: and it's extremely expensive
column17: starting at $3
column18: 000.   Inventories for the new all-in-one should start improving this   quarter as production ramps up.Taking a bite out of AppleMore broadly
column19: Surface is but part of a bigger push among the   Windows PC crowd to take a bite out ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) turf: the premium PC market. Surface is doing   well
column20: but it was never expected to comprise a large chunk of the   Windows ecosystem; that's what original equipment manufacturers   (OEMs) are for.CFO Amy Hood said that Microsoft's ""OEM non-pro performance   should grow ahead of the market
column21: due to strength in the premium   device category."" In other words
column22: high-end consumer-oriented PCs   made by Microsoft's partners are gaining traction in the market
column23: at a time when Apple lost PC market share for thefirst three quartersof 2016 (Apple reports fourth-quarter results next week). OEM   non-pro revenue grew 5% last quarter
column24: outpacing the broader PC   market.Surface is profitable
column25: tooIt's also worth pointing out that Surface is now profitable on   a gross margin basis (up 6% last quarter in dollar terms)
column26: so   those revenue gains are starting to enjoy some operating   leverage.Unfortunately
column27: currency headwinds are adversely impacting   profitability
column28: as Surface gross margin was up 17% on a constant   currency basis in dollar terms. There's a big discrepancy between   the currency impacts on revenue (2 percentage points) compared to   gross margin (11 percentage points)
column29: which is due to the fact   that Surface devices are manufactured in Asia and the Surface   cost structure is more vulnerable to currency fluctuations.Still
column30: you have to give Nadella credit for being able to take   a struggling segment conceived under Ballmer and turn it into a   profitable $4.3 billion business within just a couple of   years.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column31: it can pay to listen. After all
column32: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column33: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column34: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
