column1: 10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great;January 27
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmidst the bombast
column5: braggadocio and fact-free claims of the 2016 presidential campaign
column6: perhaps the most effective was the subtext contained in President Trump's incessantly cited mantra
column7: ""Make America Great Again.""makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe implication of this successful sonnet of sloganism is that America is not great
column8: at least not in its current iteration. And while certainly an effectual rhetorical rallying point for the most disaffected voters
column9: the claim fails to hold up to scrutiny when one takes a more lucid view of the corporate and investing landscape.Indeed
column10: there are scores of companies
column11: and scores of stocks to own
column12: that already make America great. These are the companies that make the products and services that Americans organize their lives around. Creators of communication devices
column13: social media networks and information retrieval services are just a few of the brilliant achievements of entrepreneurial Americans that have made the country great through the genius of their ideas.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018They're also among the top companies
column14: and the top stocks
column15: that make our nation great for investors. If you want to feel good about the country
column16: and about the prospects for long-term portfolio performance
column17: here are 10 stocks to own thatalreadymake America great.Stocks to Buy: Boeing (BA)Source:Phillip Capper via FlickrPremier American aircraft manufacturerBoeing Co(NYSE:BA) also is one of the largest defense contractors in the U.S. The company supplies Western military forces with the F-15 and F-18 fighter jets
column18: which also are capable of precision strategic bombing runs crucial to defeating enemies such as the Islamic State.Just check out this footage of an F-18 delivering ISIS fighters a dead-on strike with a500-lb laser guided bomb[Graphic content warning] and you'll be convinced of the efficacy of its fighter jets in the effort against a determined
column19: well-funded and ideologically inspired army.Yet Boeing is far more than just a builder of military hardware. The company's iconic ""7 Series"" passenger jets - the 747
column21: 777 and 787 - have allowed not just Americans
column22: but travelers worldwide to speed off to their destinations safely
column23: and in style. If you want evidence of American corporate greatness
column24: just look to the sky near any major metropolitan airport. You're sure to spot the greatness of Boeing in flight.Stocks to Buy:Amazon.com (AMZN)Source: ShutterstockOnline seller of everythingAmazon.com(NASDAQ:AMZN) has been making America great for nearly 23 years. The brainchild of CEO Jeff Bezos began life as a hub where avid readers could get the latest novels
column25: and discover both new and old works that would appeal to their tastes.That formula worked not only for literature
column26: but for everything from music
column27: film
column28: video games
column29: electronics
column30: clothing
column31: toys
column32: toothpaste  and just about anything else one can require or desire.Amazon.com's relatively recent foray into the cloud computing business has been an unequivocal success
column33: with the company raking in some $3.2 billion in cloud computing revenue in the third quarter of 2016.3 Fast-Food Stocks That Are Sweating Bullets Thanks to McDonald'sThat figure was up 55% from the same quarter the year prior. Amazon's web services business proves that not only does the company make America great by delivering the products we want right to our door
column34: it also makes possible many of the e-commerce sites the American - and global - economy relies on to function smoothly.Stocks to Buy:Apple (AAPL)Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrPersonal technology giantApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is not only one of the most profitable companies in history
column35: it's alsothe most admired. And why shouldn't it be?The ubiquity
column36: efficacy
column37: ease of operation
column38: quality
column39: sophisticated industrial design and just outright aesthetic beauty of the company's products is a feat of entrepreneurial genius that on its own can be cited as a ""drop-the-mic"" reason why America already deserves the greatness title.The company's iconic products - the Mac
column40: iPod
column41: iPad and iPhone - all have transformed the way not only Americans live
column42: but also the way most of the developed and developing nations live. AAPL stock ran into a slowdown for much of 2016
column43: but since Election Day
column44: Wall Street has made Apple shares great again
column45: with a surge of more than 10%.Investors are clearly betting on the continued upside likely to come with the release of the company's 10th-anniversary iPhone. If you want proof America is already great
column46: just check your iMessages.Stocks to Buy:Facebook (FB)Source: ShutterstockSocial media pioneerFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is a relatively recent entry into the ranks of companies making America great
column47: and it's done so by the sheer disruptive power of its product.The creation of CEO Mark Zuckerberg is the kind of game-changing invention that comes along infrequently
column48: but when it does it's hard to see how we ever got along without it.From connecting with old friends to staying in contact with relatives; and from discovering new interests
column49: nurturing hobbies and networking with others who share similar worldviews
column50: Facebook has become an essential part of the American (and global) experience.Ironically
column51: Facebook's flap with ""fake news"" and its ranking of certain news stories was an issue in the presidential campaign. Yet Facebook also was cited by President Trump as a key to his victory
column52: as he told CBS'60 Minutesthat thepower of his following on the social media gianthelped him win key races where he was outspent by his opponent.The 3 Best Sector ETFs to Buy for a Profitable 2017So
column53: Facebook not only already makes America great
column54: it also made President Trump's campaign a winner.Stocks to Buy:Goldman Sachs (GS)Source:Erik DrostIf you were asked to compile a list of the ""Big Banks"" that have financed America's growth
column55: as well as her ascension to greatness
column56: it's hard not to start withGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS).The premier investment bank has been at the center of the financial world since the reparative
column57: post-Civil War years
column58: when it helped finance America's rebirth beginning in 1869.Since then the company has had a storied history of providing the capital
column59: as well as the financial framework
column60: that's nurtured the rise of the greatest capitalist experiment in history.In another example ofTrumpianirony
column61: the president criticized the banks - and specifically Goldman Sachs - for transgressions that caused the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008. Yet who did Trump turn to for key positions in his campaign and in his cabinet? You guessed it
column62: numerous Goldman Sachs alumni.The moral of the story here is that when you want your own administration to be great
column63: you turn to those who have done great things at one of the greatest American financial institutions.Stocks to Buy:Alphabet (GOOGL)Source: ShutterstockPerhaps the only thing not great aboutAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column64: NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column65: better known as Google
column66: is its ghastly choice of new moniker. Yet despite its ill-fitting name
column67: Alphabet's core product - the Google search engine - has already made information-seeking America great.Founded by then-Ph.D. students Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were at Stanford University
column68: the tech entrepreneurs leveraged the PC and internet explosion and created the go-to source for information on just about anything imaginable.Its corporate mission
column69: to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful
column70: has long been accomplished. And though Google has only been in existence for less than 20 years
column71: like Facebook
column72: it also has become an essential part of the American and the international experience.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsJust try to go more than a few days without using Google. It's nearly impossible
column73: especially if you are someone who loves knowing things.Stocks to Buy:Disney (DIS)Source: ShutterstockAnyone who has grown up in America since the 1940s
column74: or who has reared children or grandchildren over the past five decades
column75: knows all-too-well the draw that is theWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS).Purveyors of iconic American characters such as Mickey and Minnie Mouse
column76: Donald Duck
column77: Goofy
column78: Snow White and so many others
column79: the company has built a media and entertainment empire by knowing what Americans (and the world) want to see.Disney's relatively recent acquisition of the Star Wars franchise is proof of the company's commitment to remaining the leader in providing entertainment with the broadest appeal.Founded on the genius of Walt Disney the man
column80: the Disney Company was set up to be a dream factory capable of igniting children's imaginations all over the world. It's safe to say that it has done just that
column81: and that it will remain great long after President Trump has completed his tenure in the Oval Office.Stocks to Buy:American Express (AXP)Source:Marcus Quigmire Via FlickrWhen ""American"" is part of your name
column82: it's easy to make the short hop of logic needed to proclaimAmerican Express Company(NYSE:AXP) a company that's already making America great. Indeed
column83: the credit card issuer
column84: andDow Jonescomponent
column85: offers what is arguably the best customer service in the financial services industry.Moreover
column86: it's an aspirational brand that pulls at the capitalist heart strings of nearly every American set on achieving financial prowess. For those who've experienced it
column87: how can you forget being approved for your first American Express card? That grant signifies an arrival of sorts into an honored clubhouse of the financially fit.Here
column88: too
column89: irony and the Trump administration once again collide. If President Trump and the Republican Congress can get personal tax reform passed
column90: American Express shares may be the biggest beneficiary. The reason why is because higher income and higher net worth consumers tend to use American Express more than rival credit cards.3 Dividend Aristocrats to Buy for Income and GrowthAs such
column91: a reduction in marginal tax rates for the nation's top earners would likely translate into increased spending via AmEx - which would funnel down directly to AXP shares.Stocks to Buy:Caterpillar (CAT)Source:Anthony via FlickrThe makers of earth-shaping equipment have literally transformed the American landscape into man's image
column92: a feat that on its own qualifiesCaterpillar Inc.(NYSE:CAT) for a spot on the 10 stocks that already make America great.The unmistakable CAT brand is responsible for helping more builders erect more homes
column93: shopping centers
column94: office buildings
column95: roads
column96: bridges and dams than any government infrastructure project could ever do.In fact
column97: any effort to make America's infrastructure great again would likely start with a whole lot of equipment from Caterpillar
column98: as its heavy machinery is an integral part of massive build outs here at home
column99: and worldwide.The CAT brand also is seen as a sort of badge of honor in the developing world
column100: as developing nations seek to build their infrastructure in the image of the American landscape. To the rest of the world
column101: America is already great  and they often use Caterpillar equipment to help their own nations look like us.Stocks to Buy:Tesla Motors (TSLA)Source: ShutterstockAmerica is a car culture country
column102: and many of her most iconic brands -General Motors Company(NYSE:GM) andFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) - represent the best of American industrial prowess.While these storied brands could themselves be on any list of stocks that already make America great
column103: one new car company embodies all of the entrepreneurial and innovative genius that's at the heart of what makes America special. That company isTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA).The brainchild of the ceaselessly creative Elon Musk
column105: performance and the lack of an internal combustion engine can be a splendid marriage; one never lacking in operator excitement. In fact
column106: the experience of driving the posh
column107: powerful and eminently smooth Model S through traffic is akin to what it must be like piloting a modern fighter jet through a formation of P-51 Mustangs.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryAnd while the World War II fighter helped make America great by vanquishing her enemies in aerial combat
column109: Model X and Model 3 are clearing a new path for automotive technology - technology that could be the American and global standard in decades to come.As of this writing
column112: GS and TSLA stock.The post10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Greatappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This Quarter;January 27
column3: 02:59:00 PM EDT;"Analysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column4: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column5: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column6: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column7: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column8: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column9: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. MicrosoftMSFTfor one has strongly resisted government demands as have AppleAAPLand AmazonAMZN. Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like IntelINTC
column10: NVIDIANVDA
column11: Qualcomm and Advanced Micro DevicesAMD; networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column12: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column13: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column14: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column15: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column16: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column17: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column18: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column19: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column20: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column21: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column22: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter
column23: that's nearly up by a billion dollars and will mostly be spent on data centers to support its cloud business.Now See Our Private Investment IdeasWhile the above ideas are being shared with the public

column1: Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Has Quite a Wall to Climb;January 27
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenever high-flying stocks get their wings clipped
column5: they are never the same on the markets.Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) ended its recovery of the summer of 2016 when it warned on Nov. 2
column7: that fourth-quarter estimates would miss estimates. Bears are all over the stock: short float stands at 43.5%. And when the company reports results in February
column8: bulls still hope the company's wearables devices sold like hot cakes.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitExpectations Lowered for FIT StockIn its third-quarter report
column9: the company cut the current quarter's estimatessharply:""The company expects revenue between $725 million and $750 million
column10: representing growth of 2%-5%
column11: with non-GAAP earnings per diluted share in the range of $0.14 to $0.18
column12: and a non-GAAP tax rate of approximately 33%.""At a full-year earnings per share of between 55 cents and 59 cents
column13: FIT trades at a forward P/E of up to 13.5 times (Based on Thursday's closing price of $7.41). Investors clearly have low expectations for the company. Trailing quarterly sales grew by 23.1%. Shorts are winning the bearish bet because they understand a company with good products is not necessarily a good stock.Competition Heating UpDespite a record low valuation
column14: low expectations for the quarter and potential growth in Europe and Asia
column15: FIT stock has one big problem: competition. During the holiday season
column16: consumers had the choice of buying many cheaper alternatives at a fraction of a FIT device. In Asia
column17: Xiaomisells similar wearables for a fraction of FIT's price.On the high end
column18: FIT competes with theGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN) Vivosmart HR
column19: which costs the same as Fitbit's Charge 2 (both cost around $149.95) andApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Watch 1 and 2.If FIT's stock collapses post-earnings
column20: it will be among a long list of fallen fad stocks. This includesGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO)
column21: whose action camera is losing popularity andEtsy Inc(NASDAQ:ETSY)
column22: whose handmade products compete withAmazon.com
column23: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) homemadestore.Fitbit's next phase of growth depends on expanding internationally. Executing on this requires good management. When management said it mishandled the Flex 2 supply chain
column24: few investors should have any confidence on management.On Jan. 12
column25: news broke out that Fitbit may havewantedto acquireJawbonelate last year. This is another example that suggests investors should worry about FIT's management capability.Whole Foods Market
column26: Inc. (WFM) in the Fresh Food WarsThe company needs to preserve its cash
column27: instead of spending it on supply chain managementBottom Line on FitbitFitbit knows that competition will worsen over time. Its (rumored) attempts to buy Jawbone would have eliminated that threat
column28: positioning the company as a stronger foe against Apple
column29: Garmin and the cheap wearable device makers.The stock is still a ""show me"" investment though
column30: especially if holiday sales are underwhelming.As of this writing
column31: Chris Lau had no position in any of the stocks mentioned. Follow him onTwitter.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in February10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You BackThe postFitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Has Quite a Wall to Climbappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: Designer Creates Interesting iPhone 8 Concept;January 27
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of an iPhone 8 concept. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.makeArticleAd();iPhone 8 Concept:Designer Iskander Utebayev has created an interesting concept of what Apple's next iPhone may look like
column6: reportsBGR. The designer created a sleek looking concept for the iPhone 8 that has a curved display. It's a slim device that has a sleek look to it. One interesting idea that can be seen in the concept is the change for the camera. The concept puts the camera for the iPhone 8 inside of the AAPL logo. It's an interesting idea
column7: but not likely one the tech company will adopt.iPad Anniversary:Today is the 7-year anniversary for the iPad
column8: MacRumorsnotes. Apple founder Steve Jobs introduced the iPad to audiences at a media event in 2010. He called it AAPL's ""most advanced technology in a magical and revolutionary device at an unbelievable price."" The original iPad had a 9.7-inch display with a resolution of 1024 x 768. It came in 16GB
column9: 32GB and 64GB models. The tablet was powered by the tech company's A4 processor.Apple Watch Music:Owners of the Apple Watch have the ability to take music with them on the go without their iPhone
column10: reports9to5Mac. The smartwatch has the ability to store up to 2GB of music. It all has to be in a single playlist first. It also requires an iPhone to get the music on there in the first place. The smartwatch can also be paired with wireless headphones so users can listen to the music through them. All and all
column11: its a bit of a complicated process
column12: but it might be worth it for those that don't want to take their iPhone with them during their morning run.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: Designer Creates Interesting iPhone 8 Conceptappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Samsung (SSNLF) Expected to Launch Galaxy S8 on March 29;January 27
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWith the official Galaxy Note 7 battery review out of the way
column5: everyone has been waiting forSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) to release the new Galaxy S8. Samsung still isn't saying anything
column6: but clues have been building that it will be later than normal. NowVentureBeatsays it has the first photos of the elusive smartphone as well as an exact Galaxy S8 launch date.makeArticleAd();Source: SamsungSamsung's well-publicized disaster with the Galaxy Note 7 had a big ripple effect on the Galaxy S8.First
column7: the company had to identify - without question - what had caused Galaxy Note 7 batteries to burst into flames. Then it had to pinpoint a fail-safe solution to the problem. After that
column8: it had to hold an event where it publicly reviewed its findings and outlined the steps it had taken to ensure it never happens again. Thatevent took place last week.Galaxy S8 Launch Pushed Back by Battery ConcernsAs part of the battery investigation
column9: Samsung also had to take measures to ensure the Galaxy S8 would not have similar problems
column10: and that would have involved delayed finalization of the battery and related components. And you can bet the company has taken testing of the battery on its new flagship smartphone to new levels.As a result
column11: it seemed likely the Galaxy S8 launch date would be pushed from it's traditional Mobile World Congress unveiling in February. Samsung confirmed this during last week's event.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The Guardian
column12: citing anonymous sources close to Samsung
column13: pointed to alate March release date. Yesterday
column14: VentureBeat'sEvan Blassclaimed to have specifics
column15: saying the Galaxy S8 launch will take place at a Samsung Unpacked event in New York City on March 29.Galaxy S8 DetailsTheVentureBeatreport also includes many technical details about SSNLF's new flagship handset(s)
column16: including photos.As has been speculated
column17: it appears that this year both Galaxy S8 smartphones will feature a curved ""Edge"" Super AMOLED display
column18: but both will also lose the Home button so nearly the entire front is display - the camera remains at top. As a result
column19: even though the overall dimensions stay roughly the same
column20: both new smartphones will have larger displays than the Galaxy Note 7: 5.8-inches and 6.2-inches.The fingerprint sensor has been moved to the back
column21: and high tech biometrics are supplemented by an iris scanner. The charge port is the new USB-C standard
column22: base storage moves to 64GB (with SD card expansion still offered) and unlikeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column23: Samsung will reportedly keep the headphone jack.By connecting to an optional dock
column24: the Galaxy S8 will be able to be used as an Android computer. And it will feature Bixby
column25: theadvanced AI personal assistantSamsung gained when it purchased Viv in October.Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL)Interestingly
column26: VentureBeatsays the price of both models - which it says will go on sale April 21 - will be 100 (roughly $100) more than last year's models.The Importance of the Galaxy S8 LaunchIt can't be understated how critical this release is to SSNLF. After recalling 3 million Galaxy Note 7s'
column27: its reputation took a serious blow. Apple will be pulling out all the stops with the iPhone 8 later this year
column28: as it celebrates the iPhone's 10th anniversary and mounts a major campaign to convince upgraders.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column29: NASDAQ:GOOGL) released its first Google-branded smartphone in the Pixel Phone at the height of the Galaxy Note 7 debacle
column30: and a follow-up is expected this year.Both rivals will be gunning to boost sales at Samsung's expense.In the last quarterly sales report (from the end of October)
column31: Samsung's smartphone sales marketshare haddropped 13.5%compared to the previous year. The next quarter's numbers could be even worse. If the Galaxy S8 launch flops
column32: Samsung's time at the top of the smartphone sales charts would likely be over.As of this writing
column33: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postSamsung (SSNLF) Expected to Launch Galaxy S8 on March 29appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can Apple Inc. (AAPL) Afford a War With Qualcomm
column4: 11:26:42 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsPatent wars are harmful to corporations and other growing things.makeArticleAd();Source:iphonedigital via FlickrApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has now gone to patent war withQualcomm
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM)
column7: knocking 13% off the modem chip maker's market cap in less than a week.The warhas now extended to China
column8: where two Apple suits are seeking $145 million in damages (about 1 billion Yuan) over how Qualcomm licenses patents there.This being early in the war
column9: the response of Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf is""bring it on.""But
column10: he hasn't seen the legal bills
column11: yet. Shareholders
column12: however
column13: seem to have a clue about what they might be
column14: and apparently feel they will be huge.Apple has yet to be hurt by any of this. AAPL stock price is up about 1.7% since the court papers were filed. But
column15: the march to its record high of $132.54 per share
column16: achieved in May 2015
column17: may now be disrupted.3 Grossly Overpriced Tech Stocks That Could CollapseWhat the War Is AboutQualcomm controls standards essential patents (SEPs)
column18: including those for the Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) system used by carriers such asVerizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ). This means that every CDMA phone chip maker
column19: and CDMA base station maker
column20: is paying license fees to Qualcomm for using those patents. Apple began doing so in 2011when it opened the iPhone to Verizon's network.Qualcomm used its CDMA patents to become the sole supplier of modem chips for the iPhone. It liked this position and refused to join industry-wide agreements covering Fair
column21: Reasonable and Non-Discriminatory (FRAND) access to its patents
column22: giving QCOM the power to constrict Apple's supply of modem chips.Apple eventually foundanother supplier for the chips
column23: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC)
column24: while still paying license fees to Qualcomm.Qualcomm
column25: meanwhile
column26: won an expensive fight with China over its patent rights
column27: and is fighting with South Korea after gettingSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) to back down and use Qualcomm gear in its phones.The short version is that Qualcomm uses its patents to control the global phone market and Apple doesn't like that.The Risk to AppleWhile the market has discounted the risks in these fights to Qualcomm
column28: it has not considered the potential impact on Apple. Credit the $642 billion market cap of Apple
column29: against Qualcomm's $76 billion.There is also a whisper number on Apple earnings
column30: due out January 31
column31: of$77.04 billion in revenue and profit of $3.23 per share. Combine that with over $200 billion in cash and the market may be anticipating a raise in the Apple dividend
column32: currently 57 cents per share. AAPL stock price is still floating on Christmas.But
column33: the risks in a patent war are real. Intel had to turn itself inside-out to make those iPhone modem chips. Another generation of phones and networks is coming
column34: and Qualcomm will have patents to fight with there
column35: too.Apple has already suffered
column36: the company claimed in court
column37: losing a $1 billion rebate it says Qualcomm owed it after AAPL helpeda South Korean investigationinto Qualcomm's business practices
column38: one that resulted in South Korea imposing$864 million in fines.So far
column39: Qualcomm has won in China and it has won against Samsung
column40: and Apple's legal arguments don't scare it. If Korea can get Qualcomm to pay the fine
column41: Samsung may feel emboldened
column42: but SSNLF isin disarrayand may not be in a position to fight Qualcomm any time soon. Apple has taken up its sword.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Steals AI Expert Back From Apple Inc. (AAPL)Given Apple's market size
column43: the cost of lawyers to fight Qualcomm business practices may appear to be a rounding error
column44: but this is going to be a nasty and costly fight. Apple's autonomy in its supply decisions is at stake
column45: as is Qualcomm's control over the market.The market has yet to discount Apple stock over the costs of this war
column46: but I suspect that will happen soon. Probably right after earnings.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column47: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in INTC and AAPL.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018Why Apple Inc. Stock (AAPL) Was Downgraded Ahead Of EarningsTechnology Stocks in 2017: Where Should Investors Focus Now? (AMZN
column48: FB)The postCan Apple Inc. (AAPL) Afford a War With Qualcomm
column49: Inc. (QCOM)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Asia Will Take Over the World
column4: 10:10:22 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's an awkward topic for rogue
column6: extreme-right wing elements in our country. Heck
column7: I'mnot even sure how I really feel about it. But there's a point where it's no longer useful to continuously ignore the giant pink elephant in the room. So here goes it - Asia will take over the world. There's not a darn thing anyone can do to stop the train. AndFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) will have it no other way.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn fact
column8: Facebook is probably one of the few companies that recognize this demographic reality. Subsequently
column9: FB stock is a very real challenger to the near-hegemonic dominance ofAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column10: NASDAQ:GOOGL).Honestly
column11: the social media network is well on its way to becoming whatApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) once was before copycat competitors entered the fray: a completely unique experience and solution with no natural predators.Interestingly
column12: much of society is turning their back towards the demographic goldmine that Facebook stock is sitting on. The NFL celebrates ""Hispanic Heritage Month
column13: and Mexico Cityhosteda regular-season game last year. After activists blasted the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences with the hashtag #OscarsSoWhite
column14: the film industry made dramatic changes. According to NBC News
column15: the ""'African-American Film Critics Association declared 2016 the best year forblacks in cinema'ever'.""While these are profound steps towards diversity and inclusion
column16: there's a glaring omission. According to researchers at theUniversity of Southern California
column17: ""'at least half or more of all cinematic
column18: television
column19: or streaming stories"" didn't portray a single Asian or Asian-American on screen.'""This ""yellow-out"" may be swept under the rug now
column20: but mark my words
column21: FB stock will change everything.Asian Markets Too Bigly for FB Stock to IgnoreAs InvestorPlace contributor Craig Adeyanju notes
column22: the Facebook stock price is all about the numbers
column23: and the numbers look amazing! Adeyanju writes that with ""Facebook on course to reach 2 billion users this year without China
column24: the opportunities become bigger once China allows FB in its country again. Keep in mind that China currently has thelargest numberof internet users globally.""7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018He is so right - the number of China'sinternet usersexceed that of the U.S. by a more than 150% margin. Those are bigly consumers that FB stock desperately wants to tap into. But they're notthatdesperate. China is often overused as a justification for buying Facebook stock or any number of investments. However
column25: just scale up the picture a bit and you'll see why Mark Zuckerberg is so excited.Themajorityof Earth's human population is Asian
column26: period. Even if you were to open a ""heritage month"" for every race
column27: color and creed in America
column28: you would at most affect less than 5% of the world. Adding in the entire Latin American population would help
column29: but the leverage would be less than Africa
column30: and slightly more than Europe.An investment in Facebook stock is simply a recognition of a changing world. Unfortunately
column31: few have this ability. For example
column32: Princeton Universitydetailed evidence ofdiscrimination in academiadesigned to ""cull"" Asian student populations. In contrast
column33: from the perspective of FB stock
column34: these demographic trends are to be embraced
column35: celebrated and ultimately
column36: profited.Untapped Riches Still Available for Facebook StockI mentioned before that China is an overused argument. But when you drill deeper into the statistics
column37: there's still a lot of gold for FB stock to mine. The perennial Asian powerhouse's internet penetration is just slightly above half the population. In contrast
column38: the U.S. internet penetration is nearly 89%. That's the raw
column39: low-hanging fruit from which Facebook stock can benefit.3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Will Keep Delivering in 2017But even in a place like Japan
column40: where the internet penetration is more than 91%
column41: there's still a viable opportunity for FB. As of the midway point of last year
column42: there were26 million JapaneseFacebook subscribers. That's less than a 21% penetration rate for the company. Japan is actually an unheralded market: it has an incredibly educated
column43: tech savvy population.In many ways
column44: that's a better prospect for FB stock rather than activating developing or frontier markets because of the existing infrastructure.Click to EnlargeBut the really exciting potential is that when developing countries reach the next stage
column45: FB can spark a global revolution. Asia's total Facebook penetration rate is less than 14% - just marginally better than Africa. That means that the company's future is in Asian hands.The North American market is near realistic capacity at 62%
column46: while Latin America is not that far behind at 52%. Given the enormous economic growth in Asia
column47: that's not a bad gig for FB stock.While the rest of the world is focused on the transition of power at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue
column48: Facebook has been looking at a trend decades in the making. Indeed
column49: the movement is inevitable and will have far-reaching consequences well outside our lifetimes. They only thing any company can do is to prepare for it
column50: and FB has a substantial lead.As of this writing
column51: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy"" 2017The postAsia Will Take Over the World
column52: and Facebook Inc (FB) Wants Inappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Videogame Stock Roundup: Microsoft Reports Q2 Earnings
column2: Nintendo Launches Pokemon Go in South Korea;January 27
column4: 09:16:00 AM EDT;"Among the top stories this week
column5: Microsoft Corp.MSFTreported second-quarter fiscal 2017 results. In a separate development
column6: after almost a six-month delay
column7: South Korean gamers can now enjoy Pokmon Go as NintendoNTDOYlaunched the game officially in the country.Meanwhile
column8: Facebook IncFBzeroed in on Hugo Barra
column9: an ex-Xiaomi executive to spearhead its VR initiatives.Recap of the Developments1. Microsoft's second-quarter fiscal 2017 adjusted earnings of 83 cents and revenues $26.07 billion easily beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate. Though gaming is a very small part of the company's business
column10: Xbox is an important aspect of the overall video game industry. Microsoft's gaming revenues fell 3% (1% in constant currency). Xbox Live monthly active users were up 17% to 55 million. The company witnessed more than 26 billion hours of gameplay on Windows 10 PCs and tablets.The company's shares have surged 26% compared with the ZacksComputer-Softwareindustry's gain of 24.31% in the last one year.At present
column11: Microsoft carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks here.2. After a six-month delay
column12: Nintendo has now officiallylaunchedits blockbuster hit game
column13: Pokmon Go in South Korea
column14: on both Alphabet'sGOOGLPlay Store and Apple Inc.'sAAPLiOS store. Per media reports
column15: Nintendo's Pokmon Go works with Google Maps
column16: which has ""limited access"" in South Korea. Niantic had earlier sought permission from the South Korean government for access to Korean maps
column17: which was flatly refused. Google had not agreed to South Korean government's demand to ""blur"" sensitive locations like government buildings on Maps.Reportedly
column18: the denial stemmed from the fact that South Korea remains concerned about its national security. It doesn't share warm ties with its neighbor
column19: North Korea. The simmering border tension between the two nations has led the South Korean government to disallow storage of detailed maps of the country on any other servers except those in South Korea
column20: add media reports.It remains unknown how Niantic
column21: the firm which developed Pokmon Go
column22: bypassed the Maps issue
column23: add media reports. Niantic chose to remain silent on this issue during the press conference it held in Seoul on Jan 23
column24: 2017.Nintendo carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). The success of Pokmon Go helped the company's share price. Over the past one year
column25: its shares are up 55.86% compared with ZacksToys/Games/ Hobby/Productsindustry's gain of 18.42%.3. Meanwhile
column26: Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg in a post announced that ex-Xiaomi vice president
column27: Hugo Barra will spearhead all the company's VR initiatives as well as the Oculus unit. Zuckerberg further added ""Hugo shares my belief that virtual and augmented reality will be the next major computing platform. They'll enable us to experience completely new things and be more creative than ever before. Hugo is going to help build that future
column28: and I'm looking forward to having him on our team.""Facebook had acquired Oculus for $2 billion in 2014. With Oculus
column29: the company is trying to fuel its ambitious AR/VR efforts. Zuckerberg has time and again mentioned that VR is the next big business opportunity. Facebook has been pumping ample resources to boost its VR efforts. A few days back
column30: Zuckerberg said that Facebook was going to spend over $3 billion over the next 10 years.However
column31: Oculus has beenslappedwith a $2 billion lawsuit filed by video game company
column32: ZeniMax. Zuckerberg appeared in a Dallas courtroom to testify against the allegations. Apparently
column33: Zuckerberg has denied all allegations and stressed that ""The idea that Oculus technology is based on someone else's is just wrong.""At present
column34: Facebook has a Zacks Rank #2.  In the past one year
column35: Facebook's shares have generated a return of 39.92%
column36: compared with the ZacksInternet Servicesindustry's gain of 19.39%.PerformanceThe following table shows the price movement of the major video game companies over both the past five trading days as well as the last six months:CompanyLast 5 DaysLast 6 MonthsATVI1.34%-5.03%EA1.68%6.32%GLUU6.98%-3.77%MSFT2.50%13.23%NTES6.00%23.20%TTWO4.15%33.77%ZNGA-2.65%-10.76%Over the last five trading sessions
column37: Glu Mobile IncGLUUwas up 6.98% whereas Zynga IncZNGAwas down 2.65%.Over the last six-month period
column38: Take Two InteractiveTTWOsurged the most (33.77%). The company continues to benefit from its popular offerings like GrandTheft Auto V and Grand Theft Auto Online (though sales are slowing down)
column39: along with its other releases like NBA 2K17. In fact
column40: higher sales of the digital version of the games add to the company's margins. The company continues to expect growth in digital revenues driven by higher sale of full game downloads and increases in recurrent consumer spending.Computer and Technology Sector 5YR % ReturnComputer and Technology Sector 5YR % ReturnZynga was down 10.76% over the same time frame. Slowdown in its user growth remains a major concern. Moreover
column41: a slowing web business along with intensifying competition are added concerns. However
column42: its cost cutting initiatives are a positive. We expect the top line to be driven by its popular games likeWords With FriendsandPoker.Want to learn more about video game stocks? Make sure to check out our podcast below!Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: How Intel Corporation Can Strengthen Its Relationship With Apple Inc.;January 27
column4: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) scored a lucky break
column5: winning a significant   portion of the cellular modem orders for Apple's latest handsets   -- arguably the highest-profile smartphone win that Intel has   ever enjoyed.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Intel cellular modem chips
column6: branded the XMM 7360
column7: are found   inside versions of the iPhone 7 devices used on networks that   don't implement the CDMA cellular standard. Chips from rivalQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) are found in the iPhone models used on CDMA   networks
column8: as Intel's chips currently don't implement CDMA.Back in late 2015
column9: Intel purchased the CDMA chipset assets   from a company called VIA Telecom
column10: presumably in a bid to   allow the former to build chips that could address the entirety   of Apple's cellular modem needs.Though Qualcomm is widely believed to build superior modems to   what Intel produces
column11: Apple recently filed a lawsuit against   Qualcomm alleging
column12: among other things
column13: that ""Qualcomm has charged   Apple a monopolistic premium for access to CDMA chipsets that are   in all other aspects identical to chipsets sold to Apple without   CDMA functionality enabled. ... Qualcomm has used its monopoly   power in CDMA chipsets to obtain anticompetitive license and   chipset supply terms
column14: the complaint filed on Jan. 20 read.I'll be writing more on the lawsuit in the coming days and   today there is an observation I would like to share regarding   Apple
column15: Intel
column16: Qualcomm
column17: and CDMA iPhones.Apple's component costs could come down if Intel     succeeds in implementing CDMABased on this complaint
column18: we now know that Qualcomm charges   Apple more for the same exact cellular modems with CDMA enabled   compared to versions without CDMA enabled. This isn't an unusual   practice in the semiconductor industry; companies like Intel   routinely charge more for identical chips but with certain   features enabled
column19: compared with variants without those features   enabled. This is plain old product segmentation at work.Image source: Qualcomm.What's interesting is that Apple is complaining that
column20: because   Qualcomm essentially has no viable competition for its   CDMA-enabled modems
column21: it is charging a ""monopolistic premium.""The magnitude of this premium isn't clear
column22: but it's clear that   Apple isn't happy about having to pay it
column23: and therein lies the   opportunity for Intel.If Intel can develop a commercially viable LTE modem that also   supports CDMA (and is certified on all of the major CDMA   networks) using those VIA Telecom assets
column24: then this would open   the door to a couple of possibilities:Intel could win more than just the non-CDMA iPhones. It     could be a true ""second source"" for all the iPhones that Apple     ships. This could potentially boost Intel's share at Apple
column25: to     Intel's benefit (and to Qualcomm's detriment).Apple could be able to get cheaper CDMA modems from     Qualcomm. Even if Apple doesn't increase the proportion of     total modems that it purchases from Intel
column26: the fact that Intel     and Qualcomm parts would be viable for all iPhone models could     help reduce the average price that Apple pays per cellular     modem.Net-net
column27: Intel's becoming a stronger cellular modem provider   would mean that Apple should
column28: in general
column29: pay less for modems.   This could help modestly improve Apple's gross profit margin and
column30: ultimately
column31: net profit.To put this into perspective
column32: in the complaint
column33: Apple says   that LTE modems sell for between $10 and $20. Let's suppose that   Apple must pay $15 for the non-CDMA Qualcomm chips and then $20   for the CDMA-capable Qualcomm chips -- though with the iPhone 7
column34: Apple doesn't appear to be buying any non-CDMA Qualcomm chips;   the non-CDMA iPhones now use Intel.If Apple can get that $20 figure down to $15 in the presence   of a viable alternative from Intel
column35: then that's $5 saved across   potentially 100 million or more iPhone models sold in a year.   That $5 figure is for illustrative purposes only
column36: as I have no   clue what the actual delta is
column37: but multiplied across the volumes   that Apple sells
column38: the savings Apple could potentially realize are   significant.Intel needs to executeThe key to all of this is for Intel to execute to building   increasingly competitive cellular modems. If Intel can
column39: then   that's obviously a positive for Intel
column40: as an opportunity to sell   more modems
column41: and an opportunity for Apple
column42: in the form of cheaper   modems.The loser
column43: if Intel can supply more of Apple's volume --   whether or not it actually does -- would be Qualcomm
column44: as at the   very least it could see the premium that it enjoys from the sale   of CDMA-capable LTE modems evaporate.In the scheme of things
column45: though
column46: losing a bit more Apple chip   business probably isn't going to sting Qualcommthatmuch. After all
column47: Intel grabbed a bunch of iPhone share this   cycle
column48: yet Qualcomm's chip business appears to be on theright track.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip

column50: the newsletter   they have run for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12

column1: Should You Sell Qualcomm After Apple's $1 Billion Lawsuit?;January 26
column3: 08:52:00 PM EDT;"Shares ofQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) plunged 13% on Jan. 23 after the chipmaker was   sued for $1 billion by one of its biggest customers
column4: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . The lawsuit is related to the FTC's   separatelawsuit against Qualcomm
column5: which alleges that the chipmaker leveraged its portfolio of   critical wireless patents to force its baseband competitors out   of the market. Let's take a closer look at this tangled   mess
column6: and see if Qualcomm shareholders should sell their   shares.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Why is Apple suing Qualcomm?Back in 2008
column7: Sprintdeployed its first WiMax network
column8: a 4G standard which wasn't   heavily dependent on Qualcomm's patent portfolio.Intel(NASDAQ: INTC) championed the use of WiMax chips
column9: but   Qualcomm opposed WiMax in favor of its upcoming LTE standard --   which it could generate more licensing fees from.At the time
column10: Apple considered launching an iPhone for WiMax   networks. Realizing that the move could hurt its LTE ambitions
column11: Qualcomm agreed to pay Apple ""rebates"" for sticking with its   baseband modems and waiting for its LTE standard instead. Those   rebate payments were dependent on Apple doing two things --exclusivelyusing Qualcomm's chips (from 2011 to 2016)
column12: and notinstigatingany litigation which accused the chipmaker of unfair   licensing practices. The FTC claims that Qualcomm essentially   ""bribed"" Apple with those rebates to prevent it from switching to   competing chipsets.Over the past two years
column13: Qualcomm was hit with antitrust   probes worldwide
column14: which all allege that it charges unfair   licensing fees for its 3G/4G technologies. It was fined $975   million in China
column15: another $854 million in South Korea
column16: and could   face up to $3 billion in additional fines in Europe and   Taiwan. Apple claims that because it cooperated with   authorities in Korea during the investigation
column17: Qualcomm   retaliated by withholding $1 billion in rebate payments -- which   it's now suing to recover.The outcome is anyone's guess...The battle between Qualcomm and Apple will be a long and nasty   one
column18: since it's dependent on many shifting variables. First
column19: the   FTC lawsuit could be dropped if commissioner Maureen K.   Ohlhausen
column20: a Republican who voted against charging Qualcomm that   was just appointed the acting chairwoman by the Trump   Administration
column21: chooses not to follow through. If the case is   dropped
column22: the rebates should remain a valid business arrangement;   but if it isn't
column23: the rebates could be invalidated as ""bribes"" --   which may hurt both companies.Regardless of what happens with the FTC case
column24: Apple   needs to prove that it didn't violate the two main conditions of   its rebate agreement by using Intel modems or aiding the Korean   FTC during its investigation. Apple doesn't deny aiding the KFTC   at all -- it recently told CNN that it was merely   ""responding truthfully to law enforcement agencies"" instead of   ""instigating"" litigation against Qualcomm.Meanwhile
column25: Qualcomm must justify many of its opaque licensing   practices. Qualcomm charges royalties based on a device's   entire value
column26: instead of just the chips in the device -- a   practice that was already blocked by Chinese regulators. It also   charges licensing fees on 3G/4G handsets which don't use any of   its chips
column27: since  those devices still rely on its wireless   technologies -- although Apple argues that some of Qualcomm's   licensed patents don't actually cover those core technologies.   This means that Apple still pays Qualcomm fees on iPhones using   Intel modems (and also the Infineon modems it used in the past)
column28: and that those fees are likely higher due to the lack of   rebates.Understanding the risks to QualcommIf Qualcomm loses its cases against Apple and other   regulators
column29: it could be forced to change its entire licensing   model. That move would cause the QTL (licensing) business'   margins to wither and crush its earnings since the business   generates the lion's share of its profits.It could also jeopardize Qualcomm'splanned acquisitionofNXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI)
column30: which would make it the largest automotive   chipmaker in the world while expanding its patent portfolio. If   Qualcomm doesn't close that deal this year
column31: its top line will   remain heavily exposed to the commoditization of the smartphone   market and seemingly endless challenges against its licensing   business.But should you sell Qualcomm?Qualcomm faces plenty of legal headwinds
column32: but I believe that   the sell-off is a knee jerk reaction that has knocked the stock   down to irrational levels. Qualcomm now trades at 14 times   earnings
column33: as opposed to the industry average of 22. It also pays   a forward yield of 3.4%
column34: which is easily supported by a payout   ratio of 53%.As a Qualcomm shareholder
column35: I'm certainly disappointed with   recent developments. But I don't plan to sell my shares unless   the litigation either derails the NXP deal or forces Qualcomm to   dramatically reduce its licensing fees. Until then
column36: I'll still   consider Qualcomm a cheap (albeit riskier) dividend play with   solid growth prospects inadjacent marketslike connected cars
column37: drones
column38: and Internet of Things gadgets.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them! column1: Qualcomm's Earnings Call Dominated By Apple Lawsuit;January 26
column3: 05:49:00 PM EDT;"CEO Steve Mollenkopf. Image source: Qualcomm.Mobile chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) reported fiscal first-quarter results last night.   While the results as well as guidance mostly topped analyst   expectations
column4: Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) recent lawsuit against the company expectedly   dominated the subsequent earnings call (""Apple"" was mentioned 74   times). For good reason
column5: too
column6: since Apple is widely considered   Qualcomm's largest customer
column7: combined with the fact that the   lawsuit threatens Qualcomm's licensing model.makeArticleAd();Beyond a few brief statements
column8: this is the first time that   Qualcomm has commented publicly and in granular detail regarding   the suit. Here's what management had to say.Prepared remarksCEO Steve Mollenkopf first noted that the two companies have   historically had a strong relationship
column9: and Qualcomm intends to   ""remain a good supplier"" despite the legal complaint. The company   would naturally have preferred to settle its dispute with Apple   in private negotiations instead of litigation
column10: but it remains   confident that it can defend itself in court. Mollenkopf summed   it up: ""Apple's complaint contains a lot of assertions
column11: but in   the end
column12: this is a commercial dispute over the price of   intellectual property. They want to pay less for the fair value   that Qualcomm has established in the marketplace for our   technology
column13: even though Apple has generated billions in profits   from using that technology.""President Derek Aberle continued:Touching briefly on Apple's complaints filed in San Diego     and China
column14: it claims that Qualcomm should be required to     license its cellular standard essential patents
column15: or SEPs
column16: to     modem suppliers. That even when licensing those patents at the     device level
column17: Qualcomm should only be able to charge royalties     on the price of the cellular modem chip inside the device.These positions
column18: however
column19: are inconsistent with     long-standing industry practice
column20: the [intellectual property     rights] policies of the relevant standard-setting bodies
column21: the     realities of licensing large portfolios of patents
column22: and basic     notions of efficiency
column23: fairness in economics.Aberle points out that device-level licensing is utilized   throughout the industry by many major patent holders beyond   Qualcomm. (Apple is seeking chip-level licensing.) Qualcomm says   its patents also contribute to many other features in modern   smartphones beyond cellular connectivity
column24: further justifying   device-level royalties. Shifting to chip-level royalties would   then introduce different layers of licensing for all the various   chips that Qualcomm enables or sells itself
column25: so it licenses the   entire portfolio for the sake of efficiency.Apple says that there is no limit to the royalty rates
column26: which   is why it seeks per-unit royalty relief in the form of ""rebate""   payments. Aberle says this is untrue:In addition
column27: it is well known that Qualcomm has per-unit     running royalty caps as part of its licensing program. This     effectively results in licensees not paying running royalties     as a percentage of the device price above a certain net selling     price of any given device. Apple's claim that royalties are     uncapped is simply incorrect.Aberle also reiterated that Qualcomm believes Apple is   instigating these regulatory attacks as well as providing   inaccurate information:Apple claims that Qualcomm retaliated because Apple     cooperated with government investigations. To be clear
column28: we did     no such thing. We simply objected to Apple making false and     misleading statements and withholding information to motivate     attacks against Qualcomm. We welcome the opportunity to have     Apple's claims heard in court
column29: where we will be entitled to     full discovery of Apple's practices and a robust examination of     the merits. We will prove that Apple's irresponsible claims of     extortion are false.There should be no immediate impact to sales from the lawsuit
column30: either. Apple still needs modems
column31: and Qualcomm will still supply   them. CFO George Davis said
column32: ""We are not forecasting any impact   to revenues related to the dispute with Apple
column33: as we are   continuing to meet their supply needs in good faith and expect   Apple will continue to meet its obligations.""Questions and answersAs usual
column34: the analyst Q&A often provides more color.   Qualcomm affirmed that Apple does not have a direct license
column35: but   rather an indirect license through its contract manufacturers.   Qualcomm isn't worried about collecting
column36: said Aberle:Apple does not have a direct license with Qualcomm today.     And so the royalties on Apple products that get paid to     Qualcomm are reported and paid by their contract manufacturers.     So although we do have a dispute now with Apple and they are     challenging some of the offers and some of our licensing terms
column37: the contracts that we have in place with their suppliers remain     valid and enforceable. And we would expect that our licensees     will continue to comply with the terms of their agreements. And     we would also hope and expect that Apple would not interfere     with the terms of those agreements. But of course
column38: we can't     fully control those actions.When asked about the exclusivity and monopoly power   allegations
column39: general counsel Don Rosenberg (who incidentally used   to work for Apple a decade ago)
column40: downplayed the idea that   Qualcomm wields monopoly power:With regard to your question about so-called exclusivity     deal
column41: first of all
column42: we -- I think you called this monopoly     power or had monopoly power. We don't believe we have monopoly     power in the chip market or any other market. And nor do we     have an exclusivity arrangement. We have never prevented Apple     or anybody else from buying from competitive chipmakers. And in     the Apple case
column43: it's pretty clear since
column44: as you know
column45: they have     been buying fromIntelfairly recently. So it's a mischaracterization to call it an     exclusive dealing arrangement.This is a little murky
column46: since Applehadbeen exclusively buying basebands from Qualcomm for five years
column47: and only started buying from Intel after the alleged exclusivity   ended.Overall
column48: Qualcomm thinks Apple is simply trying to finagle   lower payments -- lower being beneath fair value as established   by its hundreds of other licensing deals with many companies over   the years. That risks somewhat oversimplifying Apple's complaint
column49: because Apple is also accusing Qualcomm of various forms of   anticompetitive behavior. Whether or not those allegations stand   up in court remains to be seen.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column51: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column6: 03:57:04 PM EDT;"Top Tech StocksMSFT +1.09%AAPL +0.12%makeArticleAd();IBM +0.11%CSCO +0.15%GOOG -0.50%Technology stocks fell for the first time this week
column7: with shares of tech companies in the S&P 500 slipping about 0.3% just before the closing bell on Thursday.In company news
column8: American depository shares of LG Display Co (LPL) have recouped all but a small slice of its prior decline Thursday in the wake of reports the South Korean manufacturer failed to receive orders from Apple (AAPL) for iPhone displays for the first time in nearly a decade.Instead
column9: Apple will be working with Samsung's display unit on its new iPhone 8 smartphone models
column10: according a report in the South Korea daily Maeil. LG Display lost the order because it did not respond fast enough to the migration from liquid crystal display to organic light-emitting diode technology
column11: according to the report.Mobile displays has accounted for a significant portion of LG Display's revenue in recent year
column12: growing to 27.9% of its $24.3 billion in total revenue during 2015
column13: the latest 12-month period that complete figures for the company were available.LPL shares were down just 0.4% at $13.29 apiece shortly before tonight's closing bell
column14: improving on a prior slide to a session low of $13.05 a share.In other sector news

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Be Planning a Second Belgian Store;January 26
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a new store coming to Belgian. Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();Belgian Store:A new rumor claims that Apple is preparing to start construction on its second store in Belgian
column6: reportsAppleInsider. According to this rumor
column7: the tech company is planning to build its new store in Bruges. A building at 96 Steenstraat is already under construction and the rumor claims it will house the new retail location. This rumor also claims that the new store won't be opening until sometime in 2018.macOS Sierra 10.12.4 Public Beta:The first public beta of macOS Sierra 10.12.4 is out
column8: MacRumorsnote. This new public beta allows users to try out new features being tested by developers before its official release. One notable new feature is Night Shift mode. This allows users to set their Mac displays to shift colors as the day progresses and daylight wanes. This beta comes out just a couple of days after developers got their hands of the first macOS Sierra 10.12.4 beta.iOS 10.3 Public Beta:Apple fans can now check out the first iOS 10.3 public beta
column9: reports9to5Mac. The new beta is available for iPhone
column10: iPad and iPod devices. It includes the new Find My Airpods feature. This feature allows users to better keep track of AAPL's new wireless earbuds. There have also been several other small changes included in the beta. One major feature expected is Theater Mode. This is listed as coming in the next watchOS beta and that update may reveal the feature on iOS.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Be Planning a Second Belgian Storeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY) DTEK70: Game-Changer or Non-Event?;January 26
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe rumor mill is spinning again withBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY). Code-named ""Mercury
column5: the next BlackBerry device
column6: DTEK70
column7: will reportedly get a Feb. 25 launch date. And BBRY stock holders probably do not care at this point.makeArticleAd();Source:WEi WEi via FlickrBlackBerry is rebranding itself as a software company
column8: but its stock is up a mere 4.3% in the last year. By comparison
column9: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is up nearly 25% in the last year whileNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK)
column10: which exited the Windows Phone market and focused on networking
column11: fell 33%.Still
column12: the DTEK70 release is important for BBRY.BlackBerry and TCL PartnershipBlackBerry outsourced its entire hardware development and manufacturing withTCL. Early signs are positive that ""Mercury"" will win customers
column13: especially in the business space. BlackBerry said that it is 100% indevelopingsoftware solutions. TCL's ""Mercury"" build offers a secure Android operating system and has a physical keyboard. The company earns IP and royalty revenue for each device TCL sells.On its conference call in December
column14: BlackBerrydescribedthe TCL deal:This licensing model allows BlackBerry to generate ongoing high margin royalty revenue from a device software based on the number of units sold. We have a pipeline of additional opportunities that are focusing on
column15: including a late discussion in India that are ongoing.""Decent Price to PerformanceBlackBerry priced the budget DTEK50 in the right range but did not win the mainstream market. DTEK60 demonstrated the company's ability to make a solid
column16: high-performance phone at mainstream prices. DTEK70 is even more practical for business users.Rumoredto run on aQualcomm
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) Snapdragon 635 or Snapdragon 821
column18: the device will have just 4.5 inches of screen real estate.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryThis is the magic number for DTEK70: The device may sell for around just $350. At that price and size
column19: business users who crave for higher productivity will snap up this phone when it is launched.Profit MarginBlackBerry CEO John Chen will not allow the company to sell devices at a loss. Assume profit margins in the range of 25%-50% for TCL. When the costs of software development are included
column20: the profit margin for BBRY may run above 50%-60%.Launch DateOn its blog
column21: BlackBerry said it will give more details about the smartphone at the Mobile World Congress show. The event runs from Feb. 27 to March 3.Interest in ""Mercury""+ ""BlackBerry"" jumped:Click to EnlargeSource:tickertags.comGame Changer or More of the Same?Past BlackBerry Android devices did not give the company much revenue growth. In the third quarter
column22: the $172 million in software services revenue accounted for 57% of the company's revenue.The TCL licensing deal
column23: though
column24: is a game-changer for the software company. DTEK70's development costs are all shouldered by its partner. BlackBerry gets a cut in the sales through the software licensing. High profit margins from software sales will translate to more profits for the company.The one big catch is that BBRY and TCL must advertise and promote this upcoming device. BlackBerry made $12 million in operating income in the third quarter.Profit Model for DTEK 70Assuming TCL pays a 10% royalty on the profits of the $350 device
column25: or $20 per device
column26: BlackBerry could earn the following:Units Sold per quarterProfit100
column35: 000Selling 500
column36: 000 units a quarter would match the company's third-quarter operating income.3 Reasons to Buy Ford Motor Company (F) Stock on This DipBottom Line on BBRY StockThe smartphone market is still wide-open for small players like BlackBerry. Previously released Android devices demonstrated the company could deliver on supplying a highly secure
column37: bug-free operating system. The inexpensive DTEK70 targets the business user.With the rumored price and phone specifications
column38: BlackBerry may have an unexpected winner.As of this writing
column39: Chris Lau was long BBRY. Follow him onTwitter.More From InvestorPlace10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You Back7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeShould You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros

column1: Should You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros
column4: 12:27:55 PM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you bought and held stock inMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) at the height of the dot-com run
column6: it's been an unpleasant 16 years. However
column7: after a long wait
column8: MSFT stock finally reached a new all-time high last month. Despite the tech world changing drastically in the ensuing years
column9: Microsoft's PC dominance lives on
column10: minting money for the company.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrThe company's various new efforts over the years have mostly been flops. There's a reason Microsoft stock has performed poorly; efforts such as Windows phones simply haven't panned out. However
column11: it seems Microsoft has finally turned the corner.It is making real headway in several promising areas
column12: including its cloud offering. And investors have cheered
column13: sending Microsoft's stock up sharply since 2013. Can the good times continue
column14: or will buyers up at these levels be in for another long decade?MSFT Stock ConsHuge Stock Run-Up: Since 2013
column15: MSFT stock has more than doubled. At first glance
column16: that seems fine
column17: the market has performed strongly in recent years after all. However
column18: Microsoft is so large
column19: that it becomes hard to achieve further such doublings. With a market cap just under $500 billion today
column20: even one more double takes Microsoft to a trillion dollar market cap. It's worth asking what the company has going from a growth perspective that could justify such a lofty figure.Sure
column21: the company has some growth initiatives under way. The cloud offering is going well. And the LinkedIn acquisition may start to bear more fruit. But after watching the stock run from under 30 in recent years to over 60 today
column22: you have to ask how much more upside really makes sense
column23: particularly since the company has had near non-existent revenue growth lately.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsHigh Valuation:First things first
column24: MSFT stock isn't really trading at a 30 price-earnings ratio. I know that's what financial websites report. However
column25: that's based on GAAP figures that include one-off losses related to restructuring. On an adjusted basis
column26: Microsoft is trading in the mid-20s
column27: and at 21 times forward earnings. However
column28: even that doesn't paint a flattering picture for the company. Microsoft traded at 12 times earnings or less over much of the past decade. Is Microsoft worth paying twice as much for now?Sure
column29: the PC market has stabilized
column30: but it isn't likely to ever be a meaningful growth driver again. And the newer initiatives such as cloud seem likely to take years to reach strong profitability. At 21 times forward earnings
column31: MSFT stock is pricing in some serious growth prospects that may well not materialize.Questionable Deal-Making:Microsoft has a reputation for making some head-scratching M&A moves. The less said of the aQuantive purchase and the Nokia buy
column32: the better. Those two alone resulted in almost $14 billion of write-offs. And the recent LinkedIn deal raises questions. Microsoft paid $26 billion for LinkedIn
column33: and offered a massive premium to where shares where trading previously. At the price Microsoft paid
column34: it offered around 30x free cash flow for LinkedIn. On an earnings basis
column35: LinkedIn was still losing money.Sure
column36: Microsoft can cut some costs there
column37: particularly for stock-based compensation
column38: but it's still a massive price tag. And with Microsoft having such a huge war chest on its balance sheet
column39: the temptation will surely be there for the company to make other huge value-destructive deals.MSFT Stock ProsPC Market Stabilizing:For quite a few years now
column40: the traditional PC market appeared to be in serious decline. Sales peaked in 2011
column41: with364 million unitssold that year globally. Since then
column42: sales have plunged. By 2015
column43: sales dropped 24% from that peak year
column44: falling to just 275 million units. And 2016 showed another solid decline
column45: with sales reaching just 260 million units. However
column46: the worst may now have passed. 2020 projections are for 250 million units sold
column47: only a fractional decline from current levels.And themost recent datasupports this further moderation: sales slipped just 1.5% versus the same period last year. And in several areas globally
column48: including Canada and Japan
column49: PC sales are actually increasing again. One possible reason
column50: the rate of forward technological progress has slowed for both tablets and smartphones
column51: reducing pressure on consumers to switch to smaller screens. A stable market would be great news for MSFT stock.Partnership With Qualcomm:Microsoft has partnered withQualcomm
column52: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) for their Internet of Things efforts. Qualcomm has entered conflict withIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) at first over the IoT market. In the longer-run
column53: Qualcomm may use its chips to even forcefully attack Intel's long-held dominance in the PC market. In any case
column54: Microsoft benefits nicely from partnering up with Qualcomm.The IoT offerings born from this venture will help spread Windows 10 outside of just the traditional PC market. And given the shellacking that QCOM stock took earlier this week followingApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) lawsuit against the firm
column55: Qualcomm has reason to deepen ties with friendly partners. As an industry outcast
column56: Qualcomm needs whatever help it can get
column57: and if Microsoft can use that to expand Windows as a broader OS
column58: all the better.Solid Dividend Option:Microsoft has quietly turned into a nice yield choice for more conservative investors. The company has tripled its dividend since 2008. In total
column59: it's posted 16%
column60: 18% and 16% dividend growth rates over the past three
column61: five and ten years. While the payout ratio currently looks a little high
column62: that's based on abnormally soft recent earnings. Make no mistake
column63: there is plenty of room left here for more dividend increases. The company has an astounding $137 billion in cash on its balance sheet. Even after subtracting out debt
column64: the company has a net cash position of $62 billion
column65: leaving plenty of firepower for increased dividends
column66: share buybacks or acquisitions.VerdictMSFT stock is a decent selection if you're purely concerned with its yield and safety. The company's main PC business is looking healthier than it has in quite awhile. The balance sheet is tremendous. The dividend is significant at today's level
column67: and is bound to keep rising quickly.Here's Why Chevron Corporation (CVX) Stock Is the Best Play in OilHowever
column68: there's little to recommend Microsoft on valuation. The stock is expensive
column69: even when you look closely. Microsoft has plenty of growth initiatives in the works
column70: but actual operating results recently have only been so-so. When buying stocks at all-time highs
column71: you want to see a business with more operating momentum.At the time of this writing
column72: Ian Bezek held INTC and QCOM stock. He had no position in Microsoft. You can reach him on Twitter at @irbezek.More From InvestorPlace3 Energy ETFs That Will Keep Soaring3 Brokerage Stocks That Love Donald Trump's Big Tweetin'The postShould You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros
column73: 3 Consappeared first onInvestorPlace."
