column1: Better Buy: Advanced Micro Devices
column4: 11:30:00 AM EDT;"NXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI) andAdvanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ: AMD) both operate in the semiconductor industry. That's   about as far as their similarity goes. One is a rising star in   embedded solutions and automotive computing
column5: heading into a $47   billion merger with sector giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) . The other is an eternal underdog in the PC   market that's working on a dramatic turnaround right now.Which chip stock is a better fit for your portfolio? Let's   find out.The heart of the matterThe choice between AMD and NXP boils down to two simple   questions:makeArticleAd();Do you expect Qualcomm's buyout of NXP to run into any     issues in the regulatory review phase? If so
column6: NXP shares should     fall when the merger is deep-sixed and AMD should be the     obvious investment pick.Otherwise
column7: NXP becomes a simple ticket to 14% returns by     the end of 2017. Can AMD beat that 11-month payoff?Is NXP's deal safe?I have often said that the Qualcomm-NXP combinationlooks like a lock. The two companies share very few customers and end markets
column8: so   this merger is not likely to create any sort of monopoly.   Regulatory roadblocks would have to focus on the sheer scale of   the buyout. Moreover
column9: President Donald Trump is paving the way to   easier megamergers by nominating anti-regulation candidates to   many key government roles. So
column10: this buyout should be a   cakewalk.Unfortunately
column11: that high-odds risk has suddenly become more   likely.Last week
column12: Qualcomm was served a lawsuitfrom major customerApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column13: wherein the iPhone maker claims that the   chipmaker has been playing extortion games with its component   supply chain.Qualcomm shares fell as much as 14% on the news
column14: and some   analysts expect the lawsuit to delay the NXP deal. Renewed   scrutiny of Qualcomm's business practices could block   rubber-stamp deal approvals in important territories such as   China
column15: Taiwan
column16: and South Korea.The Apple charge will also divert management attention and   other assets from the NXP process. If nothing else
column17: the final   approval might be pushed into 2018 or beyond.This is a real risk for the NXP merger
column18: but I still expect the   final signatures to be delivered by the end of the year. This   business combination is too important to let it slide out of   view. And don't forget that regulatory intervention would lead to   Qualcomm sending a $1.25 billion breakup fee NXP's way.Your mileage may vary
column19: which is fine. But if you agree with my   analysis
column20: NXP remains a near-certain 14% return from here
column21: and   AMD needs to show a stronger hand than that.Image source: Getty Images.What can AMD do?Let's cut to the chase: AMD shares could go absolutely   anywhere in 2017. That's enough to keep my finger away from the   buy button.The chipmaker had a fantastic year in 2016. AMD introduced a   new graphics chip architecture to rave reviews
column22: promised an   equally game-changing update to its CPU portfolio in 2017
column23: andsaw share prices quadruple. AMD's chart has cooled down a bit in January
column24: falling back 12%   as the company prepares for a fourth-quarter report next week.   But that's still a lot of market momentum. Share prices could   keep skyrocketing in 2017 if the company continues to deliver on   its next-generation technology promises.That's a bigif
column25: though. AMD does not have a great track record when it comes to   dependable execution
column26: and often falls far short of ambitious   goals. Recently appointed CEO Lisa Su has been a breath of fresh   air so far
column27: but she is battling the fallout from nearly a   decade's worth of less-successful predecessors.If AMD's momentum runs out
column28: the stock has a long way to fall.   AMD's trailing earnings and EBITDA profits are negative
column29: and free   cash flows stand at a razor-thin $148 million. Lacking the   support of traditional valuation builders
column30: the stock chart would   take a dramatic nosedive in a hurry on the slightest of   errors.AMD owners can win big or lose big here. That's a poker chip
column31: not an investment thesis.By contrast
column32: NXP offers a near-guaranteed 14% return. Even if   the Qualcomm deal falls apart
column33: there's a quick $1.25 billion cash   payment in it for NXP investors.This one isn't a close call. I would take NXP over AMD in a   heartbeat.10 stocks we like better than Advanced Micro     DevicesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Advanced Micro Devices     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column38: 2017Anders Bylundhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool     has the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple     and short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends NXP Semiconductors. column1: Earnings Preview: Can Apple
column4: 10:36:00 AM EDT;"Scheduled to report results for its first fiscal quarter of   2017 on Tuesday
column5: Jan. 31
column6: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)  will show whether it has returned to revenue   growth. With trailing-12-month revenue down 8%
column7: even a small   year-over-year increase in Apple's first-quarter revenue would be   a nice change.Here's a preview of the earnings report as well as some   background on a few key areas worth checking in on when the tech   giant reports results.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.The numbersMetricQ1 2017 Guidance*Q1 2016Year-Over-Year ChangeRevenue$77 billion$75.9 million1.4%Earnings per share$3.17$3.28(3.4%)Gross profit margin38.25%40.1%(185 basis points)Fiscal quarters shown. Asterisk indicates figures are based on   midpoint of guidance ranges provided for management. Data for   chart retrieved from Apple's quarterly earnings releases. Table   by author.After reporting three quarters straight of year-over-year   declines in revenue
column8: Apple expects about a 1.4% year-over-year   increase in revenue in its first quarter. But despite   expectations for higher revenue
column9: management anticipates a 3.4%   earnings decline as its profit margin is negatively impacted by   currency headwinds
column10: higher cost structures for new products
column11: and   an unfavorable comparison due to a $548 million award from a   patent infringement in the year-ago quarter.3 key areas to watchBeyond Apple's first-quarter revenue
column12: EPS
column13: and gross profit   margin
column14: investors should look at iPhone sales
column15: guidance for   Apple's second quarter
column16: and services revenue growth.1. iPhone sales:Accounting for 63% of Apple's trailing-12-month revenue
column17: the iPhone segment is undoubtedly the company's most important   business. The segment dwarfs its other segments
column18: which represent   11% or less of trailing-12-month sales.iPhone 7. Image source: Apple.So
column19: what can investors expect from iPhone sales? Given Apple's   guidance for its overall results and the influence of the iPhone   segment on total results
column20: investors should expect similar iPhone   revenue and unit sales this year since Apple is only guiding for   a 1.4% increase in total revenue. In the year-ago quarter
column21: iPhone   revenue was $51.6 billion and iPhone unit sales were 74.8   million.2. Guidance:One of the quarter's most insightful metrics will be the   guidance Apple provides for its second quarter. With this figure
column22: investors will get to see whether management expects more revenue   growth.Given that the iPhone 7 didn't stick to Apple's usual biannual   schedule for form factor overhauls
column23: it's possible the company   could return to year-over-year declines in the second quarter.   But until it provides guidance
column24: there isn't any clear indication   of what investors should expect for the trajectory of revenue   beyond its first quarter.3. Services revenue growth:One segment that could help drive surprising growth is the   services segment
column25: which includes sales from the App Store
column26: iTunes
column27: Apple Music
column28: iCloud
column29: Apple Pay
column30: licensing
column31: and other   services. In the most recent quarter
column32: services revenue was up an   impressive 24%
column33: hitting a record $6.3 billion. Growing to   13% of Apple's revenue in the quarter
column34: services is now its   second-largest segment. If the segment benefited from a   significant holiday boost in the first quarter
column35: the growing   segment may play a key role in helping Apple's overall revenue   this year -- possibly even serving as the key factor for   preventing further declines in total revenue.In its most recent quarter
column36: year-over-year services revenue   growth accelerated from 19% in the third quarter of fiscal 2016   to 24% in its fourth quarter. Look to see if Apple can maintain   this higher growth rate achieved in its fourth quarter.In addition to the first-quarter report after market close on   Jan. 31
column37: management will host a live conference call to discuss   results at 2:00 p.m. PST.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Stock Market News for January 24
column4: 10:10:00 AM EDT;"All the key U.S. indexes fell on Monday following rising uncertainties regarding Trump's economic policies. However
column5: benchmarks pared some of yesterday's losses after the President announced to reduce financial regulations and corporate taxes. Separately
column6: record rise in U.S. rig counts weighed onoil prices
column7: which in turn dragged energy stocks. Additionally
column8: investors swallowed mixed bag of earnings results.For a look at the issues currently facing the markets
column9: make sure to read today'sAhead of Wall Streetarticle.The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) decreased 0.1%
column10: to close at 19
column11: 799.85. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% to close at 2
column12: 265.20. The tech-laden Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 5
column14: losing 2.39 points. The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) advanced 2% to settle at 11.77. A total of around 6.15 billion shares were traded on Monday
column15: in line with the last 20-session average. Advancers outpaced declining stocks on the NYSE. For 52% stocks that advanced
column16: 44% declined.What Weighed On the Benchmarks?The 45thU.S. President announced that the U.S. has formally exited from the Trans-Pacific Partnership
column17: a trade deal with eleven other Pacific Rim nations. Moreover
column18: during the weekend Trump announced that he will meet with his Mexican counterpart Pena Nieto and the Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Trump's ""protectionist"" approach raised uncertainty among investors over his policies.This in turn had a broad-based negative impact on key U.S. indexes. However
column19: Trump stated that his administration may slash regulations by 75 percent or ""maybe more
column20: which helped markets trim some of the losses.Separately
column21: oil prices fell on Friday after Baker Hughes Incorporated (BHI) reported that U.S. oil and gas rig counts rose by 35 to 694 rigs last week
column22: its biggest increase in almost six years. The U.S. oil rig count also increased by 29 rigs to 551
column23: its biggest increase in less than four years. Both WTI and Brent crude fell 0.9% and 0.5% to $52.75 per barrel and $55.32 a barrel
column24: respectively.Additionally
column25: shares of Halliburton Company (HAL) fell 2.9% after its fourth-quarter revenues missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate. However
column26: the world's No. 2 oilfield-services company posted better-than-expected quarterly earnings. (Read More)Decline in oil prices and fall in Halliburton led the Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE) to fall 1.1% and was the worst performing sector in the S&P 500. Key stocks from the sector including Transocean Ltd. (RIG) and Schlumberger Limited (SLB) fell 3.6% and 2.6%
column27: respectively. Both the companies possess a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks here.In other company news
column28: Qualcomm Incorporated's (QCOM) shares plunged 12.7% after it has been pressed with a $1 billion lawsuit by tech giant Apple Inc. (AAPL). The lawsuit was related to licensing royalty payments. Decline in Qualcomm weighed on the tech-based index Nasdaq. (Read More)Shares of McDonald's Corporation (MCD) fell 0.7% after its same-stores sales in the U.S. decreased 1.3% during last quarter. However

column1: Should You Buy Valeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Stock? 3 Pros
column4: 09:52:23 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsValeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc(NYSE:VRX) has imploded over the past 18 months. VRX stock is down nearly 95% since it peaked in 2015. The company has made a fool of many famous investors
column6: including famed activist Bill Ackman. What was once one of Canada's most exciting growth companies now sits at death's doorstep.Source:Wikimedia (Modified)With its market cap down to below $5 billion now
column7: the question has become existential. Can Valeant survive? Or will it end up in bankruptcy court?makeArticleAd();For investors in VRX stock
column8: it's a matter of handicapping. Valeantcouldbe a multi-bagger if it survives. However
column9: there's a good chance the stock ends up at zero. Thus
column10: what's an investor to do?Let's look at the pros and the cons for VRX stock to decide.VRX Stock ConsImploded Business Model:Ackman famously loaded up his huge position in VRX stock on the basis of ""platform value."" This was the idea that Valeant was worth a great deal due to its ability to keep acquiring new drugs. Once Valeant acquired a new drug company
column11: it typically would raise prices for the acquired drugs while slashing R&D spending and other overhead. This made for fantastic margins.Valeant borrowed heavily to make these acquisitions using the assumption that drug prices could continue rising indefinitely. This assumption
column12: however
column13: proved false following increasing scrutiny toward the sector from 2015 onward. VRX also engaged in some questionable business behavior
column14: including using gray-area specialty pharma operations to push drugs at high prices. This window of opportunity has shut. Valeant has greatly limited capacity to raise drug prices going forward
column15: and it doesn't have financial capacity to make further acquisitions.10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You     BackNeed to Sell Assets:In fact
column16: the opposite is true. Valeant is having todumpassets. And a forced seller rarely gets top dollar for their goods. For a year now
column17: Valeant management has talked up imminent asset sales. Rumors of aSalixsale for as much as $10 billion sent VRX stock flying.But that rumor
column18: as with most such Valeant rumors
column19: amounted to nothing. Valeant did manage to sell two smaller non-core businesses early in January
column20: leading to a smaller pop in VRX stock. But that quickly gave way. The EBITDA multiples
column21: particularly for theDendreonunit
column22: received on the asset sales do not appear high enough to justify the company's current valuation. Valeant likely has to sell more assets to avoid breaching debt covenants. And based on the past year's efforts
column23: it could be difficult to sell more properties at acceptable prices.Huge Debt Load:Valeant sports about $30 billion in debt
column24: against a minimal cash position. And virtually all of this debt is due no later than 2022. A sizable chunk matures in 2018.Thus
column25: Valeant is racing against the clock to come up with cash before it has to make good on its debt obligations. If lenders are generous
column26: the company may be able to roll some of its debt over
column27: though the interest rate would probably be unfavorable. Otherwise
column28: it will have to sell yet more assets to stay liquid in the short-term.VRX Stock ProsAsset Sales a Step in the Right Direction:While there is much more work to be done
column29: Valeant's asset sales earlier this month are a clear positive. The company likely will have enough cash to make it through to 2018. Many prominent bears were suggesting that Valeant would go bankrupt in 2017. That looks significantly less likely now.While VRX has much more to do
column30: $2.1 billion is certainly a step in the right direction. The Dendreon business they sold was of low quality
column31: and they appear to have gotten a decent price for it
column32: all things considered. And the business they sold toL'oreal SA (ADR)(OTCMKTS:LRLCY) went at a solid price
column33: though it was one of Valeant's highest-quality assets.Heavy Bearish Involvement: Valeant has attracted numerous short sellers. As of data from December 31st
column34: there are 29 million shares of VRX stock that have been sold short. That constitutes more than 11% of the total float. Since at least August
column35: short sellers have maintained a short position in excess of 25 million Valeant shares.Numerous big-name short sellers
column36: such as Citron Research and John Hempton of Bronte Capital
column37: have devoted numerous time to blasting the company. Hempton tends tomake commentssuch as: ""Valeant deserves to go bankrupt - and will go bankrupt unless the goodwill of bond holders and pharmaceutical payers is forthcoming.""7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeThese are talented market operators
column38: and there's a decent chance they'll be proven right. But if not
column39: bears may find themselves stuck in a position that changes character on them. Bill Ackman isn't the only pro to ride a position for too long on occasion.Better Drug Market Optics?President-elect Donald Trump will take office shortly. He's made some prickly remarks about the drug industry over the past few months
column40: notably saying that pharma is ""getting away with murder."" That sounds bad. However
column41: so far at least
column42: he still appears more moderate on the issue. Hillary Clinton took to Twitter on various occasions to call out individual pharma companies and/or their executives.Trump's repeal-and-replace rhetoric is a question mark for the healthcare industry. But it's an improvement from what would almost certainly have been a painful four years for pharma stocks had the alternative occurred. Healthcare performed worst of the S&P 500's 10 sectors last year. Unless Trump's words turn into concrete action against the drug companies
column43: there is a good chance that sentiment picks up later this year in the sector.VerdictVRX stock seems appealing as a sort of high-risk high-reward play on the surface. Shares are way down off the peak. The company seems to have put the worst behind it
column44: and is starting to make the right moves on asset sales and new management direction. But oh what a hole they had dug for themselves.Valeant is in a race against the clock
column45: and they need a lot of things to go correctly to avoid bankruptcy. There is too high a chance of the company failing before the cycle turns for me to consider this as anything more than a long-shot speculation.As of this writing
column46: Ian Bezek did not hold a position in any   of the aforementioned securities. You can reach him on   Twitter at @irbezek.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Suit Against Qualcomm

column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Will Hit All-Time Highs Soon;January 24
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSome of the reports covering the record-breaking quarter ofAlibaba Group Holding Ltd.(NYSE:BABA)
column5: announced before the market opened on Jan. 24
column6: were just a bit misleading. Luckily
column7: those trading BABA stock weren't fooled.Source: ShutterstockA 26% fall in earnings? Maybe
column8: if you squint right
column9: and you're looking for something to criticize
column10: you can argue that earnings fell short.makeArticleAd();But that was entirely due to investments made in digital media that will come back over time. And the growth in digital media sales
column12: was a star of the earnings show. Entertainment even grew faster than the company's cloud computing operations
column13: and total revenue was up 54%.If this is miss
column14: I'll take it.Investors agree. Pre-market trading had BABA stock up to almost $102 per share
column15: or about 4% higher. It's still short of 2016's high of $107 per share
column16: and well short of the $115 per share achieved in early 2015.But right now those records look due to fall.Several Moving PiecesAlibaba has several moving pieces
column17: anda detailed earnings releaseoffered real insight into them.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksWhat the release reveals is that if you're thinking of Alibaba as strictly a play on China
column18: you're thinking wrong. The fastest-growing segment of the business is ""international commerce
column19: cross-border trade
column20: mostly between China and other countries in East Asia
column21: which was up 288% year-over-year
column22: to $353 million
column23: 4% of total revenue. That's even faster than digital entertainment grew.Chinese commerce still represents 80% of revenue
column24: but that's down from 86% a year earlier
column25: even though retail sales were up 42% and wholesale sales were up 30%. It's that wholesale number that is the heart of the original company. Alibaba
column26: unlikeAmazon.com
column27: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column28: with which it is so often compared
column29: was founded to enable business-to-business commerce
column30: opening up global markets for small Chinese producers.Taken together
column31: Alibaba had GAAP net income of $2.471 billion ($1 per share) and revenue of $7.669 billion. Just as Amazon remains a fraction of the size ofWal-Mart Stores
column32: Inc.(NYSE:WMT)
column33: in other words
column34: Alibaba is a fraction of the size of Amazon.But BABA is growing faster.Where Does BABA Stock Grow From Here?While Alibaba does seek to replicate most of what Amazon does
column35: including its movies and cloud operations
column36: at the heart of the growth story lies trading.Trading is profitable. You don't have to buy what someone else is trading
column37: just handle the logistics - the online elements
column38: the transaction elements
column39: the movement and warehousing. Thus
column40: Alibaba has been able to deliver regular profits at a stage where Amazon could not
column41: and this remains the case.Non-GAAP earnings of $1.30 per share easily beat the analyst estimates of $1.13
column42: and even the whisper number of $1.16. The big numbers remain in consumer commerce within China
column43: dominated this quarter by a record-setting ""Singles Day
column44: but the big growth is in other areas.That growth is spectacular. With its latest quarter
column45: Alibaba raised its own growth estimates for the year
column46: from 48% to 54%.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Steals AI Expert Back From     Apple Inc. (AAPL)Combine Alibaba's bulk in commerce with its growth in international trade
column47: entertainment and cloud
column48: then add in executive chairman Jack Ma's unique ability to straddle the fence between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Donald Trump
column49: and you get an investment story that's hard to beat. Yes
column50: the price-to-earnings multiple of 52 looks rich
column51: and it's going up on these numbers

column53: Intime
column54: or its work on artificial intelligence.If you want a piece of that
column55: the time to buy is now.Dana   Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. His latest novel   isBridget O'Flynn vs. Something Big & Ugly.Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing

column1: Apple's Supplier Foxconn to Set Up Manufacturing in U.S?;January 24
column4: one ofApple Inc.'sAAPLbiggest suppliers
column5: Foxconn Technology Group is thinking of setting up a manufacturing plant in the United States. Though the exact details aren't available
column6: Foxconn is interested in investing over $7 billion in setting up such facilities in the U.S.Analysts note that that tech companies usually do not have manufacturing operations in the U.S because of higher labor costs involved than other regions like South East Asia. Apple has been subject to intense focus of President Donald Trump regarding this issue.Throughout his campaign
column7: Trump opposed Apple's decision to manufacture goods overseas and even promised that he will urge Apple to bring manufacturing jobs back to the country. Trump was quoted speaking to The New York Times in Nov 2016
column8: ""One of the things that will be a real achievement for me is when I get Apple to build a big plant in the United States
column9: or many big plants in the United States
column10: where instead of going to China
column11: and going to Vietnam
column12: and going to the places that you go to
column13: you're making your product right here.""Apple Inc. PriceApple Inc. Price|Apple Inc. QuoteIn fact
column14: to alleviate Apple's concern of increased prices of finished products
column15: Trump told the company's CEO Tim Cook that he will provide tech companies huge tax cuts.These promised incentives seem to have succeeded in attracting manufactures. Foxconn CEO Terry Gou was quoted saying ""If US state governments are willing to provide these terms
column16: and we calculate and it is cheaper than shipping from China or Japan
column17: then why wouldn't Sharp build a factory in the US?"". Foxconn bought the majority stake in Sharp Technologies
column18: which supplies display panels for many major smartphone brands
column19: last year for $3.5 billion.Per Verge
column20: this new facility could be in collaboration between Apple and Foxconn as Gou said that Apple
column21: too
column22: needs the display panels. The facilities could create 30 to 50K jobs in the U.S
column23: something which Trump has been so focused on. However
column24: Verge quoted Gou saying that manufacturing in the U.S will make prices go up as much as $500. So will consumers be happy about it?Moreover
column25: analyst also remain wary as it could mean taking China head on. Setting up manufacturing in the U.S. will deprive China of many million manufacturing jobs and surely the Chinese government won't be very happy about it. Foxconn has over 12 factories in China and Chinese workers form a majority of its 1.5 million strong workforce.Gou stressed that these plans are not ""promise"" but a ""wish"" and there is also a possibility that it might not work out at all. Apple made no comment on the development.Apparently
column26: Apple is mulling to bring back manufacturing jobs to U.S. A few days back it was reported that Apple requested the government to allow it to use its Mesa
column27: AZ facility to conduct ""high-tech manufacturing"". Apple had asked Foreign Trade Zones Board to allow it to manufacture ""finished products and foreign status materials/components"". This is because ""production under FTZ procedures could exempt Apple from customs duty payments on the foreign-status materials/components used in export production.""Per a Business Insider report
column28: citing sources familiar with the matter
column29: Apple will be using the Mesa facility to ""build and configure servers"" and then send it to other data center sites in the U.S. like Oregon and North Carolina. The Mesa manufacturing facility was set up by Apple in 2013 and was leased to a supplier to manufacture sapphire screen covers. However

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Steals AI Expert Back From Apple Inc. (AAPL);January 24
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe smart home market continues to heat up
column5: andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) is determined to stay in the race. After releasing the Google Home AI-powered smart speaker and Google WiFi mesh router system
column6: the company is now turning its attention toNest.Source: NestIn an effort to reboot its pioneering smart home products division
column7: Alphabet has hired back Yoky Matsuoka
column8: an AI and robotics expert who had been working for rivalApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();The former Nest vice president will return as the new Nest CTO.Rebooting the Nest MessNest has had a pioneering role in the smart home. Before being acquired by Google in 2014 for $3.2 billion
column9: the company had helped kick off an entire industry with theNest Learning Thermostat.The smart thermostat delivered on a promise to automate home temperatures
column10: learn homeowners' preferences for different times of the day and to save money on heating and cooling. It did this while being user-friendly; you didn't need to be an engineer or an electrician to install and set it up. It also introduced a chic new look to the lowly thermostat. Nest went on to branch out into smart smoke and CO detectors before being acquired by Google.Things atNest began to go sideways under Google's ownership. TheDropcampurchase involved drama around canceled products and employees quitting over cultural clashes.10 Companies That Are Bringing Jobs Back to     AmericaNest failed to deliver the home security system Google was anxiously awaiting - in fact
column11: the division has failed to releaseanynew products since being acquired (just revisions of existing gear plus those Dropcam cameras). It got mired in a PR disaster after buying theRevolvsmart hub
column12: then shutting it down
column13: effectively bricking devices that had already been bought. The division fell short of Alphabet's revenue targets.The situation culminated with the departure of Nest founder and CEO Tony Fadell.New Nest CTO Is a Familiar FaceNest has been operating under a new CEO since last summer
column14: but Alphabet is clearly trying to kick-start the division. The threat posed byAmazon.com Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa-powered Echo smart speaker is very real. Despite being late to the game and lacking a smartphone platform
column15: Amazon has vaulted into a smart home leadership positionwith Alexa able to interact with thousands of products and services.That smart home market is projected to be worth over $121 billion by 2022
column16: so being top dog is a very big deal.Bloomberg is reporting thatAlphabet has hired a key executiveto take on the crucial CTO role at Nest. An AI and robotics expert
column17: Yoky Matsuoka was a co-founder of Google's X research division. She left Google to become a VP with Nest and is credited for the Nest Learning Thermostat's adoptive technology.She jumped ship from Nest after the Google acquisition and last year landed at Apple
column18: where she led teams working on the HealthKit
column19: CareKit and ResearchKit medical health initiatives. Sheleft Apple for unknown reasons in December
column20: but now
column21: the new gig at Google looks like the most probable culprit.According to Bloomberg
column22: Matsuoka becomes Nest's new CTO. Her responsibilities include:Defining a long-term technology roadmap for Nest   products.Identifying advanced technology such as new sensors that   could be incorporated into Nest products.Identifying opportunities for collaboration within   Alphabet.Pursuing partnerships with third-party companies.In other words
column23: Matsuoka will find out where Nest is going
column24: how it can leapfrog the competition
column25: ensuring Nest products integrate with the goals and capabilities of other Alphabet products
column26: and extending Nest's reach as a smart home platform.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Suit Against Qualcomm
column27: Inc.     (QCOM) Is the Real DealWill the new CTO be able to help whip Nest back into shape and get new products out the door? Will she be able to take the spotlight away from Amazon's Echo and Alexa
column28: returning Nest to a position of smart home leadership?She has the credentials
column29: and Alphabet certainly seems to think so.As of this writing
column30: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Tuesday: Apple Inc.     (AAPL)

column1: How Microsoft Has Changed in the Past 3 Years;January 24
column3: 08:40:00 AM EDT;"Satya Nadella became CEO ofMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) about three years ago
column4: with his formal appointment   coming on Feb. 4
column5: 2014. It was an inspired pick that also   represented a change in tone from previous boss Steve Ballmer.   What wasn't known at the time is just how radically Nadella would   divert from the strategies of his predecessor and founder/CEO   Bill Gates before him.Nadella wasn't another member of the old guard taking over. He   wasn't a Gates disciple who'd been around since the early days of   the company in the mid-1970s
column6: but having started in 1992. He did   have a strong base of knowledge about where the company was and   where it needed to go. When he took over
column7: he made it very clear   that changes were coming and they were going to come quickly.""Microsoft is one of those rare companies to have truly   revolutionized the world through technology
column8: and I couldn't be   more honored to have been chosen to lead the company
column9: Nadella   said in apress releaseat the time. ""The opportunity ahead for Microsoft is vast
column10: but to   seize it
column11: we must focus clearly
column12: move faster
column13: and continue to   transform. A big part of my job is to accelerate our ability to   bring innovative products to our customers more quickly.""makeArticleAd();Those remarks would prove prescient
column14: as it's fair to say   Nadella quickly changed how Microsoft does business. It was a   radical remake that turned a still-successful tech dinosaur into   a company built for the future as well as the present.Microsoft has changed dramatically in three years under   Nadella. Image source: Microsoft.How has Microsoft changed?Under Gates and Ballmer
column15: Microsoft operated in a closed   ecosystem. The company wanted people to buy Windows computers
column16: so   it generally kept its products inside that system. There wereApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) Mac versions of Office
column17: but even those weren't   updated nearly as often as the Windows versions -- and they only   succeeded because so few options existed.Trying to keep everything in the Windows world backfired on   Microsoft when iOS and Android phones and tablets exploded. Not   having key products such as the various Office programs in the   two major app stores started teaching a generation of younger   folks that there were alternatives.Nadella quickly changed that. In November 2014
column18: he brought the   signature productivity suite to Apple iOS and Android devices. In   addition
column19: the company offered up free versions of programs   including Word
column20: Excel
column21: and PowerPoint that allowed for viewing   documents
column22: as well as some limited editing.These moves
column23: which the new CEO pushed through
column24: also helped   Microsoft change its business model for these programs. Rather   than pushing Office as a one-time sale
column25: the company moved users   toward subscriptions. That was made much easier by Microsoft's   newfound willingness to allow consumers to use Office on whatever   device they wanted
column26: instead of just Windows machines.A different companyIf Microsoft had kept the walls up
column27: it probably would have had   a long future as a steadily shrinking business selling to a core   group of business users. With its new strategy
column28: the company has   been able to introduce Office
column29: Skype
column30: and even Windows to a new   generation while creating a steady flow of subscription revenue.   For example
column31: revenue for Office 365
column32: the name for the   subscription plan
column33: was up nearly 70% in Q2 2016.In addition to opening up the company's products to Apple and   Android products
column34: Nadella has also been a decisive leader. He   made the bold decision to scrap Windows 8 and distance the   company from it by moving right to Windows 10 -- a revamp that   brought back many well-liked features. He was also quick to back   away from the Windows Phone
column35: even if that meant admitting that   the company largely wasted $7.6 billion buyingNokia's devices division.Nadella has also been a strong champion of innovation at his   company. He supported the struggling Surface hybrid
column36: which has   slowly become a strength for Microsoft. In addition
column37: the CEO has   backed HoloLens
column38: a future-looking platform that could help bring   virtual and augmented reality into the mainstream.Microsoft is hip nowCompared with Apple
column39: Microsoft was always square. That's why   the old ""I'm a Mac/I'm a PC"" commercials worked. Now
column40: under   Nadella
column41: Microsoft no longer feels the same. It still may not be   quite as hip as Apple
column42: but the Windows maker has gained some   ground
column43: and its media events now also contain surprises
column44: like the   SurfaceBook laptop.In three years
column45: the new CEO has taken his company from one in   decline to one that has a bright future. Some moves
column46: such as   Microsoft's growing cloud business
column47: can also be credited to   Ballmer
column48: but opening up the company's products to all platforms   has changed the company's trajectory by exponentially opening up   its potential audience.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of   them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Nintendo's Pokemon Go Makes a Late Entry in South Korea;January 24
column3: 08:25:00 AM EDT;"makeZacksArticleAd();After a six month delay
column4: Nintendo Co LtdNTDOYhas now officially launched its blockbuster hit game
column5: Pokmon Go in South Korea
column6: on both Alphabet'sGOOGLPlay Store and Apple Inc.'sAAPLiOS store.Per media reports
column7: Nintendo's Pokmon Go works with Google Maps
column8: which has ""limited access"" in South Korea. Niantic had earlier sought permission from the South Korean government for access to Korean maps
column9: which was flatly refused. Google had not agreed to South Korean government's demand to ""blur"" sensitive locations like government buildings on Maps.Reportedly
column10: the denial stems from the fact that South Korea remains concerned about its national security. It doesn't share warm ties with its neighbor
column11: North Korea. The simmering border tension between the two nations has led the South Korean government to disallow storage of detailed maps of the country to be stored on any other servers except those in South Korea
column12: add media reports.It remains unknown how Niantic
column13: the firm which developed Pokmon Go
column14: bypassed the Maps issue
column15: add further media reports. Niantic chose to remain silent on this issue during the press conference it held in Seoul on Jan 23
column16: 2017.Nintendo Co. PriceNintendo Co. Price|Nintendo Co. QuoteDennis Hwang
column17: Niantic's design director was quoted saying ""Niantic is a young startup run by a small team. We had not expected that 'Pokemon Go' would receive such explosive popularity worldwide
column18: and needed time to 'take a breath. For a team of our size
column19: it took a lot of time for us to prepare and localize the game for the Korean market
column20: including translating the game's contents into Korean and such.""Developed by Niantic in association with The Pokmon Go company
column21: a subsidiary of Nintendo
column22: Pokmon Go has been a monster hit. Though the success of the game didn't directly benefit Nintendo's financials
column23: we believe that it has strengthened the Japanese video game publisher's position in the lucrative mobile games space. It was created by Niantic in association with Nintendo. Consequently
column24: most of the benefit was netted by Niantic.Over the past one year
column25: the success of Pokmon Go has cushioned its share price
column26: which is up 56.63% compared with the Zacks Toys/Games/ Hobby/Products industry's gain of 14.86%. However
column27: the last few months haven't been pretty good for Nintendo. The launch details of its anticipated console
column28: Switch caused share price to plummet. Even the revival of NES classic
column29: despite a warm reception
column30: suffered a massive inventory problem. Reportedly
column31: Nintendo hasn't been able to supply NES units
column32: which makes it a very hard find
column33: thereby affecting its sales prospects.Over the last three months
column34: Nintendo's shares price has fallen 12.20% compared with the broader industry's decline of 6.82%.At present

column1: Intercept Pharmaceuticals Inc (ICPT) Stock Could Be Biotechs Grand Slam;January 24
column4: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsThe market has begun 2017 trading sideways
column5: but don't let that   fool you into thinking there aren't opportunities out there
column6: especially in biotech. We're in a period of a consolidation
column7: which means as profits are being taken and forcing stocks lower   in some parts of the market
column8: cash is coming off the sidelines to   buy the dips. Eventually
column9: it will spark the next move higher.As many of you may know by now
column10: I like to make sure my   portfolio is well positioned ahead of that move by investing in   only the best companies out there. One such company - which is   trading at a discount right now - isIntercept Pharmaceuticals Inc(NASDAQ:ICPT).makeArticleAd();I'vetalked about ICPTbefore. It's a biopharmaceutical company focused on treating   progressive non-viral liver diseases
column11: and millions of Americans   suffer from fatty liver disease.7 Straight-A Stocks to Build Your Portfolio       AroundThat sort of market opportunity gives this biotech the   potential to be a grand slam
column12: in my opinion. Fatty liver disease   is when fat accounts for more than5% to 10% of the organ's weight. I think it's the American health crisis of the 21st century
column13: and it's simply the result of Americans becoming fatter.Intercept's lead product is Ocaliva. It wasgranted accelerated approvalby the Food and Drug Administration in May 2016 for the treatment   of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)
column14: and is the first PBC   therapy that targets the farnesoid X receptor (FXR).The company is also currently evaluating Ocaliva - or   obeticholic acid (OCA) - for potential uses across a variety of   additional chronic liver diseases
column15: including nonalcoholic   steatohepatitis (NASH)
column16: primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and   biliary atresia. Intercept owns the worldwide rights to OCA   outside of Japan
column17: China and Korea.Now I will add the caveat that this biotech stock is a   higher-risk idea. It's likely gotten ahead of itself over the   years
column18: but the fact that the shares rallied to $460 in 2014   underscores the ultimate potential here.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Suit Against Qualcomm
column19: Inc.       (QCOM) Is the Real DealSure
column20: there will be competition. And there have definitely   been some execution issues. However
column21: I think the company will   clear those hurdles in time with three applications (PBC
column22: PSC and   NASH) currently in or beyond Phase II and III FDA trials.The stock is currently in a double-bottom formation
column23: and a   bounce through $125 could lift ICPT up toward $175 in the next   year. Over the very long term
column24: and certainly with some bumps   along the way
column25: I still think this could be a $400 stock.Curious what Wall Street insider Charles Payne really       thinks?Get more behind-the-scenes insights

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Had to Get In Bed With Qualcomm Because of Verizon;January 23
column4: 08:45:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.In the iPhone's early years
column5: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) bought baseband modems from Infineon
column6: which was   later acquired byIntel. The original iPhone launched as anAT&Texclusive
column7: and AT&T's 3G network is built on GSM. The Mac   maker was still paying licensing fees toQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)
column8: as all cellphone makers around the world must
column9: starting in 2007 with the original iPhone.makeArticleAd();But things got a lot more complicated in 2011
column10: which is when   Apple and Qualcomm really took their relationship to the next   level. It's because ofVerizon(NYSE: VZ) .It all started because of Big RedThat was the year that Applefinally launchedthe iPhone on Big Red's network
column11: ending Ma Bell's exclusivity   that was costing Verizon subscribers; the iPhone was a powerful   exclusive device that compelled many subscribers to switch. From   Apple's perspective
column12: Verizon is the largest carrier in the U.S.
column13: so of course it wanted access to that subscriber base. Even   though Verizon's 3G network uses CDMA
column14: the cellular technology   that Qualcomm helped pioneer
column15: and CDMA is less common in other   parts of the world
column16: Apple still recognized that it should offer   more variants of the iPhone in order to expand its addressable   markets worldwide.It's worth noting here that China
column17: which became the world's   largest smartphone market the following year in 2012
column18: also uses   CDMA or variants of CDMA for 3G wireless service.Here's an excerpt from Apple's complaint (emphasis added):Apple has been indirectly paying Qualcomm licensing fees     since 2007
column19: when it released the iPhone.Apple became even more reliant on Qualcomm in 2011 due     to Apple's desire to release an iPhone that could connect to     CDMA networks
column20: such as Verizon's.For many years
column21: Qualcomm ensured that it was the only possible     supplier of CDMA chipsets
column22: and it remains so today for the     chipsets used in Apple's flagship iPhone product line. As a     monopoly supplier of an essential input
column23: Qualcomm had the power     to constrict and disrupt chipset supply
column24: which (coupled with     Qualcomm's refusal to enter into industry-standard supply     agreements that would have guaranteed supply to Apple
column25: absent     unusual or unforeseen circumstances) would have been disastrous     to Apple's business.Considering Qualcomm's dominance in CDMA
column26: both in terms of its   patent portfolio as well as baseband chips
column27: Apple had no choice   but to get in bed with the mobile chip giant. For years
column28: it   seemed as if the pair had a strong and mutually beneficial   relationship evidenced by ongoing exclusivity. But what we now   know is that behind the scenes
column29: Apple was incredibly unhappy but   also contractually obligated to keep quiet. The Mac maker now   says that it was continuously forced into ""undesirable
column30: one-sided
column31: and unreasonable contract terms.""Ultimately
column32: it was still probably worth it
column33: considering the   iPhone's multiyear growth run that only just ended in 2016. That   growth was fueled by both tapping the largest U.S. carrier as   well as expanding internationally

column1: The 3 Stocks Most Hedge Funds Own;January 23
column3: 07:07:00 PM EDT;"Many hedge funds delivered disappointing returns last year.   The Eurekahedge Hedge Fund Index
column4: which tracks the top hedge   funds in the market
column5: rose just 4.4% in 2016 -- underperforming   the  S&P 500's 11.2% gain.The performance of individual funds varied greatly
column6: but top   investors likeWarren Buffettnoted that the market was saturated with too many hedge funds
column7: and that their high fees made them poorer investments   than basic index funds.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Nonetheless
column8: investors still like to see what the ""big boys""   own
column9: and  BarclayHedge's third quarter report on hedge fund   holdings reveals three well-known tech stocks are at the top of   their shopping lists --Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column10: Facebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column11: andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .AppleForty-five of the top hedge funds owned Apple during the third   quarter. That might seem surprising since the tech giant's   iPhone
column12: iPad
column13: and Mac sales all  declined annually last   quarter
column14: and analysts expect its revenue and earnings to   respectively rise just 6% and 8% this year.But despite those speed bumps
column15: Apple still generated $52.3   billion in free cash flow over the past 12 months
column16: held $20.5   billion in domestic cash at the end of 2016
column17: and stashes over   $200 billion overseas. This means that Apple could easily   diversify away from its core hardware products by buying up more   companies or investing in new projects.Over the past 12 months
column18: Apple repurchased $29.2 billion in   shares and paid out $12.2 billion in dividends. That equals a   yield of just 1.9%
column19: but its payout ratio of 26% means that it   could boost that payout to attract income investors. Apple's P/E   of 14
column20: which is lower than the industry average of 17
column21: also makes   it a safe value play in a volatile market.FacebookForty-three of the top hedge funds owned Facebook during the   quarter. Facebook is a great growth play because it's the   800-pound gorilla of the social networking market and is   disruptingAlphabet's business of traditional display ads.Last quarter
column22: Facebook's monthly active users (MAUs) rose    16% annually to 1.79 billion and its revenue surged 56% to   $7.01 billion. Advertising accounted for 97% of its top line
column23: and   84% of that came from mobile platforms. Its net income also   surged 166% to $2.38 billion. With those robust growth figures in   mind
column24: Facebook's trailing P/E of 61 -- which is higher than the   industry average of 50 -- doesn't look terribly expensive.   Looking ahead
column25: analysts expect its revenue and earnings to   respectively rise another 52% and 80% this year.Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. Image source: Facebook.But Facebook isn't resting on its laurels. It's still   expanding into adjacent markets like virtual reality with Oculus   and 360-degree videos
column26: machine learning with a dedicated AI unit   (FAIR)
column27: and even solar-powered drones for beaming internet   connections to rural and low income regions. Those moves could   all help Facebook grow beyond its core social networking and   advertising business.Amazon.comForty-one of the top hedge funds owned Amazon
column28: which dominates   the e-commerce and cloud infrastructure markets. Over the past   few years
column29: Amazon expanded its e-commerce ecosystem with Prime
column30: which locks in customers with free shipping
column31: discounts
column32: and   digital perks. It's further expanded that ecosystem into homes   with devices like the Kindle
column33: Fire TV
column34: Echo
column35: Dash
column36: andDRS-enabled appliances.That's a low-margin business
column37: but the higher profitability of   AWS (Amazon Web Services) -- the biggest cloud platform in the   world -- offsets those losses. Last quarter
column38: AWS' operating   income more than doubled annually to  $861 million
column39: which   offset an operating loss at its international marketplace unit   and boosted its total net income by 219% to $252 million.   Analysts expect Amazon's earnings to grow 282% this year and 85%   next year.That's why analysts currently expect Amazon's revenue and   earnings to respectively grow 28% and 282% this year. Based on   those growth estimates
column40: Amazon's trailing P/E of 185 and forward   P/E of 93 don't look that pricey.The key takeawayHedge funds often buy the same stocks because they're safe   picks. They're more likely to buy Apple
column41: Facebook
column42: and Amazon   instead of lesser-known small cap stocks with higher growth   potential. That herd-like mentality is common on Wall Street
column43: but   I believe that these three stocks are still solid core holdings   for any tech investor.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column1: Welcome Back
column4: 05:09:00 PM EDT;"Not this Apple TV. Image source: Apple.Hello there
column5: old friend. Gosh
column6: how long has it been? It must   bealmost two yearsby now.makeArticleAd();Speculating onApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) building a TV set used to be a favorite pastime   among investors and analysts. Sadly
column7: the company reportedly   abandoned those plans a few years ago
column8: after spending nearly a   decade contemplating and researching the idea. Well
column9: the   speculation is back with a vengeance. TheWall Street JournalandNikkei Asian Revieware reporting that Apple's dominant manufacturing partner   Foxconn is thinking about investing in a massive $7 billion U.S.   factory that would create some 30
column11: 000 domestic   jobs.What's sparking the speculation is that Foxconn Chairman Terry   Gou told reporters yesterday that the facility would be producing   ""larger display panels."" Apple would be investing jointly in the   facility. The logistics costs for shipping large display panels   is much higher
column12: so it makes a little bit more sense to   manufacture them in the U.S. It's not clear how large of panels   we're talking about.Cue the rumor mongersApple has already confirmed that it is exiting the standalone   display market. The company finally discontinued the aging   Thunderbolt Display last year
column13: and instead of updating or   launching a new model Apple chose to collaborate withLG Electronicsto design a couple 4K and 5K UltraFine displays that complement   the new MacBook Pros.Beyond MacBooks
column14: the only other Apple products that have   relatively large displays are iMacs
column15: which come in 21.5-inch 4K   and 27-inch 5K display sizes. Back in 2012
column16: Apple made a push   with U.S. manufacturing for both the iMac and Mac Pro. A portion   of iMac production was relocated to the U.S. at the time. In the   years since
column17: it's unclear if Apple has continued domestic   production of its flagship all-in-one; it's possible that the   company quietly shifted iMac manufacturing back to China. The Mac   Pro is still assembled stateside in Austin
column18: Texas
column19: although Apple   wouldprefer to shiftthat manufacturing back abroad too if it weren't for the current   political climate.The point here is that there are no other Apple products that   would need a domestic supply of large panel displays
column20: so the   market
column21: as it likes to do
column22: has starting dreaming.Two years later
column23: it still doesn't make senseHere's the thing: Apple can accomplish most of its TV   ambitions without making a full TV set. That's essentially why   Apple chose not to pursue a TV set a couple years ago
column24: since the   TV business is not a particularly attractive business in general;   margins are razor-thin
column25: commoditization occurs rapidly
column26: inventory   risk is significant
column27: and pricing power is virtually nonexistent   (a function of commoditization).There's little upside or potential for differentiation that   can be realized through deeper integration with TV hardware
column28: mostly since Apple can still innovate on the interface level with   software through its existing set-top box Apple TV. It can -- and   reportedly has tried -- also try to introduce TV services like   slimmer over-the-top cable packages without getting too involved   on the hardware side.I don't know what Apple's up to
column29: but I doubt that it's   resurrecting its TV ambitions.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Energous Corp (WATT) Stock Bombs After Brutal Report;January 23
column4: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsEnergous Corp(NASDAQ:WATT) stock is only for the crazy ones
column5: as it continues a   roller-coaster movement that has seen the stock edge out a gain   of 5.1% this year. Today
column6: WATT stock is getting hammered
column7: albeit   gently
column8: for a stock that traders usually swing violently by the   hind legs.Shares of Energous were chugging along with the rest of the   broader market
column9: when suddenly WATT stock took a turn for the   worst
column10: dropping more than 5% in the span of minutes. The unlikely   culprit? A report published onSeeking Alphaentitled""Energous Corporation: Game Over.""makeArticleAd();Certainly
column11: opinionated news like that can't budge a behemoth   likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column12: but for the $338 million Energous
column13: any news is a vine for   stock traders to swing on.But Seeking Alpha's report is a doozy
column14: alleging that Energous   is in way over its head and WATT stockholders are equally   clueless:""Nonetheless
column15: logic and facts have thus far failed to   influence a retail investor base suffering from the most extreme   cognitive dissonance we have witnessed since Uni-Pixel or OCZ   Technology Group. The WATT bull case has eschewed substance
column16: and   instead focused on the ""tea leaves"" of an Apple iPhone 8 wireless   charging design win.""It wasn't long ago that WATT stock saw a huge surge based on a   speculated partnership with Apple Inc.
column17: which SA believes to be   the only bull case for Energous - ""an iPhone 8 wireless charging   design win.""10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy""       2017However
column18: Apple's latest patent filing are at odds with this.   In its more than 16 patent applications for wireless charging
column19: SA   notes that Apple is focused on inductive charging
column20: not the   RF-based technology used by Energous:""This novel approach would eliminate today's wireless charging   pads that require devices maintain specific points of contact and   orientation. Apple diagrams clearly illustrate how iPhones and   iPads will elegantly turn an entire surface into an inductive   charging platform.""Energous' charging is slightly different
column21: allowing for   wire-free charging through the air on any number of devices in   the room. The tech in question is also a regulatory hurdle that   WATT has yet to pass
column22: as it hasn't been shown to not be a health   detriment.At any rate
column23: SA's report rightly concludes that Apple is   rarely a first-mover
column24: and that its inductive tech
column25: while in the   works for some time
column26: is likely to be revealed alongside the   iPhone 8.IDTI
column27: a supplier of inductive wireless charging chips for Apple's   Watch andSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column28: has previously mentioned Apple's intent to use its own tech   for iPhone wireless charging.The harshest reality
column29: however
column30: is Apple's dismissal of WATT's   technology as ""inefficient"" and a health hazard (due to radiation   no less) in a 2013 patent application for desktop wireless   charging.Free Profits in Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock       After EarningsEnergous stock was down 4.01% as of the close  but I'd   expect the WATT stock bulls to continue undeterred for the most   part.$WATTtook this pic a few years ago

column1: Apple
column2: Inc.'s Lawsuit Is a Fundamental Threat to Qualcomm's Entire Business Model;January 23
column4: 02:13:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.There's really no way to overstate how importantApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) unprecedented lawsuit againstQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) is. It's not an exaggeration to say that the   complaint
column5: which was filed last Friday evening
column6: represents a   fundamental threat to Qualcomm's entire business model. It makes   sense then that Qualcomm shares have gotten absolutely crushed   today
column7: down by as much as 14% in the morning.makeArticleAd();For starters
column8: Apple's suit has more teeththan the regulators'. Qualcomm has been able to negotiate and   settle other antitrust complaints from regulatory agencies all   around the world
column9: mostly behind closed doors. This usually   entails paying a fine and/or agreeing to reform some of its   business practices. On the other hand
column10: Apple is unlikely to go   away so quietly
column11: especially as the Mac maker feels as if it has   been coerced into silence all these years while paying what it   considers to be ""extortion-level"" royalties. While possible
column12: I   don't think Apple has any interest in settling this suit quietly
column13: and the outcome of the case will affect Qualcomm's other   customers.This is why Apple's case is so much bigger
column14: despite the fact   that the immediate financial implications are comparable. Apple   is initially seeking $1 billion that it is already owed
column15: which   isn't too much larger than the regulatory fines that Qualcomm has   been paying. Qualcomm paid $975 million in 2015 to settle with   China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC)
column16: and   South Korea's Fair Trade Commission fined Qualcomm $853 million   just a few weeks ago.Combined with Samsung
column17: Apple and its suppliers represented 40%   of all of Qualcomm's revenue last fiscal year. That's actually   down from the 49% of sales that the companies collectively   represented in fiscal 2014.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Fiscal years   shown.Being sued by your biggest customer is never a good thing
column18: but   having your biggest customer allege that your entire business   model is flawed is about as bad as it gets.""Double-dipping""Qualcomm sells chips while also simultaneously licensing its   patent portfolio and collecting royalty revenue. Apple believes   that this is an illegal form of ""double-dipping"" where Qualcomm   is able to get paid twice. In patent law
column19: the ""patent exhaustion""   doctrine
column20: which is also known as the ""first sale"" doctrine
column21: states that a purchaser of a product that uses patented   technology automatically receives a license to use or   subsequently resell that product
column22: and the patent holder should   not be able to pursue downstream customers or companies for   additional royalties
column23: since they've already been paid based on   the first sale.Yet this is precisely what Qualcomm does: It sells chips to   Apple contract manufacturers that are used in iPhones
column24: while   separately requiring licensing deals from those same suppliers.   Qualcomm gets paid twice
column25: even though when it sells chips it   should be automatically conferring the rights automatically. The   licensing business isincredibly profitable
column26: with an earnings-before-tax (EBT) margin of 85%. The chip   business has an EBT margin of just 12%. If the court agrees with   Apple
column27: Qualcomm's licensing business has a lot of potential   downside.But at what cost?The royalties that Qualcomm charges are also based as a   percentage of the final sales price
column28: another practice that Apple   argues is inappropriate. Another concept in patent law is that   royalties should be based upon the ""smallest salable unit
column29: instead of based on the entire product's value. As Apple points   out in its suit
column30: modern smartphones have become increasingly   advanced over the years with more and more features. The cellular   connectivity that Qualcomm's patents facilitate are a shrinking   portion of the total product's value. It makes no sense that   Qualcomm should collect more when customers pay extra for a   larger display or more storage
column31: but that's exactly what Qualcomm   does even though those functions are entirely unrelated to   cellular connectivity.Simply put
column32: Apple wants to pay royalties based on the chips it   buys
column33: which it argues are the ""smallest salable unit."" Apple pays   about $10 to $20 per baseband processor. The percentages that   Qualcomm charges are rather high
column34: too. While the company   typically negotiates each licensing deal separately
column35: its 2015   agreement with the NDRC sheds some light. From the most recent   10-K (emphasis added):In February 2015
column36: we reached a resolution with the National     Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) in China regarding its     investigation and agreed to implement a rectification plan that     modifies certain of our business practices in China. The     rectification plan provides
column37: among other things
column38: that for     licenses of only our 3G and 4G essential Chinese patents for     branded devices sold for use in China starting on January 1
column39: 2015 (and reported to us in the third quarter of fiscal 2015)
column40: we will charge running royalties at royalty rates of 5%     for 3G CDMA or WCDMA devices (including multimode 3G/4G     devices) and 3.5% for 4G devices that do not implement CDMA or     WCDMA (including 3-mode LTE-TDD devices)
column41: in each case using a     royalty base of 65% of the net selling price.Analysts estimate that Apple has been paying Qualcomm roughly   $15 per iPhone in royalties
column42: probably net of the ""rebates"" that   Qualcomm provides in exchange for exclusivity. Using the terms of   the NDRC agreement would imply a royalty about $21 on a $650   iPhone (which is a multimode 3G/4G device). Qualcomm actually   offered Apple comparable terms. But Apple
column43: beingno stranger to patent litigationand licensing
column44: balked at the terms. From Apple's complaint   (emphasis added):In 2015
column45: Qualcomm made an ""offer"" to Apple to license     Qualcomm's Chinese 3G/4G declared-essential patents on terms     purportedly ""consistent"" with those that resolved an inquiry by     Chinese regulators into Qualcomm's licensing practices
column46: called the ""National Development and Reform Commission     resolution"" (""NDRC resolution"" or ""rectification plan"" for     short).Apple immediately rejected the proposalbecause it was not [fair
column47: reasonable
column48: and non-discriminatory]
column49: was excessive as compared to other licenses to cellular     [standard-essential patents] Apple negotiated at arm's length
column50: and was of limited value to resolving the parties' worldwide     licensing dispute.Since Qualcomm has also been allegedly been tying chip sales   to licensing deals
column51: while also pricing chips above competitive   prices
column52: the chip business is also threatened by all of this. In   no uncertain terms
column53: this lawsuit is a massive deal with major   implications on Qualcomm's business.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column54: it can pay to listen. After all
column55: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column56: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column57: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column58: 2017Evan Niu
column59: CFAowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: iOS 11 May Introduce New Feature to FaceTime;January 23
column4: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a new feature coming in iOS 11.   Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.iOS 11:A rumor claims that Apple will be adding a new   feature to FaceTime with the introduction of iOS 11
column6: reportsBGR. According to this rumor
column7: the tech company is planning to   introduce support for multiple video calls at once to FaceTime in   iOS 11. The rumor also claims that AAPL will be putting forth   efforts to expand the social media services available with   FaceTime. This may include adding filters and other such features   that are present on other social media apps.makeArticleAd();macOS Sierra 10.12.3:Apple has officially released macOS Sierra   10.12.3 to the public
column8: MacRumorsnotes. One of the notable changes with the release of macOS   Sierra 10.12.3 is a fix for graphic issues with the 15-inch   MacBook Pro released late last year. It also fixes issues   and bugs that were present in the previous version of the   operating system. AAPL also notes that this update ""improves the   stability and security"" of Macs.iOS 10.2.1:Apple has also released iOS 10.2.1 to the   public today
column9: 9to5Macnotes. The new version of iOS that is now available to the public   shares the same build number as the last beta that was sent out   to developers. This means that developers won't have to update   their devices. The update doesn't appear to contain any   major new features. It most likely just includes bug fixes and   improves stability. There is already talk that an iOS 10.3   beta is on its way.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: iOS 11 May Introduce New   Feature to FaceTimeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Sprint to Purchase 33% Stake in Jay Z's Tidal;January 23
column4: wireless carrierSprintSannouncedit will be purchasing a 33% stake in the streaming music serviceTidal
column5: owned by hip-hop mogul Jay Z.While Sprint did not say when the acquisition would be finalized
column6: the new deal is part of a partnership between both companies where Sprint customers will receive exclusive Tidal content. Sprint has about 45 million retail customers.Jay Z
column7: as well as the group of artist-owners who helped introduce Tidal and who are involved in operations
column8: including Beyonc
column9: Madonna
column10: Kanye West
column11: and Alicia Keys
column12: will continue to run the service. Sprint CEO Marcelo Claure will join Tidal's board.We'll do great things with@Sprint& can't wait to share our exclusive experiences with their 45 million customers.https://t.co/NFRCLgrneLpic.twitter.com/Szffu8W12W- TIDAL (@TIDALHiFi)January 23
column13: 2017""The passion and dedication that these artist-owners bring to fans will enable Sprint to offer new and existing customers access to exclusive content and entertainment experiences in a way no other service can
column14: said Claure in a statement.""Sprint shares our view of revolutionizing the creative industry to allow artists to connect directly with their fans and reach their fullest
column15: shared potential
column16: Jay Z said in a statement. ""Marcelo understood our goal right away
column17: and together we are excited to bring Sprint's 45 million customers an unmatched entertainment experience.""Jay Z bought Tidal two years ago for $56 million
column18: but despite exclusive content and early access to high profile releases like Beyonc'sLemonade
column19: the streaming service has been overshadowed by its two main rivals
column20: Spotify and Apple'sAAPLApple Music. Even its subscriber count has come under question by music industry analysts. This deal with Sprint
column21: then
column22: may be the lifeline Tidal needs.Sprint had originally toyed with purchasing a large stake in Tidal back in 2015
column23: but eventually walked away from any formal deal. And just last year
column24: rumors swirled that Apple was thinking of acquiring Tidal in order to give Apple Music a little boost.Stocks that Aren't in the NewsYetYou are invited to download the full

column1: Midday Update: Wall Street Defensive With Investors Spooked by Trump's Views on Trade;January 23
column3: 12:40:25 PM EDT;"The benchmark indices were in negative territory Monday as nervous investors sorted through recent comments from President Trump regarding trade
column4: taxes and federal regulations.In his inaugural speech Friday
column5: Trump warned that ""we must protect our borders from the ravages of other countries...as protection will lead to great prosperity and strength"" prompting risk-adverse investors
column6: fearful of a trade war with Asia
column7: to dump equities in favor of safe-haven assets like precious metals and government securities.As a result
column8: Dow decliners outnumbered advancers by six to one led by heavy losses in General Electric (GE) which continued to unravel after reporting disappointing Q4 results Friday. Nine of the eleven S&P 500 sectors were negative with the exception of the real estate and telecom sectors.makeArticleAd();At the same time
column9: gold was another $11 higher
column10: the dollar was weaker
column11: and the yield on the 10-year Treasury note was down 8% to 2.39%.There was no economic data on Monday.European equities were also lower for a third day in a row as overseas investors took their turn responding to Trump's inaugural speech
column12: with the UK's FTSE-100 finding additional pressure stemming from the recent surge in sterling. Germany's DAX underperformed its Euro-zone counterparts with a loss of 0.73% followed by a 0.70% drop in the Euro-Stoxx index.Crude oil was down $0.46 to $52.76 per barrel. Natural gas was up $0.05 to $3.26 per 1 million BTU. Gold was up $12.60 points to $1

column1: Qualcomm Stock Tumbles Following Apple Lawsuit;January 23
column3: 12:38:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Getty Images.What happenedShares of mobile chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) fell sharply on Monday as analysts downgraded the   stock following news thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) was suing the company. This lawsuit came just a   few days after the Federal Trade Commission formally charged   Qualcomm over anti-competitive behavior. Qualcomm stock was down   about 13% at 11:15 a.m. EST.So whatOn Friday of last week
column4: Apple accused Qualcomm of unfairly   charging excessive royalties for its technology. Furthermore
column5: Apple alleged that Qualcomm withheld $1 billion in payments as   retaliation for Apple's cooperation with agencies investigating   the company.makeArticleAd();Just a few days earlier
column6: the FTC filed a complaint in federal   district court charging Qualcomm with ""using anti-competitive   tactics to maintain its monopoly in the supply of a key   semiconductor device used in cellphones and other consumer   products."" Specifically
column7: the FTC alleges that Qualcomm uses a ""no   license
column8: no chips"" policy
column9: refuses to license standard-essential   patents to competitors
column10: and extracted exclusivity from Apple in   exchange for reduced patent royalties in an effort to prevent   Apple from working with its competitors.Two analyst downgrades came on Monday following these   developments. Nomura analyst Romit Shah downgraded Qualcomm stock   to ""neutral"" due to the unexpected breadth of the lawsuits and   the subsequent uncertainty surrounding Qualcomm's acquisition ofNXP Semiconductors. CLSA also downgraded the stock to ""underperform.""Now whatQualcomm derives the bulk of its profits from its licensing   business
column11: which makes these two lawsuits particularly dangerous   for the company. Both are an attack on Qualcomm's extremely   lucrative business model
column12: which could be upended in the   worst-case scenario.Qualcomm has disputed the FTC complaint
column13: saying that it's   based on a flawed legal theory
column14: a lack of economic support
column15: and   significant misconceptions about the mobile technology industry.   Qualcomm also dismissed the claims in Apple's lawsuit as   baseless. These lawsuits will take time to play out
column16: and changes   to the FTC under the Trump administration could complicate things   further. Investors are taking the threats seriously
column17: though
column18: erasing the gains made by shares of Qualcomm during the second   half of 2016.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column19: it can pay to listen. After all
column20: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
