column1: The Pain Is Only the Beginning for Qualcomm
column4: 12:20:45 PM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsQualcomm
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) fell 13% in early trade on Monday afterApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column7: its largest customer
column8: dropped a large legal bomb on it this past Friday.Source: ShutterstockThe lawsuit
column9: filed in southern California late on Jan. 20
column10: alleges that Qualcomm withheld $1 billion in rebates in retaliation for Apple cooperating with Korean efforts to openthe radio chip market.makeArticleAd();The lawsuit follows a Federal Trade Commission (FTC) suit charging Qualcomm with cutting its prices to Apple in exchange for exclusivity
column11: thenusing that dealagainst other cell phone companies.The suits are direct assaults on Qualcomm's business model
column12: which is to license patents essential for getting into the mobile phone business and use those agreements to create a virtual monopoly in the chips needed for the phones to work.Governments Weigh InIn December
column13: for instance
column14: Korean regulatorsfined Qualcomm $864 millionover its patent licensing practices.Korea acted afterSamsung Electronics Co. Ltd.(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column15: a major chip supplier
column16: backed down in its ongoing dispute with Qualcomm
column17: which has tied its patent rights to its production of chips for decades. Samsung returned to Qualcomm as a supplier of modem chips for the Galaxy 7 after making its own chips for the Galaxy 6.3 Bullish Stock Charts That Scream ""Buy     Me!""Earlier
column18: China had gotten Qualcomm to accept a$975 million fineand to adjust business practices after a multi-year dispute concerning its licensing practices.At the time
column19: investors took this to be an all-clear concerning Qualcomm's business practices
column20: with the stock rising almost 20% in a month and hitting a high of $70 in November
column21: when Qualcomm announced net income of $1.6 billion on revenues of $6.184 billion
column22: meaning $1 in each $4 brought into the company was reaching the net income line. Those margins had been under pressure in 2015
column23: during the worst of the company's fight with China.Early this month it seemed the China deal was opening up vast new markets for Qualcomm
column24: after it signedpatent deals with other Chinese cellphone makers
column25: most recently withMeizu and Gionee.Now it would seem that the China agreement meant Qualcomm's legal problems were just starting
column26: which is why QCOM stock is under pressure.Monopoly Rights ThreatenedIn addition to the Apple and Korean actions
column27: European regulators have their own charges pending
column28: claiming that Qualcomm is using patents essential to industry standards to maintain an illegal monopoly over the production and sale of the required chips.Those charges couldimperilQualcomm'spending purchaseofNXP Semiconductors NV(NASDAQ:NXPI)
column29: a Dutch company
column30: announced in late October at a price then described as being $110/share. As of today
column31: NXPI was trading at $96.31/share.What's of greatest concern in the Apple suit is that Qualcomm was Apple's sole chip supplier until last year
column32: whenIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) got contracts to supply half those needed for the iPhone 7. It was after that action that
column33: Apple alleges
column34: Qualcomm took actions against it; actions it now says were illegal.While Qualcomm does make substantial profits from making and selling its Snapdragon line of modem chips
column35: most of its profits come from licensing basic technologies essential to entry into the business
column36: such as 3G and 4G
column37: to phone makers.Standards Essential Patents (SEPs)
column38: patents that are essential to a market operating are supposed to be licensed under what are calledFair
column39: Reasonable and Non-Discriminatoryterms (FRAND). But what is fair
column40: what is reasonable and what is non-discriminatory can be subject to dispute
column41: and that's what the war with Qualcomm is about.United Continental Holdings Inc (UAL) Stock     Could Fake Us All OutWith governments weighing-in alongside its biggest customer
column42: a deal that Qualcomm thought meant the end of its legal troubles may turn out to have been just the beginning of them. Thus
column43: the stock is falling. Qualcomm's existence as a major supplier is not threatened
column44: but its monopoly profits may be.Dana   Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author   of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column45: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in INTC and AAPL.More From InvestorPlace6 Dividend Growth Stocks Raising Dividends Like     Clockwork10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You     BackThe postThe Pain Is Only the Beginning for Qualcomm

column1: The $1 Billion Question: Did Apple
column2: Inc. Rat Out Qualcomm to the Feds?;January 23
column4: 12:00:00 PM EDT;"Image source: Apple.There's a lot going on inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) lawsuit againstQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) . One of the main things that Apple is seeking is   nearly $1 billion that it says Qualcomm owes. Apple has been   paying what it considers inflated royalties for years
column5: which are   passed along in full from its contract manufacturers that have   inked licensing deals with Qualcomm. Qualcomm is supposed to   license its patents at fair
column6: reasonable
column7: and non-discriminatory   (FRAND) rates.makeArticleAd();The two companies had previously reached a Business   Cooperation and Patent Agreement (BCPA)
column8: which includes quarterly   payments to Apple in exchange for other concessions
column9: the most   important being exclusivity in supplying baseband processors to   Apple. But these payments are also contingent on Apple mostly   keeping quiet about the two companies' business arrangements
column10: a   provision that Apple believes is intended to hide Qualcomm's   alleged anticompetitive behavior. However
column11: the terms of the BCPA   were never meant to preclude Apple from cooperating with   government regulators if asked. At the heart of the issue is   whether or not regulators approached Apple first
column12: or if Apple   voluntarily ratted Qualcomm out to the Feds.Apple said
column13: Qualcomm saidIn Apple's complaint
column14: it argues that Qualcomm intentionally   tries to hide its behavior from regulators (emphasis in second   paragraph added):Preventing Apple from bringing its concerns to law       enforcement.As a condition of even partial relief from its non-FRAND     royalties
column15: Qualcomm sought to gag Apple and prevent     it from bringing its concerns to law enforcement     or challenging Qualcomm's compliance with FRAND     commitments.As described above
column16: through the second paragraph of Section     7 of the BCPA
column17: Qualcomm conditioned royalty relief on a     provision thatrestricted Apple from initiating or inducing     certain legal actionsin three particular identified areas: (a) assertion of     patents against Qualcomm; (b) claims that Qualcomm failed to     offer a license to its [standards-essential patents] on     FRAND terms; and (c) claims that Qualcomm's patent rights     were exhausted....The BCPA carved out
column18: as it must
column19: an acknowledgment that     Apple has a responsibility to respond to enforcement     agencies' requests for information. But in restraining Apple     from initiating action or bringing concerns to law     enforcement
column20: Qualcomm conditioned billions of dollars on     Apple's silence before courts and regulators about Qualcomm's     business practices.That bit on ""initiating or inducing"" is a key piece here. If   Apple was the one initiating the regulatory investigation
column21: then   it could be in breach of the BCPA terms
column22: and as such Qualcomm   would be able to withhold payment. But Apple maintains that it   did no such thing:Apple has provided information and presentations only     at the requests of the agencies. Apple has not ""induced""     any agency or any other third party to take action against     Qualcomm on grounds that Qualcomm's licensing practices     violated the FRAND promise or that Qualcomm's patents were     exhausted.Apple has complied with all other conditions and     requirements of the BCPA.Naturally
column23: Qualcomm's perspective is different. The mobile   chip giant issued a briefpress releaseto comment on Apple's complaint last week. Here's what Qualcomm   general counsel Don Rosenberg had to say (emphasis added):Apple has intentionally mischaracterized our agreements and     negotiations
column24: as well as the enormity and value of the     technology we have invented
column25: contributed and shared with all     mobile device makers through our licensing program.Apple has been actively encouraging regulatory     attackson Qualcomm's business in various jurisdictions around the     world
column26: as reflected in the recent [Korea Fair Trade Commission]     decision and FTC complaint
column27: by misrepresenting facts and     withholding information.Qualcomm's response suggests that Apple has been more active   in ""inducing"" regulatory actions against Qualcomm. Furthermore
column28: Qualcomm thinks Apple is misrepresenting the pair's relationship   and business dealings. The Mac maker is looking for a wide range   of concessions
column29: but that $1 billion seems to be hanging in the   balance of whether or not Apple instigated regulatory action
column30: or   if it was merely cooperating with regulators as required by   law.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column31: it can pay to listen. After all
column32: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column33: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column34: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Why Apple's Lawsuit Against Qualcomm Has More Teeth Than the FTC's;January 23
column4: mobile chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) found itself on the receiving end of not one
column5: but   two antitrust complaints:one from the Federal Trade Commission(FTC)
column6: followed shortly thereafter by one fromApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . That sounds like a powerful double whammy of   litigation
column7: but the FTC's complaint may not actually have all   that much staying power due to the recent presidential   administration change.Apple's complaint
column8: on the other hand
column9: carries no such   concerns.The Trump factorThe FTC's complaint was initiated following a 2-1 vote. There   are typically five commissioners that are nominated by the   president and must be confirmed by the Senate. They serve   staggered terms that last seven years
column10: and there can not be more   than three commissioners from the same political party. There are   currently two vacancies
column11: but there are about to be three.   Chairwoman Edith Ramirez
column12: a Democrat that was appointed by   President Obama in 2010
column13: has announced her resignation effective   next month.makeArticleAd();FTC Chairwoman Edith Ramirez resigns next month. Image     source: FTC.gov.Of the two remaining commissioners
column14: Maureen Ohlhausen   (Republican) and Terrell McSweeny (Democrat)
column15: Ohlhausen was the   dissenting opinion that voted against the suit. Ohlhausen even   took the rare move of issuing adissenting statement(link opens PDF)
column16: believing that ""the complaint fails to allege   that Qualcomm charges more than a reasonable royalty."" The   commissioner says that she has ""been presented with no robust   economic evidence of exclusion and anticompetitive effects.""President Trump has tapped former FTC commissioner Joshua   Wright to advise on the FTC transition
column17: and Trump is expected to   bring back a Republican majority to the FTC for the first time in   nearly a decade
column18: along with a lighter regulatory stance. Despite   Trump's anti-establishment rhetoric throughout the campaign
column19: which at face value would suggest that he'd nominate outsiders
column20: Trump's recent nominations for other agency positions are   decidedly from the Republican establishment (including   Wright).The new commissioners will be inheriting a complaint that they   are unlikely to feel strongly about. As such
column21: it's quite possible   that Qualcomm can settle the lawsuit relatively quickly and on   more favorable terms.Apple is done being quietIn contrast
column22: Apple's suit is unaffected by such political   matters. This lawsuit isn't likely to go away anytime soon
column23: and   the new administration has no direct bearing on the damages that   Apple is seeking. Unlike regulatory suits
column24: which often end in   fines and other types of negotiated concessions
column25: Apple is seeking   nearly $1 billion that it says it is owed from Qualcomm
column26: which   Qualcomm has been withholding in retaliation for the Mac maker   cooperating with South Korean antitrust regulators.Image source: Apple.Apple also wants the court to help it obtain a direct license   for Qualcomm's patents at more favorable terms. Apple is seeking   disgorged royalties that it says have been ""extortion-level
column27: and   wants to legally prohibit Qualcomm from voluntarily interrupting   Apple's supply of baseband processors. More broadly
column28: Apple is   effectively asking for help in restructuring the royalties that   it has to pay
column29: arguing that Qualcomm's current practice of   setting royalty rates as a percentage of the final product's   sales price is inappropriate.Simply put
column30: Apple's case has more teeth than the FTC's because   it's here to stay
column31: and the outcome has the potential to   significantly alter how Qualcomm does business with smartphone   makers and competing baseband suppliers alike
column32: especially if this   all plays out publicly. It sounds like Apple's relationship with   Qualcomm has been deteriorating for years
column33: and considering the   extent of what Apple is seeking in the way of damages
column34: it seems   unlikely that Apple and Qualcomm will simply kiss and make   up.It's still possible that it will get settled behind closed   doors
column35: and we're all familiar with Apple's penchant for secrecy.   But Apple's rare move of suing one of its most important   suppliers was intended to bring some of these practices to light
column36: practices that Qualcomm has allegedly obfuscated for a decade   with a sprawling web of confidentiality agreements.Apple feels like it has been forcefully silenced all these   years from speaking out against alleged anticompetitive behavior   -- this suit seems predicated partially on principle. Apple has   been quietly fighting Qualcomm for years
column37: and it wants to be loud   now. Settling wouldn't just feel like a financial compromise
column38: but   a moral one
column39: too.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column40: it can pay to listen. After all
column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Suit Against Qualcomm
column4: 10:58:12 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) dropped a bombshell on one of its biggest partners
column6: Qualcomm
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) last Friday. Apple filed a complaint in U.S. District Court seeking $1 billion for monopolistic behavior. AAPL stock holders likely won't be impressed with the flimsy amount - after all
column8: Apple brought in more than $215 billion in revenues last year.Source: ShutterstockBut the litigation could have a material impact on Apple stock over the long haul.makeArticleAd();At the heart of the suit is Qualcomm's baseband chips
column9: which allow smartphones to connect to mobile networks. Without this core technology
column10: you actually wouldn't be able to do much with your device. QCOM has protected this technology with an extensive set of patents
column11: and has established global standards for the mobile industry.While AAPL stock saw little initial reaction - it was up less than 1% on the news. But QCOM saw action
column12: with shares down a grueling 10%.Qualcomm is the target of various governmental lawsuits regarding anti-competitive behavior and unreasonable royalties. Justlast week
column13: the U.S. Federal Trade Commission filed a suit (though this may ultimately be undone by the Trump administration). Then there was a similar action brought by the European Union
column14: as well as a fine of $975 million from the Chinese government.7 Straight-A Stocks to Build Your Portfolio     AroundBut the suit that has gotten most of the attention - and that's at the heart of Apple's own actions - is from the Korea Fair Trade Commission
column15: which has levied a penalty of $865 million. QCOM is vigorously pushing back
column16: claiming that its technologies are top-notch and the financial terms are within industry norms.AAPL thinks this is laughable.Apple says that Qualcomm is withholding rebates withholding rebates because of its cooperation with Korean authorities. AAPL also is alleging that it was coerced into buying QCOM chips
column17: on an exclusive basis
column18: to get relief on some royalties. This arrangement lasted from 2011 to 2016.But for the most part
column19: the real issue for Apple is that Qualcomm's royalties are steep
column20: coming to as much as 5% of the average price of an iPhone. By comparison
column21: typical chip operators likeTexas Instruments Incorporated(NASDAQ:TXN) andBroadcom Ltd(NASDAQ:AVGO) generally charge pennies per unit because of the large volumes.Is it any wonder that QCOM is so profitable? During the past five years
column22: the company generated a whopping$32 billionin pretax profits.According to areportfrom RBC's Amit Daryanani:""It would be more material if AAPL gets a lower price on IP licensing vs. what they currently pay to QCOM (QTL portion of the revenues). Furthermore
column23: in theory AAPL could procure basebands from INTC at perhaps lower ASP's and that could be another tailwind to AAPL's gross-margins (QCOM's QCT revenue).""Then there is this from Bernstein Research analystStacy Rasgon:""Rather
column24: AAPL is attempting a direct assault on Qualcomm's basic licensing business model
column25: attacking the 'essential' nature of their IP
column26: and directly targeting QCOM's device-level royalty model. The suit doesn't read well for the future of the chipset relationship either.""Bottom Line On AAPL StockNaturally
column27: there's plenty of daylight between now and any sort of decision
column28: let alone any impact of Apple shares. Litigation is time-consuming and far from predictable.Why Sprint Corp (S) Stock Could Blow Up in Your     FaceIn the meantime
column29: the key for Apple is the upcoming iPhone 8. And there are encouraging signs that this could be the turnaround spark AAPL stock needs. The buzz is that there will be whiz-bang features like gesture and facial recognition
column30: as well as wireless charging and OLED (organic light-emitting diode) screens
column31: which will be thinner and perhaps even allow for bending.What's more
column32: the valuation on Apple stock remains attractive
column33: with a forward price-to-earnings multiple of just 12X. This is at a discount to other mega-tech operators
column34: such asMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) at 19X andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) at 14 - and they certainly don't have the kinds of products that will gin up anywhere near the excitement (or potential growth) of a new iPhone.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand also is the developer of aniOS app for taxes.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column35: he did not hold a position in any of the   aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 Best High-Yield Investments for     RetirementThe 7 Best REITs to Buy for High Yield AND     GrowthThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Suit Against Qualcomm
column36: Inc. (QCOM) Is the Real Dealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Samsung (SSNLF): TWO Different Battery Failures on Galaxy Note 7;January 23
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) held a press conference this weekend that was buried by coverage of the U.S. presidential inauguration and the Women's March on Washington. The company announced the final results of its Galaxy Note 7 investigation
column5: and according to Samsung
column6: there was not one buttwoseparate Galaxy Note 7 battery flaws to blame.Source:Sylwia Bartyzel Via UnsplashThe second was introduced in the replacement battery after the initial issue was discovered.makeArticleAd();Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 Testing MarathonIt was pretty obvious once Galaxy Note 7s started bursting into flames that the battery was involved. But when the problems continued with replacement smartphones using a new battery from a different supplier
column7: suddenly the root cause got murkier.At thepress conference
column8: Samsung explained just how deeply it investigated the Galaxy Note 7.10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You     BackEverything from the new USB-C port
column9: to wireless charging and even software overload was closely studied and eliminated as a factor. So was Samsung's manufacturing process. The company built four test facilities (one at each site where it assembled the doomed smartphone) and put 700 engineers to work testing 200
column10: 000 Galaxy Note 7s plus 30
column11: 000 Galaxy Note 7 battery packs on their own. External testers from three different firms were also added to the teams.Exploding Galaxy Note 7 Battery Cause: Almost UnbelievableThe result?It turns out that SSNLF got hit by an almost unbelievable coincidence.In its rush to take advantage of the expected low-keyApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone 7 launch
column12: it used a battery sourced from an unnamed supplier
column13: that had a hidden design flaw. The battery lacked sufficient space to expand and contract - as batteries do - when charging and discharging. As a result
column14: the battery's electrodes could touch
column15: then short circuit. This issue was not caught by the battery manufacturer.Samsung pointed out that for its own quality assurance team to have noticed the problem
column16: they would have had to X-Ray the batteries.Batteries from a second supplier (also un-named) used in some Galaxy Note 7s were fine. They became the go-to replacement batteries once the first wave of trouble began. However
column17: Samsung then pushed that second supplier to dramatically increase its Galaxy Note 7 battery production volume.The demand to quickly churn out 10 million batteries overwhelmed that company's production capability and manufacturing defects crept in. A faulty internal weld could cause these replacement batteries to also short circuit and again
column18: the defect was not visible.Samsung's Safety Pledge and the Galaxy S8Samsung took full responsibility for the Galaxy Note 7 battery fiasco
column19: admitting that it had pushed suppliers and the limits of the manufacturing process.Going forward
column20: the company is implementing an8-point battery safety checkthat includes accelerated usage testing
column21: durability tests
column22: X-Ray examination and physically disassembling the batteries.In recognition that lithium-ion batteries can be extremely volatile
column23: Samsung has also committed to leaving more space around the battery packs in its smartphones going forward. While this runs contrary to the ""thinner at all cost"" mentality that Samsung and Apple have been pursuing
column24: additional buffer space will protect the battery from impacts.In aninterview with Recode
column25: Samsung's mobile division head said: ""I wish [that] this serves as an opportunity to improve safety of lithium-ion not only for Samsung but for the entire industry.""Samsung also made it clear that the Galaxy S8 - due for release this spring - will be covered by the enhanced battery safety procedures.Bank of America Corp's (BAC) Irrational     Exuberance Will EndThat Galaxy S8 launch will be the critical test of whether SSNLF truly recovers from the Galaxy Note 7 battery fiasco. The chapter is estimated to havecost the company $10 billion
column26: Samsung stock took a hit (although strong performance by its chips division more than made up for that) and its brand was damaged.If consumers accept Samsung's findings
column27: apology and pledge to prevent this from happening in the future
column28: the Galaxy S8 could see a sales rebound. If the Galaxy Note 7 battery episode still surrounds the company
column29: Apple's iPhone 8 stands a chance of clawing back share from Android when it launches in the fall and the Samsung's place on top of the Android pyramid could ultimately be in doubt.As of this writing
column30: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party     (AAPL)3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in     2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon     and Google's TurfThe postSamsung (SSNLF): TWO Different Battery Failures on Galaxy Note 7appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Here Are the Most Damning Parts of Apple's Blockbuster Lawsuit Against Qualcomm;January 23
column4: Apple finally added   another baseband supplier in the iPhone 7. Image source:   Apple.Just days after the Federal Trade Commission suedQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) for antitrust concerns
column5: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) took an unprecedented step of similarly filling   suit against one of its most important suppliers. The complaints   are largely the same
column6: but Apple felt compelled to file its own   lawsuit in part to get nearly $1 billion that it says it is owed.   According to the complaint
column7: Qualcomm gives Apple rebates that   effectively serve as royalty relief
column8: but in exchange Apple has   agreed to buy baseband processors exclusively from the company   for the past five years. It's these rebates that Qualcomm is now   withholding since Apple has cooperated with antitrust regulators   around the world.makeArticleAd();AppleInsider's Mikey Campbell unearthed the entire 104-page   complaint and posted it onScribd. I'd encourage Apple investors to give it a look
column9: but for those   that aren't inclined to spend their weekends reading legal   complaints
column10: I've read through it in full and here are the most   damning things that Qualcomm is being accused of. (All bold   emphasis added by me.)Qualcomm tried to get Apple to change its testimonyThe Korea Fair Trade Commission (KFTC) fined Qualcomm $853   million just last month
column11: based in part on Apple's testimony to   the KFTC. When Qualcomm learned that Apple would be cooperating   with the investigation
column12: it tried to use the royalty rebates as   leverage:Qualcomm claims that Apple has forfeited those amounts by     responding to requests in the course of an investigation by the     Korea Fair Trade Commission (""KFTC"")
column13: which recently levied the     largest fine in its history against Qualcomm. Qualcomm has     withheld the required contractual payments from Apple even     though the agreement clearly permits Apple to respond to the     KFTC's lawful investigation and requests for information.If that were not enough
column14: Qualcomm then attempted to     extort Apple into changing its responses and providing     false information to the KFTC in exchange for Qualcomm's     release of those payments to Apple. Apple refused.There's little enforcement of whether patents are actually   essentialWhen patents are deemed standards-essential by   standard-setting organizations (SSOs)
column15: they become incredibly   powerful. But companies are able to declare their patents as   essential
column16: and SSOs do not validate these claims:Patent owners
column17: like Qualcomm
column18: can claim that their patents     are SEPs without having to prove that they are essential. Many     SSOs expressly declare that they do not test declarations of     essentiality or validity for accuracy. For example
column19: one widely     recognized SSO
column20: the European Telecommunications Standards     Institute (""ETSI"")
column21: affirmatively states that it has ""No     involvement"" in ""the assessment of the validity and     essentiality of patents declared as SEPs.""Apple is challenging the validity of some of Qualcomm's   standards-essential patents (SEPs).Qualcomm has violated its FRAND commitmentsCompanies that have SEP portfolios are required to license   those patents to rivals at fair
column22: reasonable
column23: and   non-discriminatory (FRAND) rates. Qualcomm is egregiously   refusing to offer FRAND licensing:Violation of the FRAND bargain can take several forms
column24: including demanding unreasonable royalties; applying royalties     discriminatorily (for example
column25: charging different licensees     different amounts or imposing differing conditions on different     licensees
column26: or conditioning royalties on licensees' agreement to     advantage the patent owner's products); and asserting that     patents are essential to the standard when in fact they are     not.Qualcomm is guilty of all three.Rivals never had a chanceMany companies have exited the baseband processor market over   the past decade. It wasn't just intense competition
column27: either --   they never had a chance because Qualcomm cornered the market by   leveraging its patent portfolio:By refusing to license its SEPs to competing chipset     manufacturers
column28: and by refusing to sell its chipsets to     customers unless they first license Qualcomm's SEPs
column29: Qualcomm     forced purchasers of its chipsets to take a license to its SEPs     at extortion-level royalties. By threatening ""disloyal"" chipset     customers with even less-favorable royalties and license terms     if they purchased chipsets from Qualcomm's competitors
column30: discriminating between potential licensees by refusing to     license its SEPs to competitors
column31: and offering only ""rebates""     rather than a direct FRAND license
column32: Qualcomm excluded     competition in the chipset market. And by foreclosing     competitors from dealing with Apple
column33: a key purchaser of     chipsets
column34: Qualcomm facilitated the marginalization and exit of     many of those competitors
column35: enhancing its own monopoly     power.Apple's contract manufacturers are partially responsibleApple doesn't license Qualcomm's patents directly
column36: and not for   a lack of trying. Instead
column37: its contract manufacturers ink   licensing deals
column38: and subsequently pass along the royalty costsin fullto Apple. The contract manufacturers like Foxconn don't bother   negotiating
column39: since Apple foots the bill. These agreements are   confidential
column40: and Qualcomm won't even let Apple see them:Rather than grant Apple a direct license on FRAND terms
column41: Qualcomm has instead entered into confidential licenses with     specific Apple contract manufacturers (""CMs"")
column42: the third-party     manufacturers who make and assemble Apple products. The CMs pay     the exorbitant royalties Qualcomm demands and pass the costs     along to Apple in full.Qualcomm uses these secret licenses to conceal its     anticompetitive licensing practices. Here is how it works:     Qualcomm knows that Apple is shouldering the entire royalty     burden
column43: but by licensing the CMs and not Apple
column44: Qualcomm can demand higher royalties because the CMs     have no incentive to negotiate.In fact
column45: the CMs have agreed to license Qualcomm's SEPs on     non-FRAND terms
column46: locking Apple into outrageous royalties. And     the agreements are confidential; Apple cannot even see or     review them. The CMs have expressed willingness to show Apple     their Qualcomm licenses
column47: subject to Qualcomm's consent
column48: but     Qualcomm has refused to give that consent.Apple pays more for lessQualcomm is but one of many companies that hold SEPs and   contribute to cellular standards. Apple has to pay Qualcomm more   than everyone else combined:Qualcomm's exorbitant royalties are price gouging
column49: plain and     simple: between [REDACTED] per device
column50: [REDACTED]. In 2016
column51: this was an order of magnitude greater than the royalties that     Apple pays to any other patent holder
column52: and indeed ismore than Apple pays to all other cellular patent     holders combined.Qualcomm used Apple to kill WiMAXOnce upon a time
column53: WiMAX was a competing 4G standard. Apple   never released a WiMAX iPhone
column54: which helped contribute to the   standard's loss to LTE
column55: which has emerged as the dominant 4G   technology:The 2007 Marketing Incentive Agreement (""MIA"") capped     Apple's royalties for UMTS chipsets
column56: payable at that time on     purchases of Infineon's chipsets. In exchange
column57: Apple was     obliged to refrain from marketing wireless devices implementing     a competing wireless communication standard
column58: WiMAX. Qualcomm     forced Apple to renounce WiMAX just as WiMAX was gaining     traction in the marketplace.Qualcomm acted to eliminate the competitive threat     posed by WiMAX by ensuring that Apple would not market wireless     devices with WiMAX technology.This has been going on for nearly a decadeThe iPhone is now10 years old
column59: and as such Apple has been seeking a direct license ever   since.Fornearly ten years
column60: Qualcomm has failed to offer Apple a license for its cellular     SEPs on FRAND terms.Qualcomm makes money when you upgrade storageSince Qualcomm's royalty structure is calculated as a   percentage of the device's price
column61: the company collects more for   more expensive phones:In addition
column62: a royalty base premised on final selling prices     means that Qualcomm charges manufacturers of high-value
column63: feature-rich smartphones substantially more for a license than     it charges manufacturers of basic cellphones
column64: despite the fact that the embodied wireless     communications functionality in the two products is     similar or identical.This is inconsistent with the FRAND promise.Compared to a $100 Kyocera LTE smartphone
column65: Apple estimates   that its royalty payment for a $400 iPhone SE is ""four to nine   times more than Kyocera's royalty for its smartphone."" That also   means Qualcomm collects more when customers pay as much as $200   more for increased storage capacity
column66: a feature that has nothing   to do with cellular connectivity.Apple has wanted to bring on competing basebands suppliers   for yearsIt goes without saying that Apple considers a wide range of   suppliers for nearly all of its components
column67: considering the   significant benefits of dual-sourcing (reduced supply risk
column68: increased leverage in pricing negotiations
column69: etc.). But it   couldn't:Given the opportunity
column70: many device manufacturers
column71: including     Apple
column72: would prefer to license Qualcomm's SEPs at FRAND rates
column73: and to purchase baseband processor chipsets from     Qualcomm's competitors
column74: rather than be forced to purchase from     Qualcomm a bundle comprising a license to Qualcomm's SEPs and     substantial quantities of baseband processor chipsets....Although Apple hasfor many years been ready and able to switcha smaller portion of its baseband processor chipset     purchases (e.g.
column75: for non-CDMA iPads) to Qualcomm's rivals
column76: Qualcomm's imposition of exclusivity has prevented Apple from     switching suppliers on a less than full-line basis
column77: even withnon-Qualcomm chipsets priced substantially lower than     comparable Qualcomm chipsets.There's more where that came fromThese are the most interesting snippets within the filing
column78: but   there is a lot of other information about Apple's contentious   relationship with Qualcomm over the years. This case is going to   be a big storyline for the two companies in 2017
column79: and the legal   process could even potentially drag on for years unless Apple and   Qualcomm settle.If the pair make it to trial
column80: investors can expect even more   juicy details to finally see the light of day.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column81: it can pay to listen. After all
column82: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column83: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column84: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column4: 09:14:39 AM EDT;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column5: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsU.S. stock futures are pointed lower this morning over   concerns that President Donald Trump will pursue a protectionist   agenda. Traders are beginning to shift away from the U.S. dollar
column6: with the Japanese yen drawing a safe-haven bid
column7: and oil is also   moving lower. In earnings
column8: Halliburton Company(NYSE:HAL)
column9: McDonald's Corporation(NYSE:MCD) andYahoo! Inc.(NASDAQ:YHOO) will be in focus later today.Heading into the open
column10: futures on theDow Jones Industrial Averagehad slipped 0.1%
column11: whileS&P 500andNasdaq-100futures were both lower by 0.19%.makeArticleAd();On the options front
column12: Friday's Jan. 2017 expiration drove   massive volume with more than 21.3 million calls and 18.6 million   puts crossing the tape. Over on the CBOE
column13: the single-session   equity put/call volume ratio whipsawed from a one-month low of   0.59 on Thursday to a two-week high of 0.70. The 10-day moving   average
column14: however
column15: held steady at 0.65.Turning to Friday's volume leaders
column16: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) saw accelerated bullish bids following report the company is   planning new iPad launches in the first half of 2017. Elsewhere
column17: Rite Aid Corporation(NYSE:RAD) puts gained popularity after the Federal Trade Commission (FTC)   balked atWalgreens Boots Alliance Inc's(NASDAQ:WBA) buyout plan. Finally
column18: International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) hit a fresh all-time high following strong fourth-quarter   earnings.Apple Inc. (AAPL)AAPL stock finished Friday pinned at $120
column19: as heavy call and   put accumulations at the expiring Jan. 2017 $120 strike proved   too much for the stock to overcome.10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You       BackThe shares had plenty of bullish drivers on the session
column20: including a report that Apple was preparing to launch a slate of   revamped iPads in the first half of 2017.Specifically
column21: apre-publication note in DigiTimessaid that Apple is building a ""9.7-inch iPad with a friendly   price range"" for the first quarter
column22: with an updated 12.9-inch   iPad Pro and a 10.5-inch iPad for the second quarter. However
column23: the note doesn't call the 12.9-inch iPad a ""Pro"" model.Volume was brisk on AAPL stock Friday
column24: with nearly 1.1 million   contracts traded on the shares. What's more
column25: calls accounted for   a well above average 71% of the day's take. Overall
column26: traders   remain heavily focused on the $120 strike in both the 27 Jan. and   3 Feb. series
column27: with the latter bearing the brunt of speculation   heading into next week's quarterly earnings report.Rite Aid Corporation (RAD)RAD put options were smart money ahead of Friday's selloff. On   Wednesday last week
column28: a trade publication reported expectations   for a WBA deal approval ahead of Trump's inauguration. Instead of   optimism
column29: RAD puts flooded the market.Friday brought a decision on the WBA deal
column30: with the FTC saying   that Walgreens's proposal to sell 865 drugstores toFred's
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:FRED) wasnot enough to seal the deal. In fact
column32: the FTC worried about Fred's taking over so many   stores.RAD stock plunged more than 13% on the news
column33: with options   traders once again turning to puts in the wake of the report.   Volume for RAD swelled to nearly 950
column34: 000 contracts
column35: with puts   snapping up 74% of the day's take. According toTrade-Alert.com
column36: the largest block trade on Friday took place at the Feb. 17 $6   put
column37: where 33
column38: 000 contracts traded at the bid of 28 cents
column39: hinting at expectations that RAD may find a floor before the   selling runs much further.International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)IBM shares vaulted to a fresh 52-week high following Friday's   better-than-expected quarterly report.IBM said it earned$5.01 per share on sales of $21.77 billion
column40: compared to   expectations for $4.88 per share on sales of $21.63 billion. The   company also boosted its 2017 guidance to $13.80 per share versus   the consensus estimate for $13.74 per share.United Continental Holdings Inc (UAL) Stock       Could Fake Us All OutIBM stock rose more than 2% following the report

column1: Qualcomm (QCOM) Faces $1B Patent Royalty Suit from Apple;January 23
column4: the largest mobile chipset manufacturer using baseband technology globally
column5: has recently been pressed with a $1 billion lawsuit related to licensing royalty payments by tech giant Apple Inc.AAPL. In the lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California
column6: Apple has accused Qualcomm of overcharging for chips and refusing to pay some $1 billion in promised rebates.Notably
column7: just a couple of days before filing of Apple's lawsuit
column8: Qualcomm had faced an anti-trust lawsuit from the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The regulator filed a lawsuit with the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California claiming that the company has used anticompetitive measures to maintain a monopoly in baseband chipset market.The FTC said Qualcomm had established an exclusivity agreement with iPhone and iPAD maker Apple from 2011 to 2016. Through this deal the San Diego-based chipmaker provided billions of dollars in license rebates to Apple subject to the condition that Apple would not use chipset of Qualcomm's rival companies. The company recognized that any competitor that won Apple's business would become stronger
column9: and used exclusivity of the deal to prevent the latter from working with and improving the effectiveness of its competitors.However
column10: Qualcomm argued that the FTC's complaint is based on ""flawed legal theory
column11: a lack of economic support and significant misconceptions about the mobile technology industry"". While the chipset maker observes major flaws in the accusations
column12: it is likely get a full hearing. In the last five trading days
column13: the stock price of Qualcomm has declined 5.34% on Nasdaq.The FTC alleged that Qualcomm has barred competitors from getting a foothold in the baseband chipset market by using unfair means to secure business
column14: thereby harming consumer choice. Notably
column15: Intel Corp.INTCand Media Tek are closest competitors of Qualcomm in this field. In addition to iOS
column16: Qualcomm chipsets are vastly used for Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle developed Android software and Microsoft Corp.MSFTdeveloped Windows operating system.Qualcomm generates approximately 29% of its total revenue from the licensing business however
column17: this business accounts for almost 77% of the company's net profit. Moreover
column18: the company has a history of facing allegations related to licensing disputes. The US regulator is latest in the line of accusers alleging Qualcomm of abusing its dominant position and imposing unfair licensing terms.In 2015
column19: the Chinese regulatory authority
column20: National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) fined Qualcomm nearly $975 million for abusing China's anti-competitive terms. In Dec 2016
column21: the company was fined nearly $886 million in South Korea for restrictive licensing practices. Moreover
column22: since 2011
column23: Qualcomm has been under investigation for competition violations in the European Union region.In its filing
column24: Apple has accused Qualcomm of pressurizing the company in providing false statement to South Korea's antitrust regulator
column25: the Korea Fair Trade Commission regarding the above mentioned anti-trust case in that country. Apple and Samsung Electronics are the two major customers of Qualcomm's chipsets for modems that connect phones to wireless networks. The two companies together accounted for over 40% of Qualcomm's $23.5 billion in revenue in fiscal 2016 (ended in Sep 2016). Thus
column26: a royalty lawsuit from Apple may harm Qualcomm in big way.Price Performance of QualcommIn the last one year
column27: the stock price of Qualcomm has gained a substantial 32.16% compared with 5.97% loss witnessed by the Zacks categorizedWireless Equipmentindustry. Qualcomm
column28: the undisputed leader in the global wireless baseband chipset market is widening its presence in adjacent opportunities
column29: including automotive
column30: networking
column31: and mobile computing strategies which bode well for long-term growth. Qualcomm's Snapdragon processor is best known for its versatility in IoT applications.However
column32: aggressive competition in the mobile phone chipset market
column33: stringent regulatory norms and anti-competitive charges are some of the major headwinds faced by the company. We believe that these are the reasons behind the company's currently carrying a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: Will Samsung Be Able to Repair Its Brand Image?;January 21
column4: Samsung(SSNLF) andApple(AAPL) are the two foremost players in the worldwide smartphone industry followed by Huawei at the third position. Samsung is the undisputed leader in the smartphone industry
column5: as it holds 21% market share
column6: whereas Apple holds just 12.5% market share.Samsung was off to a great start in 2016
column7: and the company's momentum got a boost soon after the launch of its latest flagship Galaxy S7 models. According to t3.com
column8: before the launch of the Apple iPhone 7 Plus
column9: the Galaxy S7 Edge was the world's best smartphone. Samsung's Galaxy S7 Edge successfully managed to hold the world's best smartphone position for over six months.After the launch of the Galaxy S7 models
column10: Samsung launched its new flagship Galaxy Note 7
column11: which was intended to be a tough competitor for Apple's iPhone 7 models. Everything was moving in the right direction and in favour of Samsung until the Note 7 models started exploding.makeArticleAd();At the end
column12: Samsung was forced to terminate the production of Note 7 models and also announced an official recall of Note 7 devices because of the safety issues. The company reported that some batteries were irregularly sized that resulted in overheating
column13: whereas others had manufacturing defects. The detailed explanation on this topic will be unveiled on Jan. 23.Despite facing a severe problem
column14: Samsung managed to remain in the green in 2016
column15: thanks to the popularity of the Galaxy S7 models. However
column16: the company is trying hard to recover from the damage caused to its brand.For Samsung
column17: a quick comeback is essential for the sake of its reputation. The company's comeback phone could be its next flagship Galaxy S8 model. It is likely that Samsung will unveil its next flagship device next month at its upcoming Galaxy Unpacked event in Barcelona
column18: ahead of MWC.There are several rumours that Galaxy S8 will include a 4K screen
column19: a mini projector
column20: a 30 megapixel camera
column21: 6GB of RAM
column22: a mammoth battery as well as a supercharged processor.Summing upSamsung is well aware of its mistake and trying hard to repair its brand image. Samsung's Galaxy S7 models became very popular in 2016
column23: and same is expected from its upcoming flagship models this year. In comparison to Apple
column24: Samsung brings more innovation in its devices
column25: which make it a better investment candidate.Disclosure:No position in the stocks mentioned in this article.Start a free seven-day trial of Premium Membership to GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Will Apple Raise Its Dividend in 2017?;January 21
column3: 08:02:00 AM EDT;"The success ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has made many investors rich
column4: and throughout most   of the tech giant's history
column5: dividends played a tiny role.   Recently
column6: though
column7: Apple has embraced dividends
column8: and now
column9: some   income-hungry investors look to the iPhone maker for its   quarterly payouts as well as its potential for stock-price   increases. With tax reform proposals that could unlock some of   Apple's overseas cash stash
column10: Apple might be in a better position   than ever to consider a dividend boost this year. Let's look more   closely to see if Apple is likely to raise its dividend in   2017.Image source: Apple.Dividend stats on AppleCurrent Quarterly Dividend Per SharemakeArticleAd();$0.57Current Yield1.9%Number of Consecutive Years With Dividend             IncreasesFive yearsPayout Ratio27%Last IncreaseMay 2016Data source: Yahoo! Finance. Last increase refers to   ex-dividend date.Apple's dividend history is short but sweetLike many tech stocks
column11: Apple was slow to jump on the dividend   bandwagon. The company paid a small dividend during the late   1980s and early 1990s
column12: but it stopped making those payments in   1995 and left shareholders with a 17-year period during which   they received nothing in dividends from Apple.In 2012
column13: Apple restored its dividend
column14: setting a quarterly payout of about $0.38 per share when you   adjust for the 7-for-1 split the tech company made in 2014. That   worked out to a yield of a bit less than 2% and a payout ratio of   about 30% of Apple's earnings at the time
column15: which was in line with   what many other technology companies had done with their dividend   policies.Since then
column16: Apple has rewarded dividend investors with payout   boosts every year. Increases of 15% and 8% came in 2013 and 2014   respectively
column17: and subsequent increases have been roughly 10% each   year. Along the way
column18: Apple has become one of the biggest payers   of dividends in the stock market
column19: routinely sending more than $10   billion in capital back to shareholders every year through its   quarterly payouts.AAPL Dividenddata byYCharts.Yet not everyone was happy about Apple's emergence as a   dividend giant. Even when the dividend first began in 2012
column20: some   saw the move as a sign that Apple's days as a growth stock had   come to an end. Fears arose that Apple would begin to resemble   worse-performing mature tech stocks
column21: despite the success of its   budding lines of mobile devices.What's ahead for Apple?If nothing else
column22: the fact that Apple has achieved the largest   market capitalization of any stock in the market has reduced its   future growth potential to some extent. Yet the iPhone maker has   continued to increase its free cash flow
column23: securing funding   necessary for its double-digit percentage dividend increases each   year. Some criticize Apple's failure to deliver revolutionary   innovations in recent years
column24: but the company has effectively   taken advantage of still-strong demand for its mobile products   and has sustained customer loyalty with incremental evolutionary   changes to the devices over time.Indeed
column25: even with its dividend hikes over the years
column26: Apple's   payout ratio has fallen slightly
column27: now resting in the mid- to   upper-20s as a percentage of earnings. If Apple were to decide   that its growth potential had in fact slowed
column28: it would be natural   to pay a higher proportion of income to shareholders as   dividends
column29: and that could bring a big jump in yield to the   stock.Finally
column30: the potential for tax reform could prompt a different   approach to dividend policy. Currently
column31: Apple keeps considerable   amounts of cash overseas in order to avoid repatriation taxes.   With the incoming Trump administration considering tax cuts to   encourage businesses like Apple to bring capital back to the   U.S.
column32: the Cupertino-based tech giant might take advantage of such   provisions and boost the amount it returns to shareholders.Will Apple raise its dividend in 2017?For now
column33: Apple remains squarely in growth mode
column34: and so a   typical 10% increase would bring the quarterly dividend up to   $0.63 per share. At current prices
column35: that would push the yield   slightly above the 2% mark
column36: keeping pace with recent stock-price   gains. The tech giant has made a habit of announcing its annual   dividend increases in late April
column37: and there's no reason to expect   a departure from that practice in 2017. The only serious question   is whether any future change in tax policy could prompt a   response from Apple in accelerating its dividend growth going   forward.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column42: 2017Dan Caplingerowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Facebook to Build Energy-Efficient Data Center in Denmark;January 20
column3: 05:45:00 PM EDT;"Social-media giantFacebook IncFBrecently announced that it will build its new data center in Odense
column4: Denmark. The data center would be the third international data center for Facebook and is expected to create about 150 jobs.Expectedly
column5: the facility will cater to the surge in Internet usage and the demand for data storage capacity. McEntegart went on to add
column6: ""The Odense data center will be one of the most advanced
column7: energy-efficient data centers in the world.""The announcement is in line with Facebook's initiative of building energy efficient and environmental friendly facilities. Back in 2015
column8: Facebook built the 1 million dollar data center in Ft. Worth
column9: TX
column10: which uses clean wind energy to run.According to Fyens.dk sources
column11: the project valuation is more that $100 million and will include two large data centers and auxiliary structures for administration and other technical facilities. Reportedly
column12: the Danish project is expected to be completed and ready for functioning by the end of 2020.Facebook Inc. Price and ConsensusFacebook Inc. Price and Consensus|Facebook Inc. QuoteWith the growing use of Internet services especially cloud computing
column13: the need for data centers has also increased. These facilities comprise computer servers that process Internet searches
column14: emails and cloud computingAs per U.S. independent research firm
column15: Gartner
column16: data center hardware spending will grow to $177 billion in 2017. Booming cloud computing services and increasing use in mobile applications are boosting the demand for hard drives required to run them and pushing the need for big data centers and processing units. Based on this projection
column17: the company is attempting to capitalize on this opportunity.In fact
column18: Facebook is not the only company thinking on these lines. Other tech companies such as Apple Inc.AAPLand GoogleGOOGLhave also been engaged in expanding their data centers. In 2015
column19: Apple invested in a data center in Demark. Google built new facilities in Alabama and Georgia to meet the requirement of more data-intensive services
column20: such as Google search
column21: Gmail
column22: Google+ and YouTube.Positive Share Price MovementAt present

column24: Facebook's shares are up 35.46%

column12: and Amazon this quarter.First
column13: the hosts took a look at TargetTGT
column14: the latest traditional retailer to post disappointing holiday sales. column1: Qualcomm Faces a Nasty New Lawsuit Regarding Apple;January 20
column3: 01:43:00 PM EDT;"The U.S. Federal Trade Commission recently filed  an   antitrust lawsuit againstQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)
column4: claiming that the mobile chipmaker leveraged its   portfolio of crucial wireless patents to force competitors out of   the market. The Commission claims that Qualcomm charged its   baseband modem competitors higher license fees for its wireless   patents
column5: making it more expensive for smartphone makers to use   rival modems.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();At the center of this case isApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column6: which once considered launching an iPhone for   the 4G WiMax networks championed byIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) andSprint(NYSE: S) . Qualcomm opposed WiMax
column7: since it generated much lower   royalties from that standard
column8: and supported the LTE standard   instead.The FTC claims that to prevent Apple from launching a WiMax   iPhone after Sprint deployed its first WiMax network in 2008
column9: Qualcomm ""agreed to rebate to Apple royalties"" received from the   iPhone maker's contract manufacturers ""in excess of a specified   per-handset cap."" In other words
column10: Qualcomm allegedly let Apple   pay lower royalties to secure a long-term spot in the iPhone
column11: lock rivals out of the baseband market
column12: and deal a fatal blow to   the WiMax standard.The consequences of that dealThat alleged deal certainly helped Qualcomm
column13: which remained   Apple's exclusive supplier of baseband modems until the iPhone 7
column14: which uses both Qualcomm and Intel modems. Qualcomm's biggest   baseband modem rivals --Texas InstrumentsandBroadcom-- both retreated from the market as Qualcomm's market share   rose. The death of WiMax dealt a devastating blow to Sprint
column15: which had invested billions in a dying standard and was forced to   invest billions more in LTE networks.The FTC didn't outline any specific penalties against   Qualcomm
column16: but  ordered it ""to cease its anticompetitive   conduct and take actions to restore competitive conditions."" But   with the iPhone 7's modem production already split between   Qualcomm and Intel
column17: Qualcomm could easily argue that ""competitive   conditions"" have been restored.Furthermore
column18: Qualcomm could note that Intel's payment of   ""contra revenues"" (discounted chips
column19: co-marketing agreements
column20: and   financial assistance in redesigning logic boards) to OEMs in   exchange for using its mobile Atom chips was similar to its   rebate agreement with Apple.The sound and fury (probably) signifies     nothingMost importantly
column21: a Republican-led FTC probably won't   prosecute Qualcomm. The FTC voted  2-1 to charge Qualcomm --   with two Democrats supporting the lawsuit and one Republican
column22: Maureen K. Ohlhausen
column23: voting against it
column24: declaring that there was   ""no robust economic evidence"" of anticompetitive effects from the   deal.One of those Democrats has already resigned
column25: and the other   commissioner's term will expire soon. President-elect Trump is   expected to name Ohlhausen as  the acting chairwoman
column26: and   the new vacancies could be filled with Republicans who will   likely support Ohlhausen's argument. Therefore
column27: Qualcomm could   simply receive a slap on the wrist without any serious fines.But the antitrust drama isn't over yet...Even if the FTC lawsuit fades away
column28: Qualcomm still faces   billions of dollars in overseas fines. Chinese regulators hit   Qualcomm with a $975 million fine and forced it to lower its   licensing fees in 2015
column29: South Korea fined it $854 million at the   end of 2016
column30: and it could face up to $3 billion in additional   fines in Europe and Taiwan -- which are both currently   investigating the company for anticompetitive practices.These lawsuits could all hurt Qualcomm's QTL (licensing)   business
column31: which generates the lion's share of its profits and   offsets the lower margins of its QCT (chipmaking) business. With   margins declining across the heavily commoditized smartphone   market
column32: more OEMs and regulators will likely revolt against   Qualcomm's 3G/4G licensing fees -- which can  equal up to 5%   of a device's wholesale price. That could put tremendous pressure   on Qualcomm's earnings over the next few quarters.Should investors worry about these lawsuits?The lawsuits against Qualcomm reveal how badly the   commoditization of the smartphone market hurts the company. Its   QCT revenues are falling due to fierce competition from cheaper   ARM licensees like MediaTek
column33: but its QTL revenues are also being   weighed down by desperate OEMs which hope lower licensing fees   can help them squeeze out more profits per handset.These antitrust lawsuits won't sink Qualcomm
column34: which is   expected to generate nearly $24 billion in revenues this year.   But they represent a dangerous paradigm shift in the market
column35: and   explains why the chipmaker isaggressively diversifyinginto adjacent markets like connected cars
column36: drones
column37: wearables
column38: and   Internet of Things devices.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column41: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column43: 2017Leo Sunowns shares of Qualcomm. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Broadcom and Intel. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: Next iPhone May Have Wireless Charging;January 20
column4: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of wireless charging for the iPhone.   Today
column5: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.Wireless Charging:Another rumor claims that Apple's next iPhone   will have wireless charging
column6: reports9to5Mac. This rumor comes from insider sources within the tech company's   supply chain. It claims that orders for components that will be   used for wireless charging have already been obtained by some   companies. The rumors states that the wireless charging coming to   the next iPhone will work over long distances.makeArticleAd();Simply Mac:Several Simply Mac stores across the United   States are closing
column7: MacRumorsnotes. Simply Mac is a line of stores that are authorized by   Apple to resell and service its products. The chain is owned byGameStop Corp.(NYSE:GME). These closures come as GME faces poor sales and is promising   to close down stores that aren't profitable. However
column8: conflicting   reports claim that the stores are closing due to AAPL refusing to   continue its reseller agreement with the company.Meitu App:Users of the Meitu app on iOS devices should   be wary of it
column9: reportsAppleInsider. A recent report found that the app is collecting the private   information of users and sending it back to the developer. This   includes checking what wireless network the device is on
column10: giving   each device an ID based on its MAC address and checking to   see if the device has been jailbroken. The app is currently the   13th most popular in the App Store's free section. China-based   Xiamen Meitu Technology is the developer of the app.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: Next iPhone May Have   Wireless Chargingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Square Inc (SQ) Stock Needs to Make Some Money;January 20
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSquare Inc.(NYSE:SQ) has never been a money-making proposition. Like many tech companies
column5: net income has not been their thing
column6: man.Growthhas been their thing. Revenues rose from $552 million in 2013 to $1.267 billion two years later
column7: and that record will likely be beaten when the company next reports on Jan. 31.makeArticleAd();Source:Chris Harrison via Flickr (Modified)Analysts are expecting$451 million in revenue for the quarter
column8: or $1.307 billion for the year. The whisper on losses
column9: 8 cents per share
column10: would bring total losses for the year to 46 cents. Square survives on hope and cash flow
column11: which was slightly positive in 2015 and the third quarter of 2016. Its growth is slowing noticeably.But what if
column12: just for fun
column13: Square did something wild
column14: crazy
column15: and in-line with what the rest of the payments industry does
column16: and made a little money for shareholders?The stock would take off. It would take off bigly.How Square Stock Might Make MoneySquare is not going to make a net profit as a processor. It's not going to bypass exchange fees. Instead it's going to become profitable as a platform
column17: with a host of financial products attractive to its small business base.The 7 Best High-Yield Investments for RetirementAs our James Brumley wrote this weekthese include Square Capital
column18: whose loans havedoubled over the last year. Square is also offeringpayroll services
column19: inventory management and analyticsto its small business customers.This hope has sent SQ stock up 56% in the last six months
column20: which sounds great until you take the chart out a few months
column21: and see that stock hit another peak in April
column23: which took it higher than the present price of $14.90. At that point
column24: speculation on brighter days had pushed it to $15.13.Who Wants SQ Stock?Partly for that reason
column25: our Tom Taulli has another reason to buy Square stock.As takeout bait.Square has a powerful brand (at least within its niche)
column26: it's big in mobile
column27: and there are a lot of big tech companies that aren't in payments yet but might like a play there
column28: likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT).That's interesting
column29: but if SQ stock were going to be taken out
column30: the buyer would not likely come from that quarter. Processing is something a tech company can do for itself
column31: if it's interested in that low-margin business. There are easier ways to make money.It's more likely the buyer would come from the payments mainstream - processors likeFirst Data Corp(NYSE:FDC)
column32: PayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL) andVantiv Inc(NASDAQ:VNTV). These companies understand just how complex processing merchant payments are
column33: and what the capacity is worth. Wait a few years and maybe some banking organizations likeJP Morgan Chase & Co.(NYSE:JPM) orCapital One Financial Corp.(NYSE:COF) might come calling.A move by any of these players could set off a feeding frenzy in the industry
column34: one that would deliver shareholders a premium well over its current $5.3 billion price.That may be why a processor isn't making such a move. SQ stock is already bigger
column35: by market cap
column36: thanNCR Corporation(NYSE:NCR)
column37: which has been around since the 19th century.The ancillary businesses may also be unattractive. It's hard enough just processing payments.A winning premium would also make Square unaffordable for a merchant processor outfit like Vantiv
column38: worth $12.3 billion
column39: and make the merchants payment outfit vulnerable to takeover by one of the banks that distribute cards and serve the customer side of the transaction. MaybeIntuit Inc.(NASDAQ:INTU) orAmerican Express Company(NYSE:AXP) might be interested in upsetting the apple cart in that way
column40: but again you're talking about a less-profitable operation and
column41: in the case of Intuit (worth $30.1 billion)
column42: a deal that could soak up a lot of its market cap.A SpeculationThere are many companies that could make a move on SQ stock
column43: setting off a frenzy of merger activity in the payments space akin to what everyone keeps expecting will happen in media after Sumner Redstone dies and the sharks come forViacom
column44: Inc.(NASDAQ:VIAB).Is the Groupon Inc (GRPN) Comeback Done for Good?But waiting for such a frenzy
column45: betting on it with your money
column46: is speculation. Square today is still a money-losing proposition in an industry where losing money is uncommon
column47: and a company whose growth is slowing rapidly.Go for it if you wish
column48: but don't hock the silver. This is a mad money play.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column49: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AMZN

column1: Donald Trump Inauguration: Stocks To Buy
column2: Sell For The Next Four Years;January 20
column4: 11:29:41 AM EDT;"Donald Trump (Shutterstock photo)Donald Trump has been sworn in as the 45th president of the United States. The President-elect
column5: who pledged to Make America great again
column6: promised plenty of things he would do regarding his first day in office. From repealing and replacing Obamacare to renegotiating NAFTA and beginning the construction of the wall on the Mexican border.We wont know for certain which of Trumps policies will take priority or how they will be enforced. But what we do know is that for Trump to make good on his promises to bring back jobs
column7: grow GDP and strengthen industry
column8: he needs businesses to lead
column9: innovate and hire workers. For that to happen
column10: businesses leaders need to know their government is on their side. To that end
column11: here are some names to own for the next four years (at least) as Trumps policies take shape.makeArticleAd();Lower Corporate TaxesTrumps promise to lower corporate taxes can have a boosting effect on the tech sector
column12: which has an estimated $1.4 trillion stashed in overseas tax havens. These include some America's largest corporations such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT)
column13: which could face a huge tax hit if they bring that cash home. Not only has Trump promised to lower the business tax rate from 35% to 15%
column14: he pledged to eliminate the corporate alternative minimum tax.Beyond lowering the tax rate
column15: it would hardly shock anyone if Trump  given his pro-business stance  were to enact a tax holiday at some point during his presidency. Companies like Cisco (CSCO)
column16: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) would thrive. They would no longer need to borrow cheap cash to fund their operations. Likewise
column17: a better capitalized Tesla (TSLA) can accelerate the building of its Gigafactory
column18: helping it achieve not only higher profit margins
column19: but also higher vehicle production. In the process
column20: Tesla would ignite the state of Nevada as an innovative hub
column21: while mass-producing producing emission-free vehicles at affordable prices.Repeal and ReplaceThe Affordable Care Act
column22: a.k.a Obamacare was designed to  among other things  insure the un-insurable. Notably
column23: to provide insurance coverage to people with pre-existing conditions who were blocked under the then-existing rules. Depending on what side of the aisle youre on
column24: Obamacare either did its job or was a complete disaster
column25: according to Trump. Still
column26: whether Obamacare is entirely dismantled or parts of it is kept
column27: you dont have to look too far beyond UnitedHealth (UNH) to find a stock can will thrive.UnitedHealth has worked aggressively to exit the Affordable Care exchanges
column28: which reduces its  exposure to any changes Trump might make. Whats more
column29: added from being the nation's largest health insurer
column30: UnitedHealth owns Optum
column31: which provides pharmacy benefit management services. Last week
column32: not only did the company beat top- and bottom-line estimates
column33: UnitedHealth raised its fiscal 2017 financial outlook
column34: suggesting it is ready for whatever Trump decides to do.Not every company will be as lucky. Conversely
column35: companies such HCA Holdings (HCA) and Universal Health Services (UHS) that prospered under Obamacare may suffer. As will government health care providers such as Centene Corporation (CNC) and Molina Healthcare
column36: Inc. (MOH).Scale Back Dodd-FrankCutting down strict regulations imposed on financial institutions has been another policy Trump has proposed. After all
column37: how can he achieve economic growth and strengthen small business if banks aren't lending money  something banks collectively struggled to do under Dodd-Frank. But as evidenced by the strong earnings results released so far from the likes of Bank of America (BAC)
column38: JPMorgan Chase (JPM)
column39: Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS)
column40: financials are once again the sector to bank on.Written to strengthen consumer protection and create tougher rules on excessive risk-taking
column41: the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act has been cited by bank executives as a prohibiter of growth. ""There's many aspects of it that we've got to kill
column42: said Steven Mnuchin
column43: Trump's pick for Treasury secretary. Mnuchin former partner at Goldman Sachs
column44: called Dodd-Frank ""the number one priority on the regulatory side.To that end
column45: I would be surprised if Trump doesnt take to repeal and replace Dodd-Frank in his first 100 days in office. Combined with the prospect of higher interest rates
column46: lower taxes its tough to ignore the potential upside a bank like Morgan Stanley (MS) can provide. Its not just the big banks that will prosper
column47: however. Keep an eye on super regionals like Comerica (CMA)
column48: US Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial (PNC)
column49: which Trump has made great again."
